revision.text:
{{short description|Response of fish to environmental hypoxia}} Fish are exposed to large oxygen fluctuations in their aquatic environment since the inherent properties of water can result in marked spatial and temporal differences in the concentration of oxygen (see [[Oxygenation (environmental)|oxygenation]] and [[underwater]]). Fish respond to [[hypoxia (environmental)|hypoxia]] with varied behavioral, physiological, and cellular responses in order to maintain [[homeostasis]] and organism function in an oxygen-depleted environment. The biggest challenge fish face when exposed to low oxygen conditions is maintaining metabolic energy balance, as 95% of the oxygen consumed by fish is used for [[Adenosine triphosphate|ATP]] production through the [[electron transport chain]].<ref name= "Richards">{{Cite book | doi=10.1016/S1546-5098(08)00010-1|chapter = Chapter 10 Metabolic and Molecular Responses of Fish to Hypoxia|title = Hypoxia| volume=27| pages=443–485|series = Fish Physiology|year = 2009|last1 = Richards|first1 = Jeffrey G.| isbn=9780123746320}}</ref> Therefore, hypoxia survival requires a coordinated response to secure more oxygen from the depleted environment and counteract the metabolic consequences of decreased ATP production at the mitochondria. This article is a review of the effects of hypoxia on all aspects of fish, ranging from behavior down to genes.
==Hypoxia tolerance== A fish’s hypoxia tolerance can be represented in different ways. A commonly used representation is the critical O<sub>2</sub> tension (P<sub>crit</sub>), which is the lowest water O<sub>2</sub> tension (P<sub>O<sub>2</sub></sub>) at which a fish can maintain a stable O<sub>2</sub> consumption rate (M<sub>O<sub>2</sub></sub>).<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Claireaux|first1=G.|last2=Chabot|first2=D.|title=Responses by fishes to environmental hypoxia: integration through Fry's concept of aerobic metabolic scope|journal=Journal of Fish Biology|date=2016|volume=88|issue=1|pages=232–251|doi=10.1111/jfb.12833|pmid=26768976}}</ref> A fish with a lower P<sub>crit</sub> is therefore thought to be more hypoxia-tolerant than a fish with a higher P<sub>crit</sub>. But while P<sub>crit</sub> is often used to represent hypoxia tolerance, it more accurately represents the ability to take up environmental O<sub>2</sub> at hypoxic P<sub>O<sub>2</sub></sub>s and does not incorporate the significant contributions of [[anaerobic glycolysis]] and metabolic suppression to hypoxia tolerance (see below). P<sub>crit</sub> is nevertheless closely tied to a fish’s hypoxia tolerance,<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Mandic|first1=M.|last2=Speers-Roesch|first2=B.|last3=Richards|first3=J.G.|title=Hypoxia tolerance in sculpins is associated with high anaerobic enzyme activity in brain but not in liver or muscle|journal=Physiological and Biochemical Zoology|date=2012|volume=86|issue=1|pages=92–105|doi=10.1086/667938|pmid=23303324}}</ref> in part because some fish prioritize their use of aerobic metabolism over anaerobic metabolism and metabolic suppression.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Regan|first1=M.D.|last2=Gill|first2=I.S.|last3=Richards|first3=J.G.|title=Calorespirometry reveals that goldfish prioritize aerobic metabolism over metabolic rate depression in all but near-anoxic environments|journal=Journal of Experimental Biology|date=2017|volume=220|issue=4|pages=564–572|doi=10.1242/jeb.145169|pmid=27913601|url=http://jeb.biologists.org/content/jexbio/220/4/564.full.pdf}}</ref> It therefore remains a widely used hypoxia tolerance metric.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Rogers|first1=N.J.|last2=Urbina|first2=M.A.|last3=Reardon|first3=E.E.|last4=McKenzie|first4=D.J.|last5=Wilson|first5=R.J.|title=A new analysis of hypoxia tolerance in fishes using a database of critical oxygen level (P crit)|journal=Conservation Physiology|date=2016|volume=1|issue=4|doi=10.1093/conphys/cow012|pmid=27293760|pmc=4849809|url=https://academic.oup.com/conphys/article/4/1/cow012/2951333/A-new-analysis-of-hypoxia-tolerance-in-fishes|page=cow012}}</ref>
A fish’s hypoxia tolerance can also be represented as the amount of time it can spend at a particular hypoxic P<sub>O<sub>2</sub></sub> before it loses dorsal-ventral equilibrium (called time-to-LOE), or the P<sub>O<sub>2</sub></sub> at which it loses equilibrium when P<sub>O<sub>2</sub></sub> is decreased from normoxia to anoxia at some set rate (called P<sub>O<sub>2</sub></sub>-of-LOE). A higher time-to-LOE value or a lower P<sub>O<sub>2</sub></sub>-of-LOE value therefore imply enhanced hypoxia tolerances. In either case, LOE is a more holistic representation of overall hypoxia tolerance because it incorporates all contributors to hypoxia tolerance, including aerobic metabolism, anaerobic metabolism and metabolic suppression. [[File:Pcrit.png|thumb|Oxygen consumption rate decreases with decreasing environmental oxygen tension (P<sub>O<sub>2</sub></sub>) when P<sub>O<sub>2</sub></sub>< P<sub>crit</sub>. On the other hand, oxygen consumption rate is unaffected by the changes in oxygen tension when P<sub>O<sub>2</sub></sub> > P<sub>crit</sub>]]
==Oxygen sensing==
===Oxygen sensing structures=== In mammals there are several structures that have been implicated as oxygen sensing structures; however, all of these structures are situated to detect aortic or internal hypoxia since mammals rarely run into environmental hypoxia. These structures include the type I cells of the [[carotid body]],<ref>{{cite journal | last1=Gonzalez | first1=C | last2=Almaraz | first2=L | last3=Obeso | first3=A | last4=Rigual | first4=R | year=1994 | title=Carotid body chemoreceptors: from natural stimuli to sensory discharges | journal=Physiol Rev | volume=74 | pages=829–898 | pmid=7938227 | issue=4| doi=10.1152/physrev.1994.74.4.829 }}</ref> the neuroepithelial bodies of the lungs<ref>{{cite journal | last1=Fu | first1=XW | last2=Nurse | first2=CA | last3=Wong | first3=V | last4=Cutz | first4=E | year=2002 | title=Hypoxia-induced secretion of serotonin from intact pulmonary neuroepithelial bodies in neonatal rabbit | journal=J Physiol | volume=539 | pages=503–510 | pmid=11882682 | issue=Pt 2 | pmc=2290169 | doi=10.1113/jphysiol.2001.013071}}</ref> as well as some [[Central nervous system|central]] and [[Peripheral nervous system|peripheral]] [[neuron]]s and [[vascular smooth muscle]] cells. In fish, the neuroepithelial cells (NEC) have been implicated as the major oxygen sensing cells.<ref>{{cite journal | last1=Jonz | first1=MG | last2=Fearon | first2=IM | last3=Nurse | first3=CA | year=2004 | title=Neuroepithelial oxygen chemoreceptors of the zebrafish gill | journal=J Physiol | volume=560 | pages=737–752 | pmid=15331683 | doi=10.1113/jphysiol.2004.069294 | issue=Pt 3 | pmc=1665292}}</ref> NEC have been found in all teleost fish studied to date, and are likely a highly conserved structure within many [[Taxon|taxa]] of fish. NEC are also found in all four gill arches within several different structures, such as along the filaments, at the ends of the [[Fish anatomy|gill rakers]] and throughout the lamellae. Two separate neural pathways have been identified within the [[zebrafish]] gill arches both the [[Axon|motor and sensory nerve fibre]] pathways.<ref>{{cite journal | last1=Jonz | first1=MG | last2=Nurse | first2=CA | year=2003 | title=Neuroepithelial cells and associated innervation of the zebrafish gill: A confocal immunofluorescence study | journal=J Comp Neurol | volume=461 | pages=1–17 | pmid=12722101 | doi=10.1002/cne.10680 | issue=1}}</ref> Since neuroepithelial cells are distributed throughout the gills, they are often ideally situated to detect both [[Artery|arterial]] as well as environmental oxygen.<ref>{{cite journal | last1=Coolidge | first1=EH | last2=Ciuhandu | first2=CC | last3=Milsom | first3=WK | year=2008 | title=A comparative analysis of putative oxygen sensing cells in the fish gill | journal=J Exp Biol | volume=211 | pages=1231–1242 | pmid=18375847 | doi=10.1242/jeb.015248 | issue=Pt 8}}</ref>
===Mechanisms of neurotransmitter release in neuroepithelial cells=== Neuroepithelial cells (NEC) are thought to be [[neuron]]-like [[chemoreceptor]] cells because they rely on [[membrane potential]] changes for the release of [[neurotransmitters]] and signal transmission onto nearby cells. Once NEC of the [[zebrafish]] [[gills]] come in contact with either environmental or [[aortic]] [[hypoxia (medical)|hypoxia]], an outward K<sup>+</sup> "leak" channel is inhibited. It remains unclear how these K<sup>+</sup> channels are inhibited by a shortage of oxygen because there are yet to be any known direct binding sites for "a lack of oxygen", only whole cell and ion channel responses to hypoxia. K<sup>+</sup> "leak" channels are two-pore-domain [[ion channels]] that are open at the resting [[membrane potential]] of the cell and play a major role in setting the equilibrium resting membrane potential of the cell.<ref>{{cite journal | last1=Lesage | first1=F | last2=Lazdunski | first2=M | year=2000 | title=Molecular and functional properties of two-pore-domain potassium channels | journal=Am J Physiol | volume=279 | pages=F793–F801 | pmid=11053038 | issue=5| doi=10.1152/ajprenal.2000.279.5.F793 }}</ref> Once this "leak" channel is closed, the K<sup>+</sup> is no longer able to freely flow out of the cell, and the membrane potential of the NEC increases; the cell becomes depolarized. This [[depolarization]] causes voltage-gated Ca<sup>2+</sup> channels to open, and for [[extracellular]] Ca<sup>2+</sup> to flow down its concentration gradient into the cell causing the intracellular Ca<sup>2+</sup> concentration to greatly increase. Once the Ca<sup>2+</sup> is inside the cell, it binds to the [[Synaptic vesicle|vesicle]] release machinery and facilitates binding of the [[SNARE|t-snare]] complex on the vesicle to the [[SNARE|s-snare]] complex on the NEC cell membrane which initiates the release of [[neurotransmitters]] into the [[Chemical synapse|synaptic cleft]].
===Signal transduction up to higher brain centres=== If the post-synaptic cell is a sensory neuron, then an increased firing rate in that neuron will transmit the signal to the central nervous system for integration. Whereas, if the post-synaptic cell is a connective pillar cell or a [[vascular smooth muscle]] cell, then the [[serotonin]] will cause [[vasoconstriction]] and previously unused lamellae will be recruited through recruitment of more [[capillary]] beds, and the total surface area for gas exchange per lamella will be increased.<ref>{{cite journal | last1=Farrell | first1=AP | last2=Daxboeck | first2=C | last3=Randall | first3=DJ | year=1979 | title=The effect of input pressure and flow on the pattern and resistance to flow in the isolated perfused gill of a teleost fish | journal=J Comp Physiol | volume=133 | pages=233–240 | doi=10.1007/BF00691471 | issue=3}}</ref>
In fish, the hypoxic signal is carried up to the brain for processing by the [[Glossopharyngeal nerve|glossopharyngeal]] (cranial nerve IX) and [[Vagus nerve|vagus]] (cranial nerve X) nerves. The first [[Pharyngeal arch|branchial arch]] is [[innervated]] by the glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX); however all four arches are innervated by the vagus nerve (cranial nerve X). Both the glossopharyngeal and vagus nerves carry sensory nerve fibres into the brain and central nervous system.
===Locations of oxygen sensors=== Through studies using mammalian model organisms, there are two main [[Hypothesis|hypotheses]] for the location of oxygen sensing in chemoreceptor cells: the [[Cell membrane|membrane]] hypothesis and the [[Mitochondrion|mitochondrial]] hypothesis. The membrane hypothesis was proposed for the [[carotid body]] in mice,<ref>{{cite journal | last1=Lopez-Barneo | first1=J | last2=Lopez-Lopez | first2=JR | last3=Urena | first3=J | last4=Gonzalez | first4=C | year=1988 | title=Chemotransduction in the carotid body: K+ current modulated by PO2 in type I chemoreceptor cells | journal=Science | volume=241 | pages=580–582 | pmid=2456613 | doi=10.1126/science.2456613 | issue=4865}}</ref> and it predicts that oxygen sensing is an ion balance initiated process. The mitochondrial hypothesis was also proposed for the carotid body of mice, but it relies on the levels of [[oxidative phosphorylation]] and/or [[reactive oxygen species]] (ROS) production as a cue for hypoxia. Specifically, the oxygen sensitive K<sup>+</sup> currents are inhibited by [[Hydrogen peroxide|H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub>]] and [[NADPH oxidase]] activation.<ref>{{cite journal | last1=Fu | first1=XW | last2=Wang | first2=D | last3=Nurse | first3=CA | last4=Dinauer | first4=MC | last5=Cutz | first5=E | year=2000 | title=NADPH oxidase is an O2 sensor in airway chemoreceptors: Evidence from K+ current modulation in wild-type and oxidase-deficient mice | journal=Proc Natl Acad Sci USA | volume=97 | pages=4374–4379 | pmid=10760304 | issue=8 | pmc=18249 | doi=10.1073/pnas.97.8.4374}}</ref> There is evidence for both of these hypotheses depending on the species used for the study. For the neuroepithelial cells in the zebrafish gills, there is strong evidence supporting the "membrane hypothesis" due to their capacity to respond to hypoxia after removal of the contents of the cell. However, there is no evidence against multiple sites for oxygen sensing in organisms.
==Acute responses to hypoxia== Many hypoxic environments never reach the level of [[Anoxic waters|anoxia]] and most fish are able to cope with this stress using different [[Physiology|physiological]] and behavioural strategies. Fish that use air breathing organs (ABO) tend to live in environments with highly variable oxygen content and rely on aerial respiration during times when there is not enough oxygen to support water-breathing.<ref>{{citation | pmid =21056112 | doi=10.1016/j.cbpa.2010.10.029 | title=Hypoxia tolerance and partitioning of bimodal respiration in the striped catfish (Pangasianodon hypophthalmus) | journal=Comparative Biochemistry and Physiology A | date=2011 | volume=158 | issue=2 | pages=207–214 | first=Sjannie | last=Lefevre}}</ref> Though all [[teleosts]] have some form of [[swim bladder]], many of them are not capable of breathing air, and they rely on aquatic surface respiration as a supply of more oxygenated water at the surface of the water. However, many species of teleost fish are obligate water breathers and do not display either of these surface respiratory behaviours.
Typically, acute hypoxia causes [[hyperventilation]], [[bradycardia]] and an elevation in gill [[vascular resistance]] in teleosts.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Holeton | first1 = GF | last2 = Randall | first2 = DJ | year = 1967 | title = Changes in blood pressure in the rainbow trout during hypoxia | url = | journal = J Exp Biol | volume = 46 | issue = 2| pages = 297–305 | pmid = 6033996 }}</ref> However, the benefit of these changes in [[blood pressure]] to oxygen uptake has not been supported in a recent study of the [[rainbow trout]].<ref>{{citation | pmid =16574450 | doi=10.1016/j.cbpa.2006.02.026 | title=Does bradycardia or hypertension enhance gas transfer in rainbow trout (Oncorhynchus mykiss)? | journal=Comparative Biochemistry and Physiology A | date=2006 | volume=144 | issue=2 | pages=163–172 | first=S.F. | last=Perry}}</ref> It is possible that the [[Acute toxicity|acute]] hypoxia response is simply a stress response, and the advantages found in early studies may only result after [[acclimatization]] to the environment.
==Behavioral responses== Hypoxia can modify normal behavior.<ref>Reebs, S.G. (2009) [http://www.howfishbehave.ca/pdf/oxygen.pdf Oxygen and fish behaviour]</ref> Parental behaviour meant to provide oxygen to the eggs is often affected by hypoxia. For example, fanning behavior (swimming on the spot near the eggs to create a flow of water over them, and thus a constant supply of oxygen) is often increased when oxygen is less available. This has been documented in sticklebacks,<ref>Iersel, J.J.A. van. 1953. An analysis of the parental behaviour of the male three-spine stickleback (''Gasterosteus aculeatus'' L.). Behaviour Supplement 3: 1-159.</ref><ref>Sevenster, P. 1961. A causal analysis of a displacement activity (fanning in ''Gasterosteus aculeatus'' L.). Behaviour Supplement 9: 1-170.</ref> gobies,<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Torricelli | first1 = P. | last2 = Lugli | first2 = M. | last3 = Gandolfi | first3 = G. | year = 1985 | title = A quantitative analysis of the fanning activity in the male ''Padogobius martensi'' (Pisces: Gobiidae) | jstor = 4534416 | journal = Behaviour | volume = 92 | issue = 3/4| pages = 288–301 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Takegaki | first1 = T. | last2 = Nakazono | first2 = A. | year = 1999 | title = Responses of the egg-tending gobiid fish ''Valenciennea longipinnis'' to the fluctuation of dissolved oxygen in the burrow | url = | journal = Bulletin of Marine Science | volume = 65 | issue = | pages = 815–823 }}</ref> and clownfishes,<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Green | first1 = B.S. | last2 = McCormick | first2 = M.I. | year = 2005 | title = O2 replenishment to fish nests: males adjust brood care to ambient conditions and brood development | url = | journal = Behavioral Ecology | volume = 16 | issue = 2| pages = 389–397 | doi=10.1093/beheco/ari007}}</ref> among others. Gobies may also increase the size of the openings in the nest they build, even though this may increase the risk of predation on the eggs.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Jones | first1 = J.C. | last2 = Reynolds | first2 = J.D. | year = 1999 | title = Oxygen and the trade-off between egg ventilation and brood protection in the common goby | url = | journal = Behaviour | volume = 136 | issue = 7| pages = 819–832 | doi=10.1163/156853999501586}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Jones | first1 = J.C. | last2 = Reynolds | first2 = J.D. | year = 1999 | title = The influence of oxygen stress on female choice for male nest structure in the common goby | url = | journal = Animal Behaviour | volume = 57 | issue = 1| pages = 189–196 | doi=10.1006/anbe.1998.0940| pmid = 10053086 }}</ref> [[Rainbow cichlid]]s often move their young fry closer to the water surface, where oxygen is more available, during hypoxic episodes.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Courtenay | first1 = S.C. | last2 = Keenleyside | first2 = M.H.A. | year = 1983 | title = Wriggler-hanging: a response to hypoxia by brood-rearing ''Herotilapia multispinosa'' (Teleostei, Cichlidae) | url = | journal = Behaviour | volume = 85 | issue = 3| pages = 183–197 | doi=10.1163/156853983x00219}}</ref>
Behavioural adaptations meant to survive when oxygen is scarce include reduced activity levels, aquatic surface respiration, and air breathing.
===Reduced activity levels===
As oxygen levels decrease, fish may at first increase movements in an attempt to escape the hypoxic zone, but eventually they greatly reduce their activity levels, thus reducing their energetic (and therefore oxygen) demands. [[Atlantic herring]] show this exact pattern.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Domenici | first1 = P. | last2 = Steffensen | first2 = J.F. | last3 = Batty | first3 = R.S. | year = 2000 | title = The effect of progressive hypoxia on swimming activity and schooling in Atlantic herring | url = | journal = Journal of Fish Biology | volume = 57 | issue = 6| pages = 1526–1538 | doi=10.1006/jfbi.2000.1413| citeseerx = 10.1.1.1.2926 }}</ref> Other examples of fishes that reduce their activity levels under hypoxia include the [[common sole]],<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Dalla Via | first1 = D. | last2 = Van | last3 = den Thillart | first3 = G. | last4 = Cattani | first4 = O. | last5 = Cortesi | first5 = P. | year = 1998 | title = Behavioural responses and biochemical correlates in ''Solea solea'' to gradual hypoxic exposure | url = | journal = Canadian Journal of Zoology | volume = 76 | issue = 11| pages = 2108–2113 | doi=10.1139/z98-141}}</ref> the [[guppy]],<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Kramer | first1 = D.L. | last2 = Mehegan | first2 = J.P. | year = 1981 | title = Aquatic surface respiration, an adaptive response to hypoxia in the guppy, ''Poecilia reticulata'' (Pisces, Poeciliidae) | url = | journal = Environmental Biology of Fishes | volume = 6 | issue = 3–4| pages = 299–313 | doi=10.1007/bf00005759}}</ref> the [[small-spotted catshark]],<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Metcalfe | first1 = J.D. | last2 = Butler | first2 = P.J. | year = 1984 | title = Changes in activity and ventilation in response to hypoxia in unrestrained, unoperated dogfish (''Scyliorhinus canicula'' L.) | url = | journal = Journal of Experimental Biology | volume = 180 | issue = | pages = 153–162 }}</ref> and the [[viviparous eelpout]].<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Fisher | first1 = P. | last2 = Rademacher | first2 = K. | last3 = Kils | first3 = U. | year = 1992 | title = ''In situ'' investigations on the respiration and behaviour of the eelpout ''Zoarces viviparus'' under short-terms hypoxia | doi = 10.3354/meps088181 | journal = Marine Ecology Progress Series | volume = 88 | issue = | pages = 181–184 }}</ref> Some sharks that ram-ventilate their gills may understandably increase their swimming speeds under hypoxia, to bring more water to the gills.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Carlson | first1 = J.K. | last2 = Parsons | first2 = G.R. | year = 2001 | title = The effects of hypoxia on three sympatric shark species: physiological and behavioral responses | doi = 10.1023/a:1011641302048 | journal = Environmental Biology of Fishes | volume = 61 | issue = 4| pages = 427–433 }}</ref>
===Aquatic surface respiration=== In response to decreasing [[oxygenation (environmental)|dissolved oxygen]] level in the environment, fish swim up to the surface of the water column and ventilate at the top layer of the water where it contains relatively higher level of dissolved oxygen, a behavior called aquatic surface respiration (ASR).<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Kramer | first1 = D.L. | year = 1987 | title = Dissolved oxygen and fish behavior | url = | journal = Environmental Biology of Fishes | volume = 18 | issue = 2| pages = 81–92 | doi=10.1007/bf00002597}}</ref> Oxygen diffuses into water from air and therefore the top layer of water in contact with air contains more oxygen. This is true only in stagnant water; in running water all layers are mixed together and oxygen levels are the same throughout the water column. One environment where ASR often takes place is tidepools, particularly at night.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Congleton | first1 = J.L. | year = 1980 | title = Observations of the responses of some southern California tidepool fishes to nocturnal hypoxic stress | url = | journal = Comparative Biochemistry and Physiology A | volume = 66 | issue = 4| pages = 719–722 | doi=10.1016/0300-9629(80)90026-2}}</ref> Separation from the sea at low tide means that water is not renewed, fish crowding within the pool means that oxygen is quickly depleted, and absence of light at night means that there is no photosynthesis to replenish the oxygen. Examples of tidepool species that perform ASR include the tidepool [[sculpin]], ''Oligocottus maculosus'',<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Sloman | first1 = K.A. | last2 = Mandic | first2 = M.M. | last3 = Todgham | first3 = A.E. | display-authors = etal | year = 2008 | title = The response of the tidepool sculpin, ''Oligocottus maculosus'', to hypoxia in laboratory, mecocosm and field environments | url = | journal = Comparative Biochemistry and Physiology A | volume = 149 | issue = 3| pages = 284–292 | doi=10.1016/j.cbpa.2008.01.004| pmid = 18276177 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Mandic | first1 = M | last2 = Sloman | first2 = KA Richards JG | year = 2009 | title = Escaping to the surface: a phylogenetically independent analysis of hypoxia-induced respiratory behaviors in sculpins | url = | journal = Physiol Biochem Zool | volume = 82 | issue = 6| pages = 703–738 | pmid = 19799503 | doi=10.1086/605932}}</ref> the [[three-spined stickleback]],<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Reebs | first1 = S.G. | last2 = Whoriskey | first2 = F.G. | last3 = FitzGerald | first3 = G.J. | year = 1984 | title = Diel patterns of fanning activity, egg respiration, and the nocturnal behavior of male three spined sticklebacks, ''Gasterosteus aculeatus'' L. (f. ''trachurus'') | url = | journal = Canadian Journal of Zoology | volume = 62 | issue = 329| page = 334 | doi = 10.1139/z84-051 }}</ref> and the [[mummichog]].<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Wannamaker | first1 = C.M. | last2 = Rice | first2 = J.A. | year = 2000 | title = Effects of hypoxia on movements and behavior of selected estuarine organisms from the southeastern United States | url = | journal = Journal of Experimental Marine Biology and Ecology | volume = 249 | issue = 2| pages = 145–163 | doi=10.1016/s0022-0981(00)00160-x| pmid = 10841932 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Stierhoff | first1 = K.L. | last2 = Targett | first2 = T.E. | last3 = Grecay | first3 = P.A. | year = 2003 | title = Hypoxia tolerance of the mummichog: the role of access to the water surface | url = | journal = Journal of Fish Biology | volume = 63 | issue = 3| pages = 580–592 | doi=10.1046/j.1095-8649.2003.00172.x}}</ref>
But ASR is not limited to the intertidal environment. Most tropical and temperate fish species living in stagnant waters engage in ASR during hypoxia.<ref>{{citation | doi= 10.1007/BF00011822 | title=Aquatic surface respiration, a widespread adaptation to hypoxia in tropical freshwater fishes | journal=Environmental Biology of Fishes | date=1982 | volume=7 | issue=1 | pages=47–55 | first=Donald L. | last=Kramer}}</ref> One study looked at 26 species representing eight families of non-air breathing fishes from the North American great plains, and found that all but four of them performed ASR during hypoxia.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Gee | first1 = J.H. | last2 = Tallman | first2 = R.F. | last3 = Smart | first3 = H.J. | year = 1978 | title = Reactions of some great plains fishes to progressive hypoxia | url = | journal = Canadian Journal of Zoology | volume = 56 | issue = 9| pages = 1962–1966 | doi=10.1139/z78-263}}</ref> Another study looked at 24 species of tropical fish common to the pet trade, from tetras to barbs to cichlids, and found that all of them performed ASR.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Kramer | first1 = D.L. | last2 = McClure | first2 = M. | year = 1982 | title = Aquatic surface respiration, a widespread adaptation to hypoxia in tropical freshwater fishes | url = | journal = Environmental Biology of Fishes | volume = 7 | issue = | pages = 47–55 | doi=10.1007/bf00011822}}</ref> An unusual situation in which ASR is performed is during winter, in lakes covered by ice, at the interface between water and ice or near air bubbles trapped underneath the ice.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Klinger | first1 = S.A. | last2 = Magnuson | first2 = J.J. | last3 = Gallepp | first3 = G.W. | year = 1982 | title = Survival mechanisms of the central mudminnow (''Umbra limi''), fathead minnow (''Pimephales promelas'') and brook stickleback (''Culaea inconstans'') for low oxygen in winter | url = | journal = Environmental Biology of Fishes | volume = 7 | issue = 2| pages = 113–120 | doi=10.1007/bf00001781}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Magnuson | first1 = J.J. | last2 = Beckel | first2 = A.L. | last3 = Mills | first3 = K. | last4 = Brandt | first4 = S.B. | year = 1985 | title = Surviving winter hypoxia: behavioral adaptations of fishes in a northern Wisconsin winterkill lake | url = | journal = Environmental Biology of Fishes | volume = 14 | issue = 4| pages = 241–250 | doi=10.1007/bf00002627}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Petrosky | first1 = B.R. | last2 = Magnuson | first2 = J.J. | year = 1973 | title = Behavioral responses of Northern pike, yellow perch and bluegill to oxygen concentrations under simulated winterkill conditions | url = | journal = Copeia | volume = 1973 | issue = 1| pages = 124–133 | doi=10.2307/1442367| jstor = 1442367 }}</ref>
Some species may show morphological adaptations, such as a flat head and an upturned mouth, that allow them to perform ASR without breaking the water surface (which would make them more visible to aerial predators).<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Lewis | first1 = W.M. Jr | year = 1970 | title = Morphological adaptations of cyprinodontoids for inhabiting oxygen deficient waters | url = | journal = Copeia | volume = 1970 | issue = 2| pages = 319–326 | doi=10.2307/1441653| jstor = 1441653 }}</ref> One example is the [[mummichog]], whose upturned mouth suggests surface feeding, but whose feeding habits are not particularly restricted to the surface. In the [[tambaqui]], a South American species, exposure to hypoxia induces within hours the development of additional blood vessels inside the lower lip, enhancing its ability to take up oxygen during ASR.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Sundin | first1 = L. | last2 = Reid | first2 = S.G. | last3 = Rantin | first3 = F.T. | last4 = Milson | first4 = W.K. | year = 2000 | title = Branchial receptors and cardiorespiratory reflexes in a neotropical fish, the tambaqui (''Colossoma macropomum'') | url = | journal = Journal of Experimental Biology | volume = 203 | issue = | pages = 1225–1239 }}</ref> Swimming upside down may also help fishes perform ASR, as in some [[upside-down catfish]].<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Chapman | first1 = L.J. | last2 = Kaufman | first2 = L. | last3 = Chapman | first3 = C.A. | year = 1994 | title = Why swim upside down? A comparative study of two mochokid catfishes | url = | journal = Copeia | volume = 1994 | issue = 1| pages = 130–135 | doi=10.2307/1446679| jstor = 1446679 }}</ref>
Some species may hold an air bubble within the mouth during ASR. This may assist buoyancy as well as increase the oxygen content of the water passing over the bubble on its way to the gills.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Gee | first1 = J.H. | last2 = Gee | first2 = P.A. | year = 1991 | title = Reaction of gobioid fishes to hypoxia: buoyancy control and aquatic surface respiration | url = | journal = Copeia | volume = 1991 | issue = 1| pages = 17–28 | doi=10.2307/1446244| jstor = 1446244 }}</ref> Another way to reduce buoyancy costs is to perform ASR on rocks or plants that provide support near the water surface.
ASR significantly affects survival of fish during severe hypoxia.<ref>{{citation | pmid= 21316378 | doi=10.1016/j.physbeh.2011.02.009 | title=Leap of faith: Voluntary emersion behaviour and physiological adaptations to aerial exposure in a non-aestivating freshwater fish in response to aquatic hypoxia | journal=Physiology | date=2011 | volume=103 | issue=2 | pages=240–247 | first=Mauricio A. | last=Urbina}}</ref> In the [[Poecilia|shortfin molly]] for example, survival was approximately four times higher in individuals able to perform ASR as compared to fish not allowed to perform ASR during their exposure to extreme hypoxia.<ref>Plath M, Tobler M, Riesch R, García de León FJ, Giere O, Schlupp I. 2007. Survival in an extreme habitat: the roles of behaviour and energy limitation. ''Die Naturwissenschaften'' 94: 991-6. PMID</ref>
ASR may be performed more often when the need for oxygen is higher. In the [[sailfin molly]], gestating females (this species is a livebearer) spend about 50% of their time in ASR as compared to only 15% in non-gestating females under the same low levels of oxygen.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Timmerman | first1 = C.M. | last2 = Chapman | first2 = L.J. | year = 2003 | title = The effect of gestational state on oxygen consumption and response to hypoxia in the sailfin molly, ''Poecilia latipinna'' | doi =10.1023/a:1027300701599 | journal = Environmental Biology of Fishes | volume = 68 | issue = 3| pages = 293–299 }}</ref>
===Aerial respiration (air breathing)=== Aerial respiration is the ‘gulping’ of air at the surface of water to directly extract oxygen from the atmosphere. Aerial respiration evolved in fish that were exposed to more frequent hypoxia; also, species that engage in aerial respiration tend to be more hypoxia tolerant than those which do not air-breath during the hypoxia.<ref name = "Richards 2011">{{cite journal | last=Richards | first=JG | year=2011 | title=Physiological, behavioral and biochemical adaptations of intertidal fishes to hypoxia | journal=J Exp Biol | volume=214 | pages=191–199 | pmid=21177940 | doi=10.1242/jeb.047951 | issue=Pt 2}}</ref>
There are two main types of air breathing fish—facultative and non-facultative. Under normoxic conditions facultative fish can survive without having to breathe air from the surface of the water. However, non-facultative fish must respire at the surface even in normal dissolved oxygen levels because their [[gill]]s cannot extract enough oxygen from the water.
Many air breathing freshwater teleosts use ABOs to effectively extract oxygen from air while maintaining functions of the gills. ABOs are modified [[gastrointestinal tracts]], [[gas bladder]]s, and [[labyrinth organ]]s;<ref name ="Sloman">{{cite journal | last1 = Sloman | first1 = KA | last2 = Sloman | first2 = RD | last3 = De Boeck | first3 = G | last4 = Scott | first4 = GR | last5 = Iftikar | first5 = FI | last6 = Wood | first6 = CM | last7 = Almeida-Val | first7 = VMF | year = 2009 | title = The role of size in synchronous air breathing of Hoplosternum littorale | url = | journal = Physiol Biochem Zool | volume = 82 | issue = 6| pages = 625–34 | doi = 10.1086/605936 | pmid = 19799504 }}</ref> they are highly vascularized and provide additional method of extracting oxygen from the air.<ref name="Richards2">{{Cite book | doi=10.1016/S1546-5098(08)00002-2|chapter = Chapter 2 Behavioral Responses and Ecological Consequences|title = Hypoxia| volume=27| pages=25–77|series = Fish Physiology|year = 2009|last1 = Chapman|first1 = Lauren J.| last2=McKenzie| first2=David J.| isbn=9780123746320}}</ref> Fish also use ABO for storing the retained oxygen.
====Predation risk associated with ASR and aerial respiration==== Both ASR and aerial respiration require fish to travel to the top of water column and this behaviour increases the predation risks by aerial predators or other [[piscivores]] inhabiting near the surface of the water.<ref name ="Richards2"/> In order to cope with the increased predation risk upon surfacing, some fish perform ASR or aerial respiration in schools<ref name ="Sloman"/><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Domenici | first1 = P | last2 = Lefrançois | first2 = C | last3 = Shingles | first3 = A | year = 2007 | title = Hypoxia and the antipredator behaviours of fishes | url = | journal = Philos Trans R Soc Lond B | volume = 362 | issue = 1487| pages = 2105–2121 | doi = 10.1098/rstb.2007.2103 | pmid = 17472921 | pmc=2442856}}</ref> in order to ‘dilute’ the predation risk. When fish can visually detect the presence of their aerial predators, they simply refrain from surfacing, or prefer to surface in areas where they can be detected less easily (i.e. turbid, shaded areas).<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Shingles | first1 = A. | last2 = McKenzie | first2 = D.J. | last3 = Claireaux | first3 = G. | last4 = Domenici | first4 = P. | year = 2005 | title = Reflex cardioventilatory responses to hypoxia in the flathead grey mulet (''Mugil cephalus'') and their behavioural modulation by perceived threat of predation and water turbidity | url = http://orbit.dtu.dk/en/publications/reflex-cardioventilatory-responses-to-hypoxia-in-the-flathead-grey-mullet--mugil-cephalus--and-their-behavioural-modulation-by-perceived-threat-of-predation-and-water-turbidity(84d79d52-42af-45f7-bff7-360e5b460626).html| journal = Physiological and Biochemical Zoology | volume = 78 | issue = 5| pages = 744–755 | doi=10.1086/432143| pmid = 16052452 }}</ref>
==Gill remodelling in hypoxia== Gill remodelling happens in only a few species of fish, and it involves the buildup or removal of an inter-lamellar cell mass (ILCM). As a response to hypoxia, some fish are able to remodel their gills to increase [[Respiratory system|respiratory]] surface area, with some species such as goldfish doubling their lamellar surface areas in as little as 8 hours.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Regan|first1=M.D.|last2=Richards|first2=J.G.|title=Rates of hypoxia induction alter mechanisms of O2 uptake and the critical O2 tension of goldfish|journal=Journal of Experimental Biology|date=2017|volume=220|issue=14|doi=10.1242/jeb.154948|pmid=28476894|url=http://jeb.biologists.org/content/220/14/2536|pages=2536–2544}}</ref> The increased respiratory surface area comes as a trade-off with increased metabolic costs because the [[gills]] are a very important site for many important processes including respiratory [[gas exchange]], [[Acid base homeostasis|acid-base regulation]], [[Excretion|nitrogen excretion]], [[osmoregulation]], [[hormone|hormone regulation]], [[metabolism]], and environmental sensing.<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 15618479 | doi=10.1152/physrev.00050.2003 | volume=85 | issue=1 | title=The multifunctional fish gill: dominant site of gas exchange, osmoregulation, acid-base regulation, and excretion of nitrogenous waste | date=January 2005 | pages=97–177 | journal=Physiological Reviews | last1 = Evans | first1 = DH | last2 = Piermarini | first2 = PM | last3 = Choe | first3 = KP}}</ref>
The [[crucian carp]] is one species able to remodel its gill filaments in response to hypoxia. Their inter-lamellar cells have high rates of [[Mitosis|mitotic]] activity which are influenced by both hypoxia and temperature.<ref name ="Sollid">{{cite journal | pmid = 12966058 | volume=206 | issue=Pt 20 | title=Hypoxia induces adaptive and reversible gross morphological changes in crucian carp gills | date=October 2003 | pages=3667–73 | journal=J Exp Biol | doi=10.1242/jeb.00594 | last1 = Sollid | first1 = J | last2 = De Angelis | first2 = P | last3 = Gundersen | first3 = K | last4 = Nilsson | first4 = GE}}</ref> In cold (15 °C) water the crucian carp has more ILCM, but when the temperature is increased to 25 °C the ILCM is removed, just as it would be in hypoxic conditions. This same transition in [[gill]] [[Morphology (biology)|morphology]] occurs in the [[goldfish]] when the temperature was raised from 7.5 °C to 15 °C.<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 15767311 | doi=10.1242/jeb.01505 | volume=208 | issue=Pt 6 | title=Temperature alters the respiratory surface area of crucian carp Carassius carassius and goldfish Carassius auratus | date=March 2005 | pages=1109–16 | journal=Journal of Experimental Biology | last1 = Sollid | first1 = J | last2 = Weber | first2 = RE | last3 = Nilsson | first3 = GE}}</ref> This difference may be due to the temperature regimes that these fish are typically found in, or there could be an underlying protective mechanism to prevent a loss of ion balance in stressful temperatures. Temperature also affects the speed at which the gills can be remodelled: for example, at 20 °C in hypoxia, the crucian carp can completely remove its ILCM in 6 hours, whereas at 8 °C, the same process takes 3–7 days.<ref name ="Sollid"/> The ILCM is likely removed by [[apoptosis]], but it is possible that when the fish is faced with the double stress of hypoxia at high temperature, the lamellae may be lost by physical degradation. Covering the gill lamellae may protect species like the crucian carp from [[Parasitism|parasites]] and environmental toxins during normoxia by limiting their surface area for inward [[diffusion]] while still maintaining oxygen transport due to an extremely high [[hemoglobin]] oxygen binding [[Affinity (pharmacology)|affinity]].<ref name ="Sollid" />
The [[naked carp]], a closely related species native to the high-altitude [[Lake Qinghai]], is also able to remodel their gills in response to hypoxic conditions. In response to oxygen levels 95% lower than normoxic conditions, apoptosis of ILCM increases lamellar surface area by up to 60% after just 24 hours.<ref name="matey">{{cite journal|last=Matey|first=V.|author2=Richards, J. G. |author3=Wang, Y. |author4=Wood, C. M. |author5=Rogers, J. |author6=Davies, R. |author7=Murray, B. W. |author8=Chen, X.-Q. |author9=Du, J. |author10= Brauner, C. J. |title=The effect of hypoxia on gill morphology and ionoregulatory status in the Lake Qinghai scaleless carp, Gymnocypris przewalskii|journal=Journal of Experimental Biology|date=1 April 2008|volume=211|issue=7|pages=1063–1074|doi=10.1242/jeb.010181|pmid=18344480}}</ref> However, this comes at a significant osmoregulatory cost, reducing [[sodium]] and [[chloride]] levels in the [[cytoplasm]] by over 10%.<ref name="matey" /> The morphological response to hypoxia by scaleless carp is the fastest respiratory surface remodelling reported in vertebrates thus far.<ref name=cao>{{cite journal|last=Cao|first=Yi-Bin|author2=Chen, Xue-Qun |author3=Wang, Shen |author4=Wang, Yu-Xiang |author5= Du, Ji-Zeng |title=Evolution and Regulation of the Downstream Gene of Hypoxia-Inducible Factor-1α in Naked Carp (Gymnocypris przewalskii) from Lake Qinghai, China|journal=Journal of Molecular Evolution|date=22 October 2008|volume=67|issue=5|pages=570–580|doi=10.1007/s00239-008-9175-4|pmid=18941827}}</ref>
==Oxygen uptake== Fish exhibit a wide range of tactics to counteract aquatic hypoxia, but when escape from the hypoxic stress is not possible, maintaining oxygen extraction and delivery becomes an essential component to survival.<ref>{{citation | pmid =12161331 | doi=10.1016/S1569-9048(02)00113-1 | title=Physiological responses to prolonged aquatic hypoxia in the Queensland lungfish Neoceratodus forsteri | journal=Respiratory Physiology | date=2002 | volume=132 | issue=2 | pages=179–190 | first=Peter K | last=Kind}}</ref> Except for the [[Notothenioidei|Antarctic ice fish]] that does not, most fish use [[hemoglobin]] (Hb) within their red blood cells to bind chemically and deliver 95% of the oxygen extracted from the environment to the working tissues. Maintaining oxygen extraction and delivery to the tissues allows continued activity under hypoxic stress and is in part determined by modifications in two different blood parameters: [[hematocrit]] and the binding properties of hemoglobin.
===Hematocrit===
In general, hematocrit is the number of red blood cells (RBC) in circulation and is highly variable among fish species. Active fish, like the [[Marlin|blue marlin]], tend to have higher hematocrits,<ref name= "Perry">Perry, SF, Esbaugh, A, Braun, M, and Gilmour, KM. 2009. Gas Transport and Gill Function in Water Breathing Fish. In Cardio-Respiratory Control in Vertebrates, (ed. Glass ML, Wood SC), pp. 5-35. Berlin: Springer-Verlag.</ref> whereas less active fish, such as the [[starry flounder]] exhibit lower hematocrits.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Wood | first1 = CM | last2 = Mcdonald | first2 = DG | last3 = Mcmahon | first3 = BR | year = 1982 | title = The influence of experimental anemia on blood acid-base regulation in vivo and in vitro in the starry flounder (Platichthys stellatus) and rainbow trout (Salmo gairdneri) | url = | journal = J Exp Biol | volume = 96 | issue = | pages = 221–237 }}</ref> Hematocrit may be increased in response to both short-term (acute) or long-term (chronic) hypoxia exposure and results in an increase in the total amount of oxygen the blood can carry, also known as the oxygen carrying capacity of the blood.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Yamamoto | first1 = K. | last2 = Itazawa | first2 = Y. | last3 = Kobayashi | first3 = H. | year = 1985 | title = Direct observations of fish spleen by an abdominal window method and its application to exercised and hypoxic yellowtail | url = | journal = Jpn J Ichthyol | volume = 31 | issue = | pages = 427–433 }}</ref> Acute changes in hematocrit are the result of circulating stress hormones (see - [[catecholamines]]) activating receptors on the spleen that cause the release of RBCs into circulation.<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 16809464 | doi=10.1242/jeb.02279 | volume=209 | issue=Pt 14 | title=Effects of moderate and substantial hypoxia on erythropoietin levels in rainbow trout kidney and spleen | date=July 2006 | pages=2734–8 | journal=Journal of Experimental Biology | last1 = Lai | first1 = JC | last2 = Kakuta | first2 = I | last3 = Mok | first3 = HO | last4 = Rummer | first4 = JL | last5 = Randall | first5 = D}}</ref> During chronic hypoxia exposure, the mechanism used to increase hematocrit is independent of the spleen and results from hormonal stimulation of the kidney by [[erythropoietin|erythropoetin (EPO)]]. Increasing hematocrit in response to erythropoietin is observed after approximately one week and is therefore likely under genetic control of hypoxia inducible factor [[hypoxia-inducible factors|hypoxia inducible factor (HIF)]].<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Semenza | first1 = GL | year = 2004 | title = O2-regulated gene expression: transcriptional control of cardiorespiratory physiology by HIF-1 | url = | journal = J Appl Physiol | volume = 96 | issue = 3| pages = 1173–1177 | pmid = 14766767 | doi=10.1152/japplphysiol.00770.2003}}</ref> While increasing hematocrit means that the blood can carry a larger total amount of oxygen, a possible advantage during hypoxia, increasing the number of RBCs in the blood can also lead to certain disadvantages. First, A higher hematocrit results in more [[viscosity|viscous]] blood (especially in cold water) increasing the amount of energy the cardiac system requires to pump the blood through the system and secondly depending on the transit time of the blood across the [[branchial arch]] and the diffusion rate of oxygen, an increased hematocrit may result in less efficient transfer of oxygen from the environment to the blood.<ref name ="Perry"/>
===Changing the binding affinity of hemoglobin===
An alternative mechanism to preserve O<sub>2</sub> delivery in the face of low ambient oxygen is to increase the affinity of the blood. The oxygen content of the blood is related to [[Blood gas tension|PaO<sub>2</sub>]] and is illustrated using an oxygen equilibrium curve (OEC). Fish hemoglobins, with the exception of the [[agnatha]]ns, are tetramers that exhibit [[cooperativity]] of O<sub>2</sub> binding and have sigmoidal OECs.
[[File:Oxygen Equilibrium Curve.jpg|thumb|Oxygen equilibrium curve (OEC) demonstrating the PO<sub>2</sub> required for half of the hemoglobin oxygen binding sites to be saturated with oxygen (P50)]]
The binding affinity of hemoglobin to oxygen is estimated using a measurement called P50 (the partial pressure of oxygen at which hemoglobin is 50% bound with oxygen) and can be extremely variable.<ref>{{cite journal| doi =10.1093/icb/20.1.139 | title=Molecular Ecology of Teleost Fish Hemoglobins Strategies for Adapting to Changing Environments | journal=Integrative and Comparative Biology | date=1980 | volume=20 | issue=1 | pages=139–162 | first=Dennis A | last=Powers}}</ref> If the hemoglobin has a weak affinity for oxygen, it is said to have a high P50 and therefore constrains the environment in which a fish can inhabit to those with relatively high environmental PO<sub>2</sub>. Conversely, fish hemoglobins with a low P50 bind strongly to oxygen and are then of obvious advantage when attempting to extract oxygen from hypoxic or variable PO<sub>2</sub> environments. The use of high affinity (low P50) hemoglobins results in reduced ventillatory and therefore energetic requirements when facing hypoxic insult.<ref name = "Perry"/> The oxygen binding affinity of hemoglobin (Hb-O<sub>2</sub>) is regulated through a suite of [[allosteric regulation|allosteric modulators]]; the principal modulators used for controlling Hb-O<sub>2</sub> affinity under hypoxic insult are: #Increasing RBC pH #Reducing inorganic phosphate interactions
====pH and inorganic phosphates (Pi)====
In [[rainbow trout]] as well as a variety of other teleosts, increased RBC pH stems from the activation of B-andrenergic [[Na+/H+ exchanger|{{chem|Na|+|/H|+}} exchange protein]] (BNHE) on the RBC membrane via circulating catelcholamines.<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 3040965 | volume=382 | title=Control of cell volume and ion transport by beta-adrenergic catecholamines in erythrocytes of rainbow trout, Salmo gairdneri | pmc=1183016 | date=January 1987 | pages=123–44 | journal=J Physiol | doi=10.1113/jphysiol.1987.sp016359 | last1 = Borgese | first1 = F | last2 = Garcia-Romeu | first2 = F | last3 = Motais | first3 = R}}</ref> This process causes the internal pH of the RBC to increase through the outwards movement of {{chem|H|+}} and inwards movement of {{chem|Na|+}}.<ref>{{citation | doi =10.1007/BF00689729 | title=Adrenergic regulation of haemoglobin oxygen affinity in rainbow trout red cells | journal=Journal of Comparative Physiology B | date=1983 | volume=152 | issue=1 | pages=67–72 | first=Mikko | last=Nikinmaa}}</ref> The net consequence of [[alkalinity|alkalizing]] the RBC is an increase in Hb-O<sub>2</sub> affinity via the [[Bohr effect]]. The net influx of {{chem|Na|+}} ions and the compensatory activation of [[Na+/K+-ATPase|{{chem|Na|+|/K|+}}-ATPase]] to maintain ionic equilibrium within the RBC results in a steady decline in cellular ATP, also serving to increase Hb-O<sub>2</sub> affinity.<ref>{{cite book|author1=Nikinmaa, M|author2=Boutilier, RG|year=1995|contribution=Adrenergic control of red cell pH, organic phosphate concentrations and haemoglobin function in teleost fish|title=Advances in Comparative and Environmental Physiology|volume=21|editor=Heisler, N|pages=107–133|location=Berlin|publisher= Springer-Verlag}}</ref> As a further result of inward {{chem|Na|+}} movement, the [[osmolarity]] of the RBC increases causing [[osmotic]] influx of water and cell swelling. The dilution of the cell contents causes further spatial separation of hemoglobin from the inorganic phosphates and again serves to increase Hb-O<sub>2</sub> affinity.<ref name ="Perry"/>
====Changing Hb- isoforms==== Nearly all animals have more than one kind of Hb present in the RBC. Multiple Hb isoforms (see [[isoforms]]) are particularly common in [[ectotherm]]s, but especially in fish that are required to cope with both fluctutating temperature and oxygen availability. Hbs isolated from the [[European eel]] can be separated into [[anodic]] and [[cathodic]] isoforms. The anodic isoforms have low oxygen affinities (high P50) and marked Bohr effects, while the cathodic lack significant pH effects and are therefore thought to confer hypoxia tolerance.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Tamburrini | first1 = M | last2 = Verde | first2 = C | last3 = Olianas | first3 = A | last4 = Giardina | first4 = B | last5 = Corda | first5 = M | last6 = Sanna | first6 = MT | last7 = Fais | first7 = A | last8 = Deiana | first8 = AM | last9 = Prisco | first9 = G | last10 = Pellegrini | first10 = M | year = 2001 | title = The hemoglobin system of the brown moray Gymnothorax unicolor: Structure/function relationships | url = | journal = Eur J Biochem | volume = 268 | issue = 14| pages = 4104–4111 | pmid = 11454005 | doi=10.1046/j.1432-1327.2001.02333.x}}</ref> Several species of African cichlids raised from early stage development under either hypoxic or normoxic conditions were contrasted in an attempt to compare Hb isoforms. They demonstrated there were Hb isoforms specific to the hypoxia-raised individuals.<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 17626121 | doi=10.1152/ajpregu.00536.2006 | volume=293 | issue=3 | title=Multiple strategies of Lake Victoria cichlids to cope with lifelong hypoxia include hemoglobin switching | date=September 2007 | pages=R1376–83 | journal=American Journal of Physiology. Regulatory, Integrative and Comparative Physiology | last1 = Rutjes | first1 = HA | last2 = Nieveen | first2 = MC | last3 = Weber | first3 = RE | last4 = Witte | first4 = F | last5 = Van | first5 = | last6 = den Thillart | first6 = GE}}</ref>
==Metabolic challenge== To deal with decreased ATP production through the electron transport chain, fish must activate anaerobic means of energy production (see [[anaerobic metabolism]]) while suppressing metabolic demands. The ability to decrease energy demand by metabolic suppression is essential to ensure hypoxic survival due to the limited efficiency of anaerobic ATP production.
===Switch from aerobic to anaerobic metabolism=== Aerobic respiration, in which oxygen is used as the terminal electron acceptor, is crucial to all water-breathing fish. When fish are deprived of oxygen, they require other ways to produce ATP. Thus, a switch from aerobic metabolism to anaerobic metabolism occurs at the onset of hypoxia. [[Glycolysis]] and [[substrate-level phosphorylation]] are used as alternative pathways for ATP production.<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 21818543 | doi=10.1007/s10695-011-9542-8 | volume=38 | issue=3 | title=Effects of dissolved oxygen on glycolytic enzyme specific activities in liver and skeletal muscle of Fundulus heteroclitus | date=June 2012 | pages=615–24 | journal=Fish Physiology and Biochemistry | last1 = Abbaraju | first1 = NV | last2 = Rees | first2 = BB}}</ref> However, these pathways are much less efficient than aerobic metabolism. For example, when using the same substrate, the total yield of ATP in anaerobic metabolism is 15 times lower than in aerobic metabolism. This level of ATP production is not sufficient to maintain a high metabolic rate, therefore, the only survival strategy for fish is to alter their metabolic demands.
===Metabolic suppression=== Metabolic suppression is the regulated and reversible reduction of metabolic rate below [[basal metabolic rate]] (called standard metabolic rate in ectothermic animals).<ref name="Richards" /> This reduces the fish’s rate of [[Adenosine triphosphate|ATP]] use, which prolongs its survival time at severely hypoxic sub-P<sub>crit</sub> P<sub>O<sub>2</sub></sub>s by reducing the rate at which the fish’s finite anaerobic fuel stores ([[glycogen]]) are used. Metabolic suppression also reduces the accumulation rate of deleterious anaerobic end-products ([[lactic acid|lactate]] and protons), which delays their negative impact on the fish.
The mechanisms that fish use to suppress metabolic rate occur at behavioral, physiological and biochemical levels. Behaviorally, metabolic rate can be lowered through reduced locomotion, feeding, courtship, and mating.<ref name="Nilsson et al. (1993)">{{cite journal|last1=Nilsson|first1=GE|last2=Rosen|first2=PR|last3=Johansson|first3=D|title=Anoxic depression of spontaneous locomotor activity in crucian carp quantified by a computerized imaging technique|journal=Journal of Experimental Biology|date=1993|volume=180|pages=153–162|url=http://jeb.biologists.org/content/180/1/153.article-info}}</ref><ref name="Wang et al. (2009)">{{Cite book |doi=10.1016/S1546-5098(08)00008-3 |chapter=Chapter 8 the Effects of Hypoxia on Growth and Digestion |title=Hypoxia |volume=27 |pages=361–396 |series=Fish Physiology |year=2009 |last1=Wang |first1=Tobias |last2=Lefevre |first2=Sjannie |last3=Thanh Huong |first3=Do Thi |last4=Cong |first4=Nguyen van |last5=Bayley |first5=Mark |isbn=9780123746320 }}</ref><ref name="Wu (2009)">{{Cite book |doi=10.1016/S1546-5098(08)00003-4 |chapter=Chapter 3 Effects of Hypoxia on Fish Reproduction and Development |title=Hypoxia |volume=27 |pages=79–141 |series=Fish Physiology |year=2009 |last1=Wu |first1=Rudolf S.S. |isbn=9780123746320 }}</ref> Physiologically, metabolic rate can be lowered through reduced growth, digestion, gonad development, and ventilation efforts.<ref name="Fitzgibbon et al. (2007)">{{cite journal|last1=Fitzgibbon|first1=QP|last2=Seymour|first2=RS|last3=Ellis|first3=D|last4=Buchanan|first4=J|title=The energetic consequence of specific dynamic action in southern bluefin tuna Thunnus maccoyii|journal=Journal of Experimental Biology|date=2007|volume=210|issue=2|pages=290–8|doi=10.1242/jeb.02641|pmid=17210965}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book |doi=10.1016/S1546-5098(08)00008-3|chapter=Chapter 8 the Effects of Hypoxia on Growth and Digestion|title=Hypoxia|volume=27|pages=361–396|series=Fish Physiology|year=2009|last1=Wang|first1=Tobias|last2=Lefevre|first2=Sjannie|last3=Thanh Huong|first3=Do Thi|last4=Cong|first4=Nguyen van|last5=Bayley|first5=Mark|isbn=9780123746320}}</ref> And biochemically, metabolic rate can be further lowered below standard metabolic rate through reduced gluconeogenesis, protein synthesis and degradation rates, and ion pumping across cellular membranes.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Jibb|first1=LA|last2=Richards|first2=JG|title=AMP-activated protein kinase activity during metabolic rate depression in the hypoxic goldfish, Carassius auratus|journal=Journal of Experimental Biology|date=2008|volume=211|issue=Pt 19|pages=3111–22|doi=10.1242/jeb.019117|pmid=18805810}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Lewis|first1=JM|last2=Costa|first2=I|last3=Val|first3=AL|last4=Almeida Val|first4=VM|last5=Gamperl|first5=AK|last6=Driedzic|first6=WR|title=Responses to hypoxia recovery: Repayment of oxygen debt is not associated with compensatory protein synthesis in the Amazonian cichlid, Astronotus ocellatus|journal=Journal of Experimental Biology|date=2007|volume=210|issue=Pt 11|pages=1935–43|doi=10.1242/jeb.005371|pmid=17515419}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Smith|first1=RW|last2=Houlihan|first2=DF|last3=Nilsson|first3=GE|last4=Brechin|first4=JG|title=Tissue-specific changes in protein synthesis rates in vivo during anoxia in the crucian carp|journal=American Journal of Physiology|date=1996|volume=271|issue=4 Pt 2|pages=R897–904|pmid=8897979|doi=10.1152/ajpregu.1996.271.4.r897}}</ref> Reductions in these processes lower ATP use rates, but it remains unclear whether metabolic suppression is induced through an initial reduction in ATP use or ATP supply.
The prevalence of metabolic suppression use among fish species has not been thoroughly explored. This is partly because the metabolic rates of hypoxia-exposed fish, including suppressed metabolic rates, can only be accurately measured using direct [[calorimetry]], and this technique is seldom used for fish.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Regan|first1=MD|last2=Gosline|first2=JM|last3=Richards|first3=JG|title=A simple and affordable calorespirometer for assessing the metabolic rates of fishes|journal=Journal of Experimental Biology|date=2013|volume=216|issue=Pt 24|pages=4507–13|doi=10.1242/jeb.093500|pmid=24072793}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Nelson|first1=JA|title=Oxygen consumption rate v. rate of energy utilization of fishes: a comparison and brief history of the two measurements|journal=Journal of Fish Biology|date=2016|volume=88|issue=1|pages=10–25|doi=10.1111/jfb.12824|pmid=26768970}}</ref> The few studies that have used calorimetry reveal that some fish species employ metabolic suppression in hypoxia/anoxia (e.g., goldfish, tilapia, European eel) while others do not (e.g. rainbow trout, zebrafish).<ref>{{cite journal|last1=van Ginneken|first1=V|last2=Addink|first2=A|last3=van den Thillart|first3=GE|title=Metabolic rate and level of activity determined in tilapia (Oreochromis mossambicus Peters) by direct and indirect calorimetry and videomonitoring|journal=Themochimica Acta|date=1997|volume=291|pages=1–13|doi=10.1016/S0040-6031(96)03106-1}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=van Ginneken|first1=VJ|last2=Onderwater|first2=M|last3=Olivar|first3=OL|last4=van den Thillart|first4=GE|title=Metabolic depression and investigation of glucose/ethanol conversion in the European eel (Anguilla anguilla Linnaeus 1758) during anaerobiosis|journal=Thermochimica Acta|date=2001|volume=373|pages=23–30|doi=10.1016/S0040-6031(01)00463-4}}</ref><ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite journal|last1=Regan|first1=MD|last2=Gill|first2=IS|last3=Richards|first3=JG|title=Calorespirometry reveals that goldfish prioritize aerobic metabolism over metabolic rate depression in all but near-anoxic environments|journal=Journal of Experimental Biology|date=2017|volume=220|issue=4|pages=564–572|doi=10.1242/jeb.145169|pmid=27913601}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Stangl|first1=P|last2=Wegener|first2=G|title=Calorimetric and biochemical studies on the effects of environmental hypoxia and chemicals on freshwater fish|journal=Themochimica Acta|date=1996|volume=271|pages=101–113|doi=10.1016/0040-6031(95)02586-3}}</ref><ref name="Richards" /> The species that employ metabolic suppression are more hypoxia-tolerant than the species that do not, which suggests that metabolic suppression enhances hypoxia tolerance. Consistent with this, differences in hypoxia tolerance among isolated [[threespine stickleback]] populations appear to result from differences in the use of metabolic suppression, with the more tolerant stickleback using metabolic suppression.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Regan|first1=MD|last2=Gill|first2=IS|last3=Richards|first3=JG|title=Metabolic depression and the evolution of hypoxia tolerance in threespine stickleback, Gasterosteus aculeatus|journal=Biology Letters|date=2017|volume=13|issue=11|doi=10.1098/rsbl.2017.0392|pmid=29093174|pmc=5719371|page=20170392}}</ref>
Fish that are capable of hypoxia-induced metabolic suppression reduce their metabolic rates by 30% to 80% relative to standard metabolic rates.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=van Waversveld|first1=J|last2=Addink|first2=ADF|last3=van den Thillart|first3=GE|title=The anaerobic energy metabolism of goldfish determined by simultaneous direct and indirect calorimetry during anoxia and hypoxia|journal=Journal of Comparative Physiology|date=1989|volume=159|issue=3|pages=263–268|doi=10.1007/bf00691503}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=van Ginneken|first1=V|last2=Addink|first2=A|last3=van den Thillart|first3=GE|title=Metabolic rate and level of activity determined in tilapia (Oreochromis mossambicus Peters) by direct and indirect calorimetry and videomonitoring|journal=Thermochimica Acta|date=1997|volume=291|pages=1–13|doi=10.1016/S0040-6031(96)03106-1}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=van Ginneken|first1=VJ|last2=Onderwater|first2=M|last3=Olivar|first3=OL|last4=van den Thillart|first4=GE|title=Metabolic depression and investigation of glucose/ethanol conversion in the European eel (Anguilla anguilla Linnaeus 1758) during anaerobiosis|journal=Thermochimica Acta|date=2001|volume=373|pages=23–30|doi=10.1016/S0040-6031(01)00463-4}}</ref><ref name="ReferenceA"/> Because this is not a complete cessation of metabolic rate, metabolic suppression can only prolong hypoxic survival, not sustain it indefinitely. If the hypoxic exposure lasts sufficiently long, the fish will succumb to a depletion of its glycogen stores and/or the over-accumulation of deleterious anaerobic end-products. Furthermore, the severely limited energetic scope that comes with a metabolically suppressed state means that the fish is unable to complete critical tasks such a predator avoidance and reproduction. Perhaps for these reasons, goldfish prioritize their use of aerobic metabolism in most hypoxic environments, reserving metabolic suppression for the extreme case of anoxia.<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
===Energy conservation=== In addition to a reduction in the rate of protein synthesis, it appears that some species of hypoxia-tolerant fish conserve energy by employing Hochachka’s ion channel arrest hypothesis. This hypothesis makes two predictions: # Hypoxia-tolerant animals naturally have low membrane permeabilities # Membrane permeability decreases even more during hypoxic conditions (ion channel arrest)<ref>{{citation | pmid= 2417316 | doi=10.1126/science.2417316 | title=Defense strategies against hypoxia and hypothermia | journal=Science | date=1986 | volume=231 | issue=4735 | pages=234–241 | first=P. | last=Hochachka}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Buck | first1 = L. T. | last2 = Hochachka | first2 = P. W. | year = 1993 | title = Anoxic suppression of Na+/K+-ATPase and constant membrane potential in hepatocytes: support for channel arrest | url = | journal = Am J Physiol | volume = 265 | issue = 5 Pt 2| pages = R1020–R1025 | pmid = 8238602 | doi=10.1152/ajpregu.1993.265.5.r1020}}</ref> The first prediction holds true. When membrane permeability to Na+ and K+ ions was compared between reptiles and mammals, reptile membranes were discovered to be five times less leaky.<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 3605374 | volume=253 | issue=1 Pt 2 | title=Evolution of mammalian endothermic metabolism: "leaky" membranes as a source of heat | date=July 1987 | pages=R1–7 | journal=Am J Physiol | last1 = Else | first1 = PL | last2 = Hulbert | first2 = AJ| doi=10.1152/ajpregu.1987.253.1.R1 }}</ref> The second prediction has been more difficult to prove experimentally, however, indirect measures have showed a decrease in Na+/K+-ATPase activity in eel and trout [[hepatocytes]] during hypoxic conditions.<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 16228932 | doi=10.1086/432857 | volume=78 | issue=6 | title=Metabolic arrest and its regulation in anoxic eel hepatocytes | year=2005 | pages=926–36 | journal=Physiological and Biochemical Zoology | last1 = Busk | first1 = M | last2 = Boutilier | first2 = RG}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Bogdanova | first1 = A. | last2 = Grenacher | first2 = B. | last3 = Nikinmaa | first3 = M. | last4 = Gassmann | first4 = M. | year = 2005 | title = Hypoxic responses of Na +/K+ ATPase in trout hepatocytes | url = | journal = J. Exp. Biol. | volume = 208 | issue = Pt 10| pages = 1793–1801 | pmid = 15879061 | doi=10.1242/jeb.01572}}</ref> Results seem to be tissue-specific, as crucian carp exposed to hypoxia do not undergo a reduction in Na+/K+ ATPase activity in their brain.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Hylland | first1 = P. | last2 = Milton | first2 = S. | last3 = Pek | first3 = M. | last4 = Nilsson | first4 = G. E. | last5 = Lutz | first5 = P. L. | year = 1997 | title = Brain Na+/K+-ATPase activity in two anoxia tolerant vertebrates: Crucian carp and freshwater turtle | url = | journal = Neurosci Lett| volume = 235| issue = 1–2| pages = 89–92| pmid = 9389603 | doi = 10.1016/s0304-3940(97)00727-1 }}</ref> Although evidence is limited, ion channel arrest enables organisms to maintain ion channel concentration gradients and membrane potentials without consuming large amounts of ATP.
===Enhanced glycogen stores=== The limiting factor for fish undergoing hypoxia is the availability of fermentable substrate for anaerobic metabolism; once substrate runs out, ATP production ceases. Endogenous [[glycogen]] is present in tissue as a long term energy storage molecule. It can be converted into glucose and subsequently used as the starting material in glycolysis. A key adaptation to long-term survival during hypoxia is the ability of an organism to store large amounts of glycogen. Many hypoxia-tolerant species, such as carp, goldfish, [[killifish]], and [[oscar (fish)|oscar]] contain the largest glycogen content (300-2000 µmol glocosyl units/g) in their tissue compared to hypoxia-sensitive fish, such as rainbow trout, which contain only 100 µmol glocosyl units/g.<ref>{{Cite book | doi=10.1016/S1546-5098(08)00009-5|chapter = Chapter 9 the Anoxia-Tolerant Crucian Carp (Carassius Carassius L.)|title = Hypoxia| volume=27| pages=397–441|series = Fish Physiology|year = 2009|last1 = Vornanen|first1 = Matti| last2=Stecyk| first2=Jonathan A.W.| last3=Nilsson| first3=Göran E.| isbn=9780123746320}}</ref> The more glycogen stored in a tissue indicates the capacity for that tissue to undergo glycolysis and produce ATP.
===Tolerance of waste products=== When anaerobic pathways are turned on, glycogen stores are depleted and accumulation of acidic waste products occurs. This is known as a [[Pasteur effect]]. A challenge hypoxia-tolerant fish face is how to produce ATP anaerobically without creating a significant Pasteur effect. Along with a reduction in metabolism, some fish have adapted traits to avoid accumulation of [[lactic acid|lactate]]. For example, the crucian carp, a highly hypoxia-tolerant fish, has evolved to survive months of anoxic waters. A key adaptation is the ability to convert lactate to ethanol in the muscle and excrete it out of their gills.<ref>{{citation | pmid= 7384807 | doi=10.1126/science.7384807 | title=Ethanol: novel end product of vertebrate anaerobic metabolism | journal=Science | date=1980 | volume=209 | issue=4453 | pages=308–309 | first=E. | last=Shoubridge}}</ref> Although this process is energetically costly is it crucial to their survival in hypoxic waters.
==Gene expression changes== [[DNA microarray]] studies done on different fish species exposed to low-oxygen conditions have shown that at the genetic level fish respond to hypoxia by changing the expression of genes involved in oxygen transport, ATP production, and [[protein synthesis]]. In the liver of [[mudsucker]]s exposed to hypoxia there were changes in the expression of genes involved in [[heme]] metabolism such as [[hemopexin]], [[heme oxygenase 1]], and [[ferritin]].<ref name= "Gracey">{{cite journal | last1 = Gracey | first1 = AY | last2 = Troll | first2 = JV | last3 = Somero | first3 = GN | year = 2001 | title = Hypoxia-induced gene expression profiling in the euryoxic fish Gillichthys mirabilis | url = | journal = Proc Natl Acad Sci USA | volume = 98 | issue = 4| pages = 1993–1998 | pmid = 11172064 | doi=10.1073/pnas.98.4.1993 | pmc=29370}}</ref> Changes in the sequestration and metabolism of iron may suggest hypoxia induced [[erythropoiesis]] and increased demand for hemoglobin synthesis, leading to increased oxygen uptake and transport. Increased expression of [[myoglobin]], which is normally only found in muscle tissue, has also been observed after hypoxia exposure in the gills of zebrafish<ref name= "van der meer">{{cite journal | pmid = 15994372 | doi=10.1152/ajpregu.00089.2005 | volume=289 | issue=5 | title=Gene expression profiling of the long-term adaptive response to hypoxia in the gills of adult zebrafish | date=November 2005 | pages=R1512–9 | journal=American Journal of Physiology. Regulatory, Integrative and Comparative Physiology | last1 = van der Meer | first1 = DL | last2 = den Thillart | first2 = GE | last3 = Witte | first3 = F | display-authors = 3 | last4 = et al}}</ref> and in non-muscle tissue of the [[common carp]]<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Fraser | first1 = J | last2 = de Mello | first2 = LV | last3 = Ward | first3 = D | last4 = Rees | first4 = HH | last5 = Williams | first5 = DR | last6 = Fang | first6 = YC | last7 = Brass | first7 = A | last8 = Gracey | first8 = AY | last9 = Cossins | first9 = AR | year = 2006 | title = Hypoxia-inducible myoglobin expression in non-muscle tissues | url = | journal = Proc Natl Acad Sci USA | volume = 103 | issue = 8| pages = 2977–2981 | pmid = 16469844 | doi=10.1073/pnas.0508270103 | pmc=1413783}}</ref> suggesting increased oxygen transport throughout fish tissues.
Microarray studies done on fish species exposed to hypoxia typically show a metabolic switch, that is, a decrease in the expression of genes involved in aerobic metabolism and an increase in expression of genes involved in anaerobic metabolism. Zebrafish embryos exposed to hypoxia decreased expression of genes involved in the [[citric acid cycle]] including, [[succinate dehydrogenase]], [[malate dehydrogenase]], and [[citrate synthase]], and increased expression of genes involved in glycolysis such as [[phosphoglycerate mutase]], [[enolase]], [[aldolase]], and [[lactate dehydrogenase]].<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 12700360 | doi=10.1152/physiolgenomics.00128.2002 | volume=13 | issue=2 | title=Gene expression profile of zebrafish exposed to hypoxia during development | date=April 2003 | pages=97–106 | journal=Physiological Genomics | last1 = Ton | first1 = C | last2 = Stamatiou | first2 = D | last3 = Liew | first3 = CC}}</ref> A decrease in protein synthesis is an important response to hypoxia in order to decrease ATP demand for whole organism metabolic suppression. Decreases in the expression of genes involved in protein synthesis, such as [[elongation factor-2]] and several [[ribosomal proteins]], have been shown in the muscle of the mudsucker<ref name= "Gracey"/> and gills of adult zebrafish<ref name= "van der meer"/> after hypoxia exposure .
Research in mammals has implicated [[hypoxia-inducible factors|hypoxia inducible factor (HIF)]] as a key regulator of gene expression changes in response to hypoxia<ref name= "Nikinmaa">{{cite journal | pmid = 15821280 | doi=10.1152/ajpregu.00626.2004 | volume=288 | issue=5 | title=Oxygen-dependent gene expression in fishes | date=May 2005 | pages=R1079–90 | journal=American Journal of Physiology. Regulatory, Integrative and Comparative Physiology | last1 = Nikinmaa | first1 = M | last2 = Rees | first2 = BB}}</ref> However, a direct link between fish HIFs and gene expression changes in response to hypoxia has yet to be found. [[Phylogenetics|Phylogenetic analysis]] of available fish, [[tetrapod]], and [[bird]] HIF-α and -β sequences shows that the isoforms of both subunits present in mammals are also represented in fish Within fish, HIF sequences group close together and are distinct from tetrapod and bird sequences.<ref name ="Richards"/> As well, amino acid analysis of available fish HIF-α and -β sequences reveals that they contain all functional domains shown to be important for mammalian HIF function,<ref name ="Richards"/> including the [[Basic-helix-loop-helix|basic helix-loop-helix (bHLH)]] domain, [[PAS domain|Per-ARNT-Sim (PAS)]] domain, and the oxygen-dependent degradation domain (ODD), which render the HIF-α subunit sensitive to oxygen levels.<ref name= "Nikinmaa"/> The evolutionary similarity between HIF sequences in fish, tetrapods and birds, as well as the conservation of important functional domains suggests that HIF function and regulation is similar between fish and mammalian species. There is also evidence of novel HIF mechanisms present in fish not found in mammals. In mammals, HIF-α protein is continuously synthesized and regulated [[posttranslational modification|post-translationally]] by changing oxygen conditions,<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Kenneth | first1 = NS | last2 = Rocha | first2 = S | year = 2008 | title = Regulation of gene expression by hypoxia | url = | journal = Biochem J | volume = 414 | issue = 1| pages = 19–29 | pmid = 18651837 | doi=10.1042/BJ20081055}}</ref> but it has been shown in different fish species that HIF-α [[mRNA]] levels are also responsive to hypoxia. In the hypoxia tolerant [[grass carp]], substantial increases in HIF-1α and HIF-3α mRNA were observed in all tissues after hypoxia exposure.<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 16623959 | doi=10.1186/1471-2199-7-15 | volume=7 | title=Cloning and expression analysis of two distinct HIF-alpha isoforms--gcHIF-1alpha and gcHIF-4alpha--from the hypoxia-tolerant grass carp, Ctenopharyngodon idellus | pmc=1473195 | year=2006 | pages=15 | issue=1 | journal=BMC Molecular Biology | last1 = Law | first1 = SH | last2 = Wu | first2 = RS | last3 = Ng | first3 = PK | last4 = Yu | first4 = RM | last5 = Kong | first5 = RY}}</ref> Likewise, mRNA levels of HIF-1α and HIF-2α were hypoxia-responsive in the ovaries of the [[Atlantic croaker]] during both short and long term hypoxia.<ref>{{citation | pmid =17467194 | doi=10.1016/j.gene.2007.03.009 | title=Molecular cloning, characterization and expression of two hypoxia-inducible factor alpha subunits, HIF-1α and HIF-2α, in a hypoxia-tolerant marine teleost, Atlantic croaker (Micropogonias undulatus) | journal=Gene | date=2007 | volume=396 | issue=2 | pages=273–282 | first=Md. Saydur | last=Rahman}}</ref>
