{{Expert needed|reason=Shockingly unsubstantiated material primarily in the composition section}} In [[astronomy]], the '''intracluster medium''' ('''ICM''') is the superheated [[plasma (physics)|plasma]] that permeates a [[galaxy cluster]]. The gas consists mainly of [[ionized hydrogen]] and [[helium]] and accounts for most of the [[baryon]]ic material in galaxy clusters. The ICM is heated to temperatures on the order of 10 to 100 [[Orders of magnitude (temperature)|megakelvins]], emitting strong [[X-ray]] radiation. [[Image:A2199 Xray Optical.jpg|thumb|333px|Comparison of the [[X-ray]] emission from the intracluster medium in the core of the [[Abell 2199]] galaxy cluster against the optical emission of the galaxies (from the [[Digitized Sky Survey|DSS]])]]
==Composition== {{See also|Intergalactic star}} The ICM is composed primarily of ordinary [[baryon]]s, mainly ionised hydrogen and helium.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title=Galaxies in the Universe|last=Sparke|first=L.S.|last2=Gallagher|first2=J.S.|publisher=[[Cambridge University Press]]|year=2007|isbn=978-0-521-67186-6|location=|pages=|quote=|via=}}</ref> This plasma is enriched with heavier elements, including [[iron]]. The amount of heavier elements relative to hydrogen, known as [[metallicity]] in astronomy, is roughly a third of the value in the [[sun]].<ref name=":0" />{{doubtful|reason=Metallicity is heavily dependent on age and environment, and a meaningful average for galaxy clusters does not make any sense for the Universe as a whole.|date=December 2017}} The metallicity rises from the outer region towards the center and in some clusters (e.g. the [[Centaurus cluster]]) the metallicity of the gas can rise above that of the sun.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Sanders|first=J. S.|last2=Fabian|first2=A. C.|last3=Taylor|first3=G. B.|last4=Russell|first4=H. R.|last5=Blundell|first5=K. M.|last6=Canning|first6=R. E. A.|last7=Hlavacek-Larrondo|first7=J.|last8=Walker|first8=S. A.|last9=Grimes|first9=C. K.|date=2016-03-21|title=A very deep Chandra view of metals, sloshing and feedback in the Centaurus cluster of galaxies|url=https://academic.oup.com/mnras/article/457/1/82/988962/A-very-deep-Chandra-view-of-metals-sloshing-and|journal=Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society|volume=457|issue=1|pages=82–109|doi=10.1093/mnras/stv2972|issn=0035-8711|bibcode=2016MNRAS.457...82S|arxiv = 1601.01489 }}</ref> Due to the gravitational field of clusters, metal-enriched gas ejected from [[supernova]]e remains [[Gravitational binding energy|gravitationally bound]] to the cluster as part of the ICM. Studying the chemical composition of typical ICMs{{explain|reason=what is a typical ICM anyway?|date=December 2017}} at varying [[redshift]], which corresponds to looking at different epochs of the evolution of the Universe, can provide a history record of element production.<ref>Loewenstein, Michael. ''[[arxiv:astro-ph/0310557|Chemical Composition of the Intracluster Medium]]'', Carnegie Observatories Centennial Symposia, p.422, 2004.</ref>
80-95% of the baryons in galaxy clusters reside in the ICM, rather than in the galaxies and single stars.{{citation needed|date=December 2017}} However, most of the mass in a galaxy cluster consists of [[dark matter]] and not baryonic matter. For the Virgo Cluster, the ICM contains roughly 3 × 10<sup>14</sup> M<sub>☉</sub> - including all kinds of matter - while the total mass of the cluster is estimated to be 1.2 × 10<sup>15</sup> M<sub>☉</sub>.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Fouque|first=Pascal|last2=Solanes|first2=Jose M.|last3=Sanchis|first3=Teresa|last4=Balkowski|first4=Chantal|date=2001-09-01|title=Structure, mass and distance of the Virgo cluster from a Tolman-Bondi model|journal=Astronomy & Astrophysics|volume=375|issue=3|pages=770–780|doi=10.1051/0004-6361:20010833|issn=0004-6361|arxiv=astro-ph/0106261|bibcode=2001A&A...375..770F}}</ref>
Although the ICM on the whole contains the bulk of a cluster's baryons, it is not very dense, with typical values of 10<sup>−3</sup> particles per cubic centimeter. The [[mean free path]] of the particles is roughly 10<sup>16</sup> m, or about one lightyear. The density of the ICM rises towards the centre of the cluster with a relatively strong peak. In addition, the temperature of the ICM typically drops to 1/2 or 1/3 of the outer value in the central regions. Once the density of the plasma reaches a critical value, enough interactions between the ions ensures cooling via X-ray radiation.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Peterson|first=J. R.|last2=Fabian|first2=A. C.|year=2006|title=X-ray spectroscopy of cooling clusters|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0370157306000020|journal=Physics Reports|volume=427|issue=1|pages=1–39|doi=10.1016/j.physrep.2005.12.007|bibcode=2006PhR...427....1P|arxiv = astro-ph/0512549 }}</ref>
==Observing the intracluster medium== As the ICM is at such high temperatures, it emits [[X-ray]] radiation, mainly by the [[bremsstrahlung]] process and X-ray [[emission lines]] from the heavy elements.<ref name=":0" /> These X-rays can be observed using an [[X-ray telescope]] and through analysis of this data, it is possible to determine the physical conditions, including the temperature, density, and metallicity, of the plasma.
Measurements of the temperature and density profiles in galaxy clusters allow for a determination of the mass distribution profile of the ICM through [[hydrostatic equilibrium]] <nowiki/>modeling. The mass distributions determined from these methods reveal masses that far exceed the luminous mass seen and are thus a strong indication of dark matter in galaxy clusters.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Kotov|first=O.|last2=Vikhlinin|first2=A.|year=2006|title=Chandra Sample of Galaxy Clusters at z = 0.4-0.55: Evolution in the Mass-Temperature Relation|url=http://stacks.iop.org/0004-637X/641/i=2/a=752|journal=The Astrophysical Journal|language=en|volume=641|issue=2|pages=752-755|doi=10.1086/500553|issn=0004-637X|bibcode=2006ApJ...641..752K|arxiv = astro-ph/0511044 }}</ref>
Inverse Compton Scattering of low energy photons through interactions with the relativistic electrons in the ICM cause distortions in the spectrum of the [[Cosmic microwave background|cosmic microwave background radiation (CMB)]], known as the [[Sunyaev–Zel'dovich effect]]. These temperature distortions in the CMB can be used by telescopes such as the [[South Pole Telescope]] to detect dense clusters of galaxies at high redshifts<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Staniszewski|first=Z.|last2=Ade|first2=P. A. R.|last3=Aird|first3=K. A.|last4=Benson|first4=B. A.|last5=Bleem|first5=L. E.|last6=Carlstrom|first6=J. E.|last7=Chang|first7=C. L.|last8=H.-M. Cho|last9=Crawford|first9=T. M.|year=2009|title=Galaxy Clusters Discovered with a Sunyaev-Zel'dovich Effect Survey|url=http://stacks.iop.org/0004-637X/701/i=1/a=32|journal=The Astrophysical Journal|language=en|volume=701|issue=1|pages=32-41|doi=10.1088/0004-637X/701/1/32|issn=0004-637X|bibcode=2009ApJ...701...32S|arxiv = 0810.1578 }}</ref>
== Cooling flows == Plasma in regions of the cluster, with a cooling time shorter than the age of the system, should be cooling due to strong X-ray radiation where emission is proportional to the density squared. Since the density of the ICM is highest towards the center of the cluster, the radiative cooling time drops a significant amount.<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=Fabian|first=A. C.|date=2003-06-01|title=Cluster cores and cooling flows|journal=Galaxy Evolution: Theory & Observations (Eds. Vladimir Avila-Reese|bibcode=2003RMxAC..17..303F|volume=17|pages=303–313|arxiv = astro-ph/0210150 }}</ref> The central cooled gas can no longer support the weight of the external hot gas and the pressure gradient drives what is known as a [[cooling flow]] where the hot gas from the external regions flows slowly towards the center of the cluster. This inflow would result in regions of cold gas and thus regions of new star formation.<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Fabian|first=A. C.|date=1994-01-01|title=Cooling Flows in Clusters of Galaxies|bibcode=1994ARA&A..32..277F|journal=Annual Review of Astronomy and Astrophysics|volume=32|pages=277–318|doi=10.1146/annurev.aa.32.090194.001425|issn=0066-4146|arxiv=astro-ph/0201386|citeseerx=10.1.1.255.3254}}</ref> Recently however, with the launch of new X-ray telescopes such as the [[Chandra X-ray Observatory]], images of galaxy clusters with better spatial resolution have been taken. These new images do not indicate signs of new star formation on the order of what was historically predicted, motivating research into the mechanisms that would prevent the central ICM from cooling.<ref name=":3" />
==Heating== [[File:NASA-PerseusGalaxyCluster-ChandraXRayObservatory-20140624.jpg|thumb|[[Chandra X-ray Observatory|Chandra]] image of the [[Perseus cluster|Perseus Cluster]]'s radio lobes. These relativistic jets of plasma emit [[radio wave]]s, are X-ray "cold", and appear as dark patches in stark contrast to the rest of the ICM. ]] There are two popular explanations of the mechanisms that prevent the central ICM from cooling: feedback from [[Active galactic nucleus|active galactic nuclei]] through injection of relativistic jets of plasma<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Yang|first=H.-Y. Karen|last2=Reynolds|first2=Christopher S.|date=2016-01-01|title=How AGN Jets Heat the Intracluster Medium—Insights from Hydrodynamic Simulations|url=http://stacks.iop.org/0004-637X/829/i=2/a=90|journal=The Astrophysical Journal|language=en|volume=829|issue=2|pages=90|doi=10.3847/0004-637X/829/2/90|issn=0004-637X|bibcode=2016ApJ...829...90Y|arxiv = 1605.01725 }}</ref> and sloshing of the ICM plasma during mergers with subclusters.<ref>{{cite journal|last=ZuHone|first=J. A.|last2=Markevitch|first2=M.|date=2009-01-01|title=Cluster Core Heating from Merging Subclusters|journal=The Monster's Fiery Breath: Feedback in Galaxies|volume=1201|arxiv=0909.0560|pages=383–386|doi=10.1063/1.3293082|series=AIP Conference Proceedings|bibcode=2009AIPC.1201..383Z|citeseerx=10.1.1.246.2787}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title=Lighthouses of the Universe: The Most Luminous Celestial Objects and Their Use for Cosmology|last=Fabian|first=Andrew C.|publisher=Springer, Berlin, Heidelberg|pages=24–36|language=en|doi=10.1007/10856495_3|arxiv = astro-ph/0201386 |chapter = Cooling Flows in Clusters of Galaxies|series = Eso Astrophysics Symposia|year = 2002|isbn = 978-3-540-43769-7|citeseerx = 10.1.1.255.3254}}</ref> The relativistic jets of material from active galactic nuclei can be seen in images taken by telescopes with high angular resolution such as the [[Chandra X-ray Observatory]].
==See also== * [[Interstellar medium]] * [[List of plasma (physics) articles]]

'''Jaskólski''', feminine: '''Jaskólska''' is a Polish-language [[toponymic surname]] derived from any of the places named [[Jaskółki (disambiguation)|Jaskółki]]. The latter word is the plural of the Polish word ''[[wikt:jaskółka|jaskółka]]'', i.e., literally means "[[swallow]]s". The surname may be phonemically transcribed as '''Jaskulski / Jaskulska'''. As a [[szlachta|Polish noble]] surname, it belongs to the [[Leszczyc coat of arms]] [[heraldic clan]].
When transliterated via the Russian language, the surname accepts the forms ''Yaskolsky / Yaskolski'' (f.: ''Yaskolskaya''), resp. ''Yaskulsky / Yaskulski'' (f.: ''Yaskulskaya'').
Notable people with the surname include:
*[[Erwin Jaskulski]] (1902–2006), American sprinter *[[Franciszek Jerzy Jaskulski]] (1913–1947), Polish resistance fighter *[[Marcin Jaskulski]] (born 1977), Polish-born Australian journalist *[[Robert Jaskulski]], American politician
==See also== *[[Jaskółka (disambiguation)]]
{{surname}} [[Category:Polish-language surnames]] [[Category:Toponymic surnames]]
[[pl:Jaskólski]]

{{Infobox book | name = Keeping Up with the Kalashnikovs | title_orig = | translator = | author = [[Paul Howard (journalist)|Paul Howard]] | illustrator = Alan Clarke | cover_artist = Alan Clarke | country = Ireland | language = [[English language|English]] | series = [[Ross O'Carroll-Kelly]] | published = 2014 [[Penguin Books]] | preceded_by = [[Downturn Abbey]] | followed_by = [[Seedless in Seattle]] | title_working = Raiders of the Lost Dork<ref>https://www.rte.ie/culture/2016/0908/815210-no-dark-star-paul-howard-on-ross-ocarroll-kelly/</ref> }}
'''''Keeping Up with the Kalashnikovs''''' is a 2014 novel by Irish journalist and author [[Paul Howard (journalist)|Paul Howard]] and serves as the fourteenth book in the [[Ross O'Carroll-Kelly]] series.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/culture/books/there-s-life-in-the-old-rosser-yet-keeping-up-with-the-kalashnikovs-1.1941634|title=There’s life in the old Rosser yet: Keeping up with the Kalashnikovs|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.writing.ie/readers/keeping-up-with-the-kalashnikovs/|title=Keeping up with the Kalashnikovs|first=Writing.ie. Editor Vanessa|last=O'Loughlin.|publisher=}}</ref>
The title refers to ''[[Keeping Up with the Kardashians]]'' and the [[Kalashnikov rifle]].
==Plot== Fionn is taken captive while teaching at a school in [[Uganda]]. Ross and the guys go out to rescue him. Meanwhile, Sorcha has given birth to triplets and Honor is more difficult than ever.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rossocarrollkelly.ie/NewsPage.aspx?p=Kala |title=Keeping Up with the Kalashnikovs |publisher=www.rossocarrollkelly.ie |accessdate=16 February 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150202051721/http://www.rossocarrollkelly.ie/NewsPage.aspx?p=Kala |archivedate= 2 February 2015 |df= }}</ref>

'''Land ownership in Canada''' is held by governments, Indigenous groups, corporations, and individuals. [[Canada]] is the second-largest country in the world by area; at 9,093,507 km² or 3,511,085 mi² of land (and more if fresh water is not included) it occupies more than 6% of the Earth's surface. Since Canada uses primarily English-derived [[common law]], the holders of the land actually have [[land tenure]] (permission to hold land from [[the Crown]]) rather than absolute ownership.<ref>http://www.aucc.ca/_pdf/english/programs/cepra/cad-wp3.pdf {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071013104529/http://www.aucc.ca/_pdf/english/programs/cepra/cad-wp3.pdf |date=October 13, 2007 }}</ref>
== Crown lands == {{See also|Crown land#Canada}}
The majority of all lands in Canada are held by governments as [[public land]] and are known as [[Crown land]]s. About 89% of Canada's land area (8,886,356 km²) is Crown land, which may either be [[Government of Canada|federal]] (41%) or [[Legislative Assemblies of Canadian provinces and territories|provincial]] (48%); the remaining 11% is privately owned.<ref name="Crown">{{Cite web|url=http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.com/en/article/crown-land/ |title=Crown Land |accessdate=2007-02-12|author=V.P. NEIMANIS|work=The Canadian Encyclopedia: Geography|publisher=Historica Foundation of Canada}}</ref> Most federal-administered land is in the Canadian territories ([[Northwest Territories]], [[Nunavut]] and [[Yukon]]), and is administered on behalf of [[Aboriginal Affairs and Northern Development Canada]]; only 4% of land in the provinces is federally controlled, largely in the form of [[National Parks of Canada|National Parks]], [[Indian reserves]], or [[Canadian Forces]] bases. In contrast, provinces hold much of their territory as provincial Crown land, which may be held as [[List of Canadian provincial parks|Provincial Parks]] or wilderness.
The largest class of landowners are the provincial governments, who hold all unclaimed land in their jurisdiction. Over 90% of the sprawling [[boreal forest of Canada]] is provincial Crown land.<ref>State of Canada's Forests 2004–2005, p. 49</ref> Provincial lands account for 60% of the area of the province of Alberta,<ref>[http://www.srd.alberta.ca/lands/geographicinformation/resourcedataproductcatalogue/greenwwhiteareas.aspx] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090312072546/http://www.srd.alberta.ca/lands/geographicinformation/resourcedataproductcatalogue/greenwwhiteareas.aspx |date=March 12, 2009 }}</ref> 94% of the land in [[British Columbia]],<ref>[http://www.al.gov.bc.ca/clad/crownland_factsheet.pdf; Minister of Agriculture and Lands; ''Crown Land Fact Sheet''.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110903144257/http://www.al.gov.bc.ca/clad/crownland_factsheet.pdf |date=2011-09-03 }}</ref> 95% of [[Newfoundland and Labrador]],<ref name="Crown" /> and 48% of [[New Brunswick]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Mitchell|first=Simon J.|title=Who Owns Crown Lands?|publisher=Falls Brook Centre|accessdate=18 February 2014|date=June 2003}}</ref>
The largest single landowner in Canada by far, and by extension one of the world's largest, is the [[Government of Canada]]. The bulk of the federal government's lands are in the vast [[Northern Canada|northern territories]] where Crown lands are vested in the federal, rather than territorial, government. In addition the federal government owns [[National Parks of Canada|national parks]], [[First Nations reserves]] and [[Canadian Forces Base|national defence installations]].
Until the [[Natural Resources Acts]] of 1930 the prairie provinces of Alberta, Saskatchewan, and Manitoba, and to a limited extent British Columbia, did not control Crown lands or subsoil rights within their boundaries, which instead rested with the federal government. This deprived them of the benefits of [[royalties]] from mining, oil and gas, or forestry (stumpage) within their boundaries. This was a major source of [[Western alienation]] at the time.
== History of land distribution == In [[New France]] land was settled according to the [[seigneurial system of New France|seigneurial system]], which was similar to the type of late feudalism practised in France at the time, and land was divided into long strip lots running back from the riverfront. This land pattern was also used in certain areas of Western Canada by French and [[Métis people (Canada)|Métis]] settlers.
In contrast, areas of British settlement used square block patterns of land distribution. Those in Eastern Canada contoured around geographical features and consisted of smaller lots. In Western Canada, where the American-influenced [[Dominion Land Survey]] was used, geographical features were largely ignored in favour of geometric standardization, with larger lots.
In [[Canadian law]] all lands are subject to the Crown, and this has been true since Britain acquired much of [[Eastern Canada]] from France by the [[Treaty of Paris (1763)]]. However, the British and Canadian authorities recognized that indigenous peoples already on the lands had a prior claim, [[aboriginal title]], which was not extinguished by the arrival of the Europeans. This is in direct contrast to the situation in Australia where the continent was declared [[terra nullius]], or vacant land, and was seized from Aboriginal peoples without compensation. In consequence, all of Canada, save a section of southern Quebec exempted by the [[Royal Proclamation of 1763]], is subject to Aboriginal title. Native groups historically negotiated treaties in which they traded tenure to the land for annuities and certain legal exemptions and privileges. Most of Western Canada was secured in this way by the government via the [[Numbered Treaties]] of 1871 to 1921, though not all groups signed treaties. In particular, in most of British Columbia Aboriginal title has never been transferred to the Crown. Many native groups, both those that have never signed treaties or those that are dissatisfied with the execution of treaties have made formal [[Aboriginal land claims]] against the government.
The Crown also gave tenure to much of Canada to a private company, the [[Hudson's Bay Company]] (HBC) which from 1670 to 1870 had a legal and economic monopoly on all land in the [[Rupert's Land]] territory (identical to the [[drainage basin]] of [[Hudson Bay]]), and later the [[Columbia District]] and the [[North-Western Territory]] (now British Columbia, the Yukon, the Northwest Territories, and [[Nunavut]]) were added to the HBC's lands, making it one of the largest private landowners in world history. In 1868 the [[British Imperial Parliament|Imperial Parliament]] passed the ''[[Rupert's Land Act]]'' that saw most of its land ownership transferred to the Dominion of Canada.
After Canada acquired the HBC's land in 1870, it used the land as an economic tool to promote settlement and development. Under the [[Dominion Lands Act]] system of 1871, huge areas were given to the [[Canadian Pacific Railway]] to fund its transcontinental line, other areas were reserved for school boards to be sold to fund education, and the rest was distributed to settlers for agriculture. Settlers paid a $10 fee and agreed to make some improvements within a specified time for {{convert|160|acres}}, commonly known as a quarter section, of land. This was at a time of extreme land shortage in many agricultural areas of Europe, and aided in the rapid settlement of Western Canada. In areas where ranching was preferred to field agriculture (e.g. [[southern Alberta]]), large areas were leased to [[cattle baron]]s at a nominal rate, allowing the development of an industrial-scale beef export industry centred on the city of [[Calgary]].
At the same time, major land reforms were underway in Prince Edward Island to end the practice of [[absentee landlordism]], which locals felt exploited them. The Government of Canada agreed to provide the Island with an $800,000 fund to purchase the remaining absentee landlord's estates as part of negotiations that brought PEI into Confederation.
Lands given out in the early years of the Dominion Lands Act included rights to the subsoil, including all minerals, oil, or natural gas found below the property.{{citation needed|date=April 2014}} Later grants (after circa 1900) did not include subsoil rights. As a result, in the leading petroleum producing province of Alberta, 81% of the subsurface mineral rights are owned by the provincial Crown. The remaining 19% are owned by the federal Crown, individuals, or corporations.<ref>{{cite web|title=Talk about Royalties, Facts on Royalties|url=http://www.energy.alberta.ca/Org/pdfs/FS_Royalties.pdf|publisher=Alberta Government|accessdate=18 February 2014|date=September 2012}}</ref>
== Characteristics of modern distribution == The result of cheaply distributed land and land reforms has been that modern Canada's land holding pattern is very egalitarian and large-scale{{Citation needed|date=October 2017}}. The majority of the population owns some land, often in large quantities. This is distinct from the few large landed estates and masses of tenant farmers typical of [[Old World]] and Latin American countries that have not enacted [[land reforms]], the communal and state ownership typical of Communist countries, or the small-holdings in those parts of Europe and Latin America where the estates were broken up.
== Recent trends == In the last century, the trend in Canada has been for a smaller percentage of people to own land, as more urbanization has turned people into renters. Still Canada has one of the world's highest rates of home ownership, which actually increased during the economic boom of the mid 2000s. In 2008, of the 12.4 million households in Canada, more than 8.5 million, over two-thirds (68.4%) owned their home, the highest rate since 1971. Much of the recent increases were in the form of [[condominium]]s, however, which are not land ownership in the traditional sense. In 1981, less than 4% of owner households owned condominiums. By 2001, this proportion had more than doubled to 9%, and by 2006, it had reached 10.9%.<ref>{{cite web|title=2006 Census: Changing patterns in Canadian homeownership and shelter costs|url=http://www.statcan.gc.ca/daily-quotidien/080604/dq080604a-eng.htm|work=statcan.gc.ca|accessdate=18 February 2014|date=June 4, 2008}}</ref> Again, this reflects the impact of urbanization which has changed land holding patterns substantially.
In rural areas, the trend has been towards further farm consolidation. The number of farms has continually decreased since the end of the pioneering era in Western Canada (as recently as the 1930s in some regions, but more generally 1914), and at the same time, farm sizes have increased.
The other trend in rural Canada is for more urbanites to own summer homes, cottages, cabins, acreages, and hobby farms. This is especially apparent in areas that are situated within a convenient driving distance of major urban centres. Because Canada's major urban centres were historically founded on prime agricultural land, the end result is a permanent loss of agricultural land. This trend is further exacerbated by low-density residential subdivisions being constructed at the margins of cities, as well as the appearance of isolated rural residential "satellite subdivisions" specifically designed for complete [[Automobile dependency|car dependency]].
==See also== * [[Land tenure]] * [[Landholder]] * Patterns of landholding: [[Feudalism]] / [[Smallholding]] / [[Commune (intentional community)|Commune]] / [[Sharecropping]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=November 2017}} [[File:Pixar logo.svg|260px|right]] This is a '''list of films from [[Pixar|Pixar Animation Studios]]''', an American [[computer-generated imagery|CGI]] film production company based in [[Emeryville, California]], United States. As of {{dts|2018}}, Pixar Animation Studios has released 20 feature films, which were all released under the [[Walt Disney Pictures]] banner. The company produced its first feature-length film, ''[[Toy Story]]'', in 1995. Their second production, ''[[A Bug's Life]]'', was released in 1998, followed by their first sequel, ''[[Toy Story 2]]'', in 1999. Pixar Animation Studios had two releases in a single year twice: ''[[Inside Out (2015 film)|Inside Out]]'' and ''[[The Good Dinosaur]]'' in 2015 and ''[[Cars 3]]'' and ''[[Coco (2017 film)|Coco]]'' in 2017. Their upcoming slate of films include ''[[Toy Story 4]]'' (2019),{{cite news|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/john-lasseter-direct-fourth-toy-747226 | title=John Lasseter to Direct Fourth 'Toy Story' Film | last=Ford | first=Rebecca | work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] | date=November 6, 2014 | accessdate=November 6, 2014}}{{cite news|last1=Hipes|first1=Patick|title=Disney: ‘Ant Man And The Wasp’ A Go, ‘The Incredibles 2’ Dated & More|url=http://deadline.com/2015/10/ant-man-sequel-incredibles-2-release-dates-disney-1201570867/|accessdate=October 8, 2015|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|date=October 8, 2015}}{{cite web|last1=Williams|first1=Mike|title=No More Sequels in Development After "The Incredibles 2," Pixar Says|url=https://uk.movies.yahoo.com/no-more-sequels-in-development-after-incredibles-135242136.html|publisher=[[Yahoo!]]|accessdate=July 3, 2016}} two untitled films set to be released in 2020, an untitled film set to be release in 2021,{{cite web|last1=Busch|first1=Anita|title='Star Wars,' 'Frozen 2' And 'The Lion King': Disney Unleashes A Barrage of Release Dates|url=http://deadline.com/2017/04/star-wars-episode-ix-frozen-sequel-and-the-lion-king-live-action-disney-release-dates-1202077098/|website=Deadline Hollywood|accessdate=April 25, 2017|date=April 25, 2017}} and another two untitled films set to be released in 2022.{{cite news|last1=Milligan|first1=Mercedes|title=Disney Pushes Live ‘Mulan’ to 2020/1988, Dates Multi-Studio Slate|url=http://www.animationmagazine.net/features/disney-pushes-live-mulan-to-2020-dates-multi-studio-slate/|accessdate=March 5, 2018|work=Animation Magazine|date=March 1, 2018}} ==Films== ===Released=== {| class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align:center; margin=auto; width:100%;" |- ! ===Upcoming=== {| class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align:center; margin=auto; width:100%;" |- ! rowspan=2 width=3% | # ! rowspan=2 width=10% | Film ! rowspan=2 width=10% | Release date ! width=10% | Screenplay |- | 21 | ''[[Toy Story 4]]''{{cite web|last1=Berman|first1=Rachel|url=https://ohmy.disney.com/news/2016/10/26/breaking-toy-story-4-and-the-incredibles-2-get-new-release-dates/|title=Breaking: Toy Story 4 and The Incredibles 2 Get New Release Dates!|publisher=Oh My Disney|date=October 26, 2016|accessdate=November 5, 2016}} | June 21, 2019 | Josh Cooley | John Lasseter, Pete Docter, Andrew Stanton & Lee Unkrich{{cite news|last1=Khatchatourian|first1=Maane|title='Toy Story 4': Josh Cooley Becomes Sole Director as John Lasseter Steps Down|url=https://variety.com/2017/film/news/toy-story-4-new-director-josh-cooley-john-lasseter-steps-down-1202496456/|accessdate=July 21, 2017|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=July 14, 2017}} | Stephany Folsom{{cite news|url=https://variety.com/2018/film/news/disney-pixar-screenwriter-toy-story-4-1202669141/|title=Disney-Pixar Hires New Screenwriter for ‘Toy Story 4’|last1=McNary|first1=Dave|date=January 18, 2018|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]}} | Jonas Rivera{{cite news|url=http://www.cbr.com/d23-expo-pixar-walt-disney-animation-studios-upcoming-films/|title=D23 Expo: Pixar and Walt Disney Animation Studios: The Upcoming Films|last1=Ching|first1=Albert|date=July 14, 2017|publisher=[[Comic Book Resources|CBR]]}} | style="background:lightgrey;" | TBA | Randy Newman |} After the release of ''Toy Story 4'', five untitled projects are slated for March 6, 2020, June 19, 2020, June 18, 2021, March 18, 2022, and June 17, 2022.{{cite news|last1=Milligan|first1=Mercedes|title=Disney Pushes Live ‘Mulan’ to 2020/1988, Dates Multi-Studio Slate|url=http://www.animationmagazine.net/features/disney-pushes-live-mulan-to-2020-dates-multi-studio-slate/|accessdate=March 5, 2018|work=Animation Magazine|date=March 1, 2018}} As of June 2016, both films set for 2020 are planned to be original, followed by another two original films that are still in early development.{{cite news|url=http://www.ew.com/article/2016/07/01/pixar-sequels-ratatouille-wall-e-inside-out|title=Pixar: No sequels for ''Ratatouille'', ''WALL-E'', or ''Inside Out'' anytime soon|last=Snetiker|first=Marc|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|date=July 1, 2016|accessdate=July 2, 2016}} In 2017, it was announced that Dan Scanlon is directing a suburban fantasy film, with Kori Rae producing, which takes place in a post-magical world without humans and populated with elves, trolls, and sprites, where unicorns are as common as rodents. The film will follow two elf brothers who lost their father when they were too young to remember him, and with the help of some magical remains left in the world, they embark on a quest which could give them a day to spend with their deceased father.{{cite news|title=D23: Pixar Announces Untitled Quest Movie Set in 'Suburban Fantasy World'|url=https://variety.com/2017/film/news/pixar-disney-untitled-suburban-fantasy-world-unicorns-d23-1202496455/|date=July 14, 2017|accessdate=July 21, 2017|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]}} The film was inspired by the death of Scanlon's father, who died when he and his brother were 1 and 3 years old respectively. Scanlon decided to write this story when they were played an audio clip of him as teenagers.[http://www.mtv.com/news/3025627/pixar-suburban-fantasy-film-dan-scanlon/ Pixar's New 'Suburban Fantasy' Sounds Like A Real Tearjerker - MTV] It will begin production in January 2019.{{cite news|title=EXCLUSIVE: Untitled Pixar Film Begins Production January 2019|url=https://disneyfilmfacts.com/2018/05/31/untitled-pixar-begins-january-2019/amp/?__twitter_impression=true|date=May 31, 2018|accessdate=May 31, 2018|work=Disney Film Facts}} Since 2017, Brian Fee has been directing an original film for Pixar,{{cite web|last1=Thomas|first1=Angelo|title='Cars 3' Director Brian Fee Is Directing an Original Pixar Movie|url=http://www.rotoscopers.com/2017/07/20/cars-3-director-brian-fee-is-directing-an-original-pixar-movie/|publisher=Rotoscopers|accessdate=July 21, 2017|date=July 20, 2017}} as well as films from Mark Andrews,{{cite news|last1=Ferguson|first1=Brian|title=Sequel to Disney-Pixar’s Brave on the cards|url=https://www.scotsman.com/lifestyle/culture/film/sequel-to-disney-pixar-s-brave-on-the-cards-1-2885742|accessdate=February 24, 2018|work=The Scotsman|date=April 10, 2013|quote=I am currently working on another film, which is original and is being written and directed by me, but that’s all I can say about that.}} and Pete Docter.{{cite news|title=Oscars: What the Nominees Are Saying|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/lists/2016-oscar-nominations-reactions-855599/item/pete-docter-oscar-nomination-reaction-855818|accessdate=February 24, 2018|work=The Hollywood Reporter|date=January 14, 2016|quote=I have a pitch late this week to John Lasseter for a new movie.}}{{cite web|title=Interview: Pixar president Jim Morris – 'The Good Dinosaur'|url=http://www.timeout.com.hk/film/features/75455/interview-pixar-president-jim-morris-the-good-dinosaur.html|publisher=TimeOut|accessdate=February 24, 2018|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160216092203/http://www.timeout.com.hk/film/features/75455/interview-pixar-president-jim-morris-the-good-dinosaur.html|archivedate=February 16, 2016|date=January 28, 2016|deadurl=yes|quote=Pete [Docter] and Jonas [Rivera], the producer, have a new and equally weird idea that they are working on...}} In 2018, it was revealed that [[Domee Shi]] was working on an animated feature based on an original idea.[https://variety.com/gallery/10-animators-to-watch-2018-variety/#!9/domee-shi Variety's 10 Animators to Watch 2018 – Variety] ===Production cycle=== In July 2013, Pixar Studios President [[Edwin Catmull]] said that the studio planned to release one original film each year, and a sequel every other year, as part of a strategy to release "one and a half movies a year."{{cite news|last=Vary|first=Adam|title=Pixar Chief: Studio To Scale Back Sequels, Aim For One Original Film A Year|url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/adambvary/pixar-chief-studio-to-scale-back-sequels-aim-for-one-origina|accessdate=July 2, 2013|publisher=[[BuzzFeed]]|date=June 27, 2013}} On July 3, 2016, Pixar president Jim Morris revealed that after ''[[Toy Story 4]]'', there are no plans for further sequels, and right now Pixar is only developing original ideas with five films currently in the works. ===Cancelled projects=== In 2005, Pixar began collaborating with Disney and [[Warner Bros.]] on a live-action film adaptation of [[James Dalessandro]]'s novel ''[[1906 (novel)|1906]]'', with Brad Bird attached to direct.{{cite web|last=Bastoli |first=Mike |title='1906' to be Disney/Pixar/Warner Bros. collaboration |url=http://www.bigscreenanimation.com/2008/03/1906-to-be-pixarwarner-bros.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20121208150759/http://www.bigscreenanimation.com/2008/03/1906-to-be-pixarwarner-bros.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=December 8, 2012 |work=March 13, 2008 |publisher=Big Screen Animation |accessdate=July 10, 2012 }} It would have marked Pixar's first involvement in a live-action production. The film was abandoned by Disney and Pixar due to script problems and an estimated budget of $200 million, and it is now in limbo at Warner Bros.{{cite news|last=Fischer|first=Russ|title=What Happened to Brad Bird’s 1906?|url=http://www.slashfilm.com/what-happened-to-brad-birds-1906/|accessdate=July 10, 2012|newspaper=[[Slashfilm]]|date=January 27, 2010}} In June 2018, Bird mentioned the possibility of adapting the novel as a TV series, with the earthquake sequence as a feature film.{{cite web|url=http://collider.com/1906-update-brad-bird/|title=Brad Bird Says '1906' May Get Made as an "Amalgam" of a TV and Film Project|date=June 18, 2018|accessdate=June 18, 2018|publisher=[[Collider (website)|Collider]]|author=Adam Chitwood}} A Pixar film titled ''Newt'' was announced in April 2008, with Pixar planning to release it in 2011,{{cite web|last1=Sciretta|first1=Peter|title=Pixar Announces Up, Newt, The Bear and the Bow and Cars 2|url=http://www.slashfilm.com/pixar-announces-up-newt-the-bear-and-the-bow-and-cars-2/|publisher=[[/Film]]|accessdate=May 27, 2015|date=April 8, 2008}} which was later bumped to 2012,{{cite web|last1=Sciretta|first1=Peter|title=Pixar's Newt Gets Cars 2's Old Release Date|url=http://www.slashfilm.com/pixars-newt-gets-cars-2s-old-release-date/|publisher=/Film|accessdate=May 27, 2015|date=September 25, 2008}} but it had been finally cancelled by early 2010.{{cite web|last1=Goldberg|first1=Matt|title=Pixar's NEWT Cancelled|url=http://collider.com/pixar-newt-cancelled/|publisher=Collider|accessdate=January 29, 2017|date=May 11, 2010}}{{cite web|last1=Bastoli |first1=Mike |title=Exclusive: Newt is "cancelled" |url=http://pixarblog.blogspot.com/2010/05/exclusive-newt-is-cancelled.html |publisher=The Pixar Blog |accessdate=January 29, 2017 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100514115251/http://pixarblog.blogspot.com/2010/05/exclusive-newt-is-cancelled.html |archivedate=May 14, 2010 |date=May 11, 2010 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy-all }} John Lasseter noted that the film's proposed plot line was similar to another film, [[Blue Sky Studios]]' ''[[Rio (2011 film)|Rio]]'', which was released in 2011.{{cite news|last=Vejvoda|first=Jim|title=Pixar on Newt|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2011/05/02/pixar-on-newt|accessdate=November 1, 2012|publisher=[[IGN]]|date=May 2, 2011}} In March 2014, in an interview, Pixar president Edwin Catmull stated that ''Newt'' was an idea that was not working in pre-production. When the project was passed to Pete Docter, the director of ''Up'', he pitched an idea that Pixar thought was better, and that concept became ''Inside Out''.{{cite news|title=Pixar’s Ed Catmull On How To Balance Art And Commerce|url=https://www.fastcompany.com/3027549/pixars-ed-catmull-on-how-to-balance-art-and-commerce|accessdate=March 5, 2018|work=Fast Company|date=March 19, 2014}}{{cite web|last1=Sciretta|first1=Peter|title=How Pixar's 'Newt' Got Flipped 'Inside Out'|url=http://www.slashfilm.com/pixars-newt-inside-out/2/|publisher=/Film|accessdate=March 5, 2018|date=August 15, 2014}} In 2010, [[Henry Selick]] formed a joint venture with Pixar called [[Cinderbiter Productions]], which was to exclusively produce stop-motion films.{{cite news|last=LeBlanc|first=Will|title=Henry Selick Bringing Stop-Motion Back To Disney|url=http://www.cinemablend.com/new/Henry-Selick-Bringing-Stop-Motion-Back-To-Disney-17865.html|accessdate=March 8, 2013|newspaper=Cinemablend|date=April 1, 2010}} Its first planned feature ''ShadeMaker'' was set for release in 2013,{{cite news |last=Bettinger |first=Brendan |title=Disney Cancels Production on Henry Selick's Untitled Stop-Motion Movie|publisher=Collider.com|date=August 14, 2012}} but was cancelled in 2012 due to creative differences.{{cite news|last=Fritz|first=Ben|title=Disney takes $50 million write-down on canceled animation project|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2012/sep/13/entertainment/la-et-ct-disney-50-million-write-down-20120913|accessdate=March 8, 2013|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=September 13, 2012}} Selick was then given the option to shop the project (now titled ''[[The Shadow King]]'') to other studios.{{cite web |url=http://www.avclub.com/articles/henry-selicks-the-shadow-king-proceeding-without-d,92060/ |title=Henry Selick's The Shadow King proceeding without Disney, but with a plot and voice cast |work=[[The A.V. Club]] |first= |last= |date= February 5, 2013 |accessdate=February 8, 2013}} In addition, when the now-defunct [[Circle 7 Animation]] was open, there were plans for sequels to ''Finding Nemo'' (which became ''Finding Dory'') and ''Monsters, Inc.'' (which became a prequel in the form of ''Monsters University''), as well as a different version of ''Toy Story 3''.{{cite news|last=Catmull|first=Ed|title=Pixar's Ed Catmull on How to Balance Art and Commerce|url=http://www.fastcompany.com/3027549/lessons-learned/pixars-ed-catmull-on-how-to-balance-art-and-commerce|accessdate=March 2, 2014|work=[[Fast Company (magazine)|Fast Company]]|date=March 19, 2014}} ===Co-production=== ''[[Buzz Lightyear of Star Command: The Adventure Begins]]'' is a traditionally animated direct-to-video film produced by [[Disney Television Animation]] with an opening sequence created by Pixar. The film was released on August 8, 2000, and led to a [[Buzz Lightyear of Star Command|television series]], with Pixar creating the CGI portion of the opening theme.{{cite news|last=Fretts|first=Bruce|title=Buzz Lightyear of Star Command Review|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,64853,00.html|accessdate=January 19, 2014|newspaper=Entertainment Weekly|date=August 8, 2000}} ===Collaboration=== Pixar assisted with the story development for the live-action Disney film ''[[The Jungle Book (2016 film)|The Jungle Book]]'', as well as providing suggestions for the film's end credits sequence. The film was released on April 15, 2016. Additional special thanks credit was given to Mark Andrews.{{cite news|last1=Taylor|first1=Drew|title=9 Things Disney Fans Need to Know About The Jungle Book, According to Jon Favreau|url=https://ohmy.disney.com/insider/2016/04/15/the-jungle-book-according-to-jon-favreau/|accessdate=April 16, 2016|work=Disney Insider|publisher=The Walt Disney Company}} ===Related productions=== ''[[Planes (film)|Planes]]'' is a spin-off of the [[Cars (franchise)|''Cars'' franchise]], produced by the now defunct [[Disneytoon Studios]] and co-written and executive produced by John Lasseter. The film was conceived from the short film ''[[Cars Toons#Mater's Tall Tales|Air Mater]]'', which introduces aspects of ''Planes'' and ends with a hint of the film. It was released on August 9, 2013. A sequel, ''[[Planes: Fire & Rescue]]'', was released on July 18, 2014. A third ''Planes'' film was announced in July 2017, with a planned release on April 12, 2019,{{cite web|url=http://www.comingsoon.net/movies/news/869187-untitled-space-movie-announced-by-disneytoon-studios#/slide/1|title=Space Movie Announced by DisneyToon Studios|date=July 14, 2017|publisher=}} but was subsequently removed from the release schedule on March 1, 2018.{{cite web|url=http://collider.com/disney-marvel-animation-release-dates/|title=Disney Announces a Slew of New Marvel, Live-Action and Animation Release Dates Through 2023|last=Foutch|first=Haliegh|website=Collider|date=March 1, 2018|accessdate=March 1, 2018}} The film was eventually cancelled when Disneytoon Studios shut down on June 28, 2018.{{cite news|last1=Desowitz|first1=Bill|title=Disney Shuts Down Disneytoon Studios in Glendale: Exclusive|url=https://www.indiewire.com/2018/06/disneytoon-studios-shuts-down-disney-glendale-1201979736/|accessdate=June 28, 2018|work=IndieWire|date=June 28, 2018}} ==Reception== ===Critical and public reception=== {| class="sortable wikitable" style="text-align: center;" |+ |- ! style="width:120px;" | Film ! data-sort-type="number" | [[Rotten Tomatoes]]{{cite web|title=Pixar|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/franchise/pixar/|publisher=[[Rotten Tomatoes]]}} ! data-sort-type="number" | [[Metacritic]]{{cite web|title=Pixar Animation Studios' Scores|url=http://www.metacritic.com/company/pixar-animation-studios|publisher=[[Metacritic]]}} ! List of archaeological sites in Whitchurch–Stouffville

revision.text:
This is a list of archaeological sites in [[Whitchurch–Stouffville]], [[Ontario]], [[Canada]]:<ref>See Gordon C. Dibb, "An Archaeological Survey of the East Holland River and its Environs." Manuscript on file, Ontario Ministry of Culture, Toronto, 1979; also Jean Barkey, et al., [http://www.ourroots.ca/page.aspx?id=2871838&qryID=2965ac36-2eaf-4194-94d0-1d9b3871d6b1 Whitchurch Township] (Erin, ON: Boston Mills, 1993), ch. 7; Jennifer Birch, ''[https://uga.academia.edu/JenniferBirch/Papers/700995/Coalescent_Communities_in_Iroquoian_Ontario Coalescent Communities Iroquoian Ontario]'' (PhD Dissertation, Dept. of Anthropology, McMaster University, 2010).</ref> Both the [[Trent University Site Designation]] number and the [[Borden System]] archaeological designations are given.<ref>For lot and concession numbers, see the detailed 1878 map, [http://digital.library.mcgill.ca/countyatlas/images/maps/townshipmaps/yor-m-whitchurch.jpg Township of Whitchurch], ''Illustrated historical atlas of the county of York and the township of West Gwillimbury & town of Bradford in the county of Simcoe, Ont.'' (Toronto: Miles & Co., 1878); also [https://mapsengine.google.com/map/edit?mid=zCsn2pUKysNY.kWv9uCGFsWQo Google Maps].</ref>
''Late Ontario Iroquois (1400 AD - 1650 AD)''<ref>Barkey et al., [http://www.ourroots.ca/page.aspx?id=2871842&qryID=9b743108-a4c1-4310-8d26-a5e22f04ca7f Whitchurch Township], pp. 121ff.</ref>
* [[Aurora Site, Wendat (Huron) Ancestral Village|Aurora (or Old Fort) Site]] (7Yk27; BaGu-27); 3.4 ha ** Location: Lots 14 and 15, Concession 6, West half. [https://maps.google.ca/maps?q=44%C2%B000%2720.3%22N+79%C2%B020%2719.1%22W&hl=en&ie=UTF8&sll=44.006278,-79.335306&sspn=0.054018,0.077162&gl=ca&t=m&z=17 44°00'N 79°20'W] ** Date: 1550-1600 AD * Aurora Isolated Site (7Yk24; BaGu-11) ** Location: Lot 15, Concession 6, West half. [https://maps.google.ca/maps?q=44%C2%B000%2722.6%22N+79%C2%B020%2707.1%22W&hl=en&ie=UTF8&sll=44.004453,-79.338005&sspn=0.013505,0.01929&gl=ca&t=m&z=14 44°00'N 79°20'W] * Chalk Site (7Yk20; BaGu-8) ** Location: Lot 16, Concession 4, East half. [https://maps.google.ca/maps?q=44%C2%B000%2730.3%22N+79%C2%B020%2743.2%22W&hl=en&ie=UTF8&sll=44.005639,-79.338639&sspn=0.006752,0.009645&gl=ca&t=m&z=14 44°00'N 79°22'W] * Clark Lake Site (7Yk23; BaGu-10) ** Location: Lot 14, Concession 5, East half. Entrance: [https://maps.google.ca/maps?q=44%C2%B000%2708.7%22N+79%C2%B020%2727.9%22W&hl=en&ie=UTF8&ll=44.0024,-79.341073&spn=0.013505,0.01929&sll=43.992969,-79.382508&sspn=0.013508,0.01929&gl=ca&t=m&z=16 44°00'N 79°20'W] * Foote Site (7Yk26; AlGt-158) ** Location: East side of [[York Regional Road 67|McCowan Road]], north of [[York Regional Road 14|Stouffville Road]]. [https://maps.google.ca/maps?q=43%C2%B057%2758.4%22N+79%C2%B018%2701.8%22W&hl=en&ie=UTF8&sll=44.008417,-79.345333&sspn=0.054016,0.077162&gl=ca&t=m&z=16 43°57'N 79°18'W] * Horton-Devins Site (7Yk22; BaGu-9) ** Location: East of [[York Regional Road 65|Warden Avenue]], north of Vandorf Sideroad. [https://maps.google.ca/maps?q=44%C2%B001%2702.6%22N+79%C2%B020%2720.7%22W&hl=en&ie=UTF8&sll=43.966222,-79.3005&sspn=0.013514,0.01929&gl=ca&t=m&z=17 44°01'N 79°20'W] * Hoshel-Huntly Site (7Yk21; AlGu-15)<ref>Cf. Barkey et al., [http://www.ourroots.ca/page.aspx?id=2871845&qryID=0d731b00-4479-452e-a2fd-87628f3683fd Whitchurch Township], p. 124.</ref> ** Location: West of [[York Regional Road 65|Warden Avenue]], on the south side of Vandorf Sideroad. [https://maps.google.ca/maps?q=44%C2%B000%2703.8%22N+79%C2%B022%2704%22W&hl=en&ie=UTF8&sll=44.017389,-79.339083&sspn=0.006751,0.009645&gl=ca&t=m&z=16 44°00'N 79°22'W] * [[Mantle Site, Wendat (Huron) Ancestral Village|Mantle Site]] (AlGt-334); 4.2 ha; 90% excavated ** Location: Immediately west of Byers Pond Way, and south-west of Lost Pond Crescent. [https://maps.google.ca/maps?q=43%C2%B057%2749.9%22N+79%C2%B014%2712%22W&hl=en&ie=UTF8&sll=44.001056,-79.367778&sspn=0.013506,0.01929&gl=ca&t=m&z=17 43°57'49.9"N 79°14'12"W] ** Date: 1500-1550 AD * Preston Site (7Yk18; AlGu-9) ** Location: Lot 13, Concession 4, West half. [https://maps.google.ca/maps?q=43%C2%B059%2734.7%22N+79%C2%B022%2757%22W&hl=en&ie=UTF8&ll=43.992969,-79.382508&spn=0.013508,0.01929&sll=43.991657,-79.383795&sspn=0.013508,0.01929&gl=ca&t=m&z=16 43°59'N 79°22'W] * [[Ratcliff Site, Wendat (Huron) Ancestral Village|Ratcliff (or Radcliffe) Site]] (7Yk25; AlGt-157); 2.8 ha ** Location: Lot 9, Concession 8, West half. [https://maps.google.ca/maps?q=43%C2%B059%2742.4%22N+79%C2%B016%2756%22W&ie=UTF8&hnear=0x89d52e9a36911b51:0x5cbfd9bb56678c8d,43%C2%B059%2742.4%22N+79%C2%B016%2756%22W&gl=ca&t=m&z=16 43°59'N 79°W] ** Date: 1550-1600 AD * Van Nostrand-Wright (or Vandorf) Site (7Yk19; A1Gu-13); 4.3 ha; limited excavation ** Location: Lots 14 and 15, Concession 4, West half; overlooking Van Nostrand Lake to the north-east. [https://maps.google.ca/maps?q=43%C2%B059%2741.3%22N+79%C2%B023%2711.5%22W&hl=en&ie=UTF8&sll=43.995111,-79.282222&sspn=0.013507,0.01929&gl=ca&t=m&z=16 43°59'N 79°23'W] ** Date: 1550-1600 AD
==See also== * [[Whitchurch–Stouffville]] * [[Draper Site, Wendat (Huron) Ancestral Village|Draper Site]], [[Pickering, Ontario]].

page.title: List of mobile network operators of the Middle East and Africa

revision.comment: There's no other UMTS; no need to distinguish it (and the redirects may go away anyway).
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2012}} This is a '''list of [[mobile network operator]]s of the [[Middle East]] and [[Africa]]'''. ==Algeria== At the end of 2014, the penetration rate was estimated at 109% over a population estimate of 39.5 million.{{cite web |url=http://www.arpt.dz/fr/doc/obs/etude/2014/Observatoire_Mobile_2014.pdf |title=Observatoire du marché de la telephonie mobile en Algerie annee 2014 |accessdate=25 March 2016}} The telecom regulator in Algeria is [http://www.arpt.dz/ Autorité de Régulation de la Poste et des Télécommunications] (ARPT). {|class="wikitable" |- ! style="width:3%;"| Rank !! style="width:15%;"| Operator !! style="width:30%;"| Technology !! style="width:20%;" | Subscribers
(in millions) !! style="width:32%;"| Ownership |- |align=right| 1 || [[Djezzy]] || [[GSM]]-900/1800 MHz ([[GPRS]], [[EDGE]])
2100 MHz [[UMTS]], [[High Speed Packet Access|HSPA]], [[HSPA+]]
1800 MHz [[Long Term Evolution|LTE]] || 18.6 (2014){{cite web |url=http://www.arpt.dz/fr/obs/etude/ |title=Algérie - Parc global des abonnés aux réseaux mobiles GSM & 3G par opérateur 2014 |publisher=Autorite de Regulation de la Poste et des Telecommunications (Algeria) |date=2014 |accessdate=25 March 2016}} || [[Global Telecom Holding]] (51.7%){{cite web |url=http://www.cellular-news.com/story/Business/65501.php |title=VimpelCom Sells 51% Stake in Algeria's Djezzy to Settle Long Running Dispute |publisher=cellular-news |date=2014-04-19 |accessdate=2014-04-19}} |- |align=right| 2 || [[Mobilis (Algeria)|Mobilis]] ||[[GSM]]-900/1800 MHz ([[GPRS]], [[EDGE]])
2100 MHz [[UMTS]], [[High Speed Packet Access|HSPA]], [[HSPA+]]
1800 MHz [[Long Term Evolution|LTE]] || 13.0 (2014) || [[Algérie Télécom]] |- |align=right| 3 || [[Ooredoo Algeria|Ooredoo]]
(formerly Nedjma) ||| [[GSM]]-900/1800 MHz ([[GPRS]], [[EDGE]])
2100 MHz [[UMTS]], [[High Speed Packet Access|HSPA]], [[HSPA+]]
1800 MHz [[Long Term Evolution|LTE]] || 11.7 (2014) || [[Ooredoo]] (74.4%) |} ==Angola== In September 2010 the penetration rate was estimated at 63.7% over a population estimate of 13.3 million.{{cite web |url=http://mnodirectory.com/ame/Angola.htm |title=Angola Mobile Market (Q1 2008 - Q3 2010) |accessdate=10 November 2011}} The telecom regulator in Angola is Instituto Angolano das Comunicações (INACOM). {|class="wikitable" |- ! style="width:3%;"| Rank !! style="width:15%;"| Operator !! style="width:30%;"| Technology !! style="width:20%;" | Subscribers
(in millions) !! style="width:32%;"| Ownership |-Mauritius |align=right| 1 || [[Unitel (Angola)|Unitel]] || [[GSM]]-900/1800 ([[GPRS]], [[Enhanced Data Rates for GSM Evolution|EDGE]])
2100 MHz [[UMTS]], [[HSDPA]]
2100 MHz [[Long Term Evolution|LTE]] || 7 (nov 2011){{cite web|url=http://wireless.sys-con.com/node/2056246 |title=OnMobile Launches RBT Services for Unitel Subscribers in Angola | Wireless Developer's Journal |publisher=Wireless.sys-con.com |date= |accessdate=13 August 2012}} || [[Mercury Communications|Mercury]] ([[Sonangol]] group) (25%), Group [[Geni Angola|GENI]] (25%),
[[Vidatel]] (25%), [[Portugal Telecom]] (25%){{cite web|author=carol says: |url=http://www.howwemadeitinafrica.com/angola-a-lucrative-market-for-telecoms-operators/3463/ |title=Angola a lucrative market for telecoms operators |publisher=Howwemadeitinafrica.com |date=15 September 2010 |accessdate=13 August 2012}} |- |align=right| 2 || [[Movicel]] || [[GSM]] ([[GPRS]], [[Enhanced Data Rates for GSM Evolution|EDGE]])
900 MHz [[UMTS]], [[HSDPA]]
1800 MHz [[Long Term Evolution|LTE]]|| 2.5 (September 2010) || Government ([[Angola Telecom]] (18%), [[Correios Telegrafos de Angola]] (2%)),
[[Porturil]] (40%), [[Modus Comicare]] (19%), [[Ipang]] (10%), Lambda (6%) |} ==Bahrain== At the end of 2011 the penetration rate was estimated at 133% over a population estimate of 1.27 million.{{cite web |url=http://www.tra.org.bh/en/pdf/2011TelecommunicationsMarketsIndicators-ForPublic.pdf |title=Telecommunications markets indicators January 2012 |accessdate=January 2012}} The telecom regulator in Bahrain is Telecommunications Regulatory Authority of Bahrain [[هيئة تنظيم الاتصالات]] (TRA). {|class="wikitable" |- ! style="width:3%;"| Rank !! style="width:15%;"| Operator !! style="width:30%;"| Technology !! style="width:20%;" | Subscribers
(in millions) !! style="width:32%;"| Ownership |- |align=right| 1 || [[Batelco]] ||| [[GSM]]-900 ([[GPRS]], [[Enhanced Data Rates for GSM Evolution|EDGE]])
2100 MHz [[UMTS]], [[DC-HSPA+]]
1800 MHz [[LTE (telecommunication)|LTE]] || 0.738[http://www.batelcogroup.com/media/23966/fr_g5ej0kdt_batelco_ar_2011_enlo.pdf Batelco Group - Annual report 2011] (Dec 2011) || [[Batelco|Bahrain Telecommunications Company]] |- |align=right| 2 || [[Zain Group|Zain]]
(formerly MTC-Vodafone) ||| [[GSM]]-900/1800 ([[GPRS]], [[Enhanced Data Rates for GSM Evolution|EDGE]])
2100 MHz [[UMTS]], [[HSDPA]]
1800 MHz [[LTE (telecommunication)|LTE]]
[[WiMAX]] || 0.787 (Sep 2014) || [[Zain Group]] (56.25%) |- |align=right| 3 || [[Saudi Telecom Company|Viva]] ||| [[GSM]]-900/1800 ([[GPRS]], [[Enhanced Data Rates for GSM Evolution|EDGE]])
2100 MHz [[UMTS]], [[DC-HSPA+]]
1800 MHz [[LTE (telecommunication)|LTE]] || ''Not Yet Available'' || [[Saudi Telecom Company|STC]] |} ==Benin== In December 2015, the penetration rate was estimated at 90.33%{{cite web |url=http://arcep.bj/admin/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/TABLEAU-DE-BORD-TELEPHONIE-MOBILE-DEC-2015.pdf |title=Benin : Tableau de bord de la telephonie mobile (Dec 2015) |publisher=ARCEP Benin|format=pdf |date=December 2015 |accessdate=25 March 2016}} (in 2014, the population was estimated as 10.33 millions{{cite web |url=http://arcep.bj/admin/wp-content/uploads/2015/05/Annuaire-Statistique-ARCEP-BENIN-2014.pdf |title=Benin : Annuaire statistique 2014 |publisher=ARCEP Benin|format=pdf |date=December 2014 |accessdate=25 March 2016}}). The telecom regulator in Benin is Autorité de Régulation des Communications Electroniques de la Poste (ARCEP). {|class="wikitable" |- ! style="width:3%;"| Rank !! style="width:15%;"| Operator !! style="width:30%;"| Technology !! style="width:20%;" | Subscribers
(in millions) !! style="width:32%;"| Ownership |- |align=right| 1 || [[MTN Group|MTN]] ||| [[GSM]]-900/1800 MHz [[UMTS]], [[DC-HSPA+]] [[LTE (telecommunication)|LTE]] | 4.3 (Dec 2015) || [[Mobile Telephone Networks|MTN]] (75%) |- |align=right| 2 || Moov ||| [[GSM]]-900 MHz
[[UMTS]], [[DC-HSPA+]] [[LTE (telecommunication)|LTE]] | 3.3 (Dec 2015) || [[Etisalat]] |- |align=right| 3 || [[Globacom|Glo]] ||| [[GSM]]-900/1800 MHz || 1.7 (Dec 2015) || [[Globacom]] |- |align=right| 4 || Libercom ||| [[GSM]]-900 MHz || 0.056 (Dec 2015) || [[:fr:Bénin Télécoms SA|Benin Telecom]] |- |align=right| - || [[BBcom]] ||| [[GSM]]-900/1800 MHz || ND{{cite web |url=http://lautrefraternite.com/2016/01/21/gsm-au-benin-loperateur-bbcom-hors-reseau/ |title=GSM au Bénin : L’opérateur BBCOM hors réseau |publisher=L'Autre Fraternité Benin |date=21 January 2016 |accessdate=25 March 2016}} (Dec 2015) || [[Bell Benin Communications]] |} ==Botswana== In March 2015 the penetration rate was 167% over a population estimate of 2.05 millions.{{cite web |url=http://www.bocra.org.bw/telecoms-statistics |title=Botswana : Telecoms Statistics - Market share by number of subscriptions as at March 2015 |publisher=BOCRA |date=March 2015 |accessdate=26 March 2016}} The telecom regulator in Botswana is Botswana Communications Regulatory Authority (BOCRA). {|class="wikitable" |- ! style="width:3%;"| Rank !! style="width:15%;"| Operator !! style="width:30%;"| Technology !! style="width:20%;" | Subscribers
(in millions) !! style="width:32%;"| Ownership |- |align=right| 1 || [[MASCOM|Mascom]] ||| [[GSM]]-900
2100 MHz [[UMTS]], [[HSPA+]] [[LTE (telecommunication)|LTE]] | 1.7 (March 2015) || [[Mascom Wireless (Pty) Limited]], [[Mobile Telephone Networks|MTN]] (53%) |- |align=right| 2 || [[Orange S.A.|Orange]] ||| [[GSM]]-900
2100 MHz [[UMTS]], [[HSDPA]] [[LTE (telecommunication)|LTE]] | 1.1 (March 2015) || [[Orange S.A.]] (69%), Mosokelatsebeng Cellular (local investors, 26%), local individuals (5%) |- |align=right| 3 || [[Botswana Telecommunications Corporation|BeMobile]] ||| [[GSM]]-900/1800
[[UMTS]] || 0.52 (March 2015) || BTC [[Botswana Telecommunications Corporation]] |} ==Burkina Faso== In December 2011 the penetration rate was estimated at 36% over a population estimate of 16.7 million.{{cite web |url=http://www.gsma.com/newsroom/wp-content/uploads/2012/06/africamobileobservatory2011.pdf |title=African Mobile Observatory |accessdate=1 July 2012}} The telecom regulator in Burkina Faso is Autorité de Régulation des Communications Électroniques (ARCE). {|class="wikitable" |- ! style="width:3%;"| Rank !! style="width:15%;"| Operator !! style="width:30%;"| Technology !! style="width:20%;" | Subscribers
(in millions) !! style="width:32%;"| Ownership |- |align=right| 1 || [[Orange S.A.|Orange]] ||| [[GSM]] 900 MHz ([[GPRS]], [[Enhanced Data Rates for GSM Evolution|EDGE]])
2100 MHz [[UMTS]], [[HSPA+]] || 4.1 (2012) || [[Orange S.A.|Orange]]{{cite web|url=http://www.orange.com/en/Press-and-medias/press-releases-2016/Orange-to-acquire-Airtel-s-subsidiaries-in-Burkina-Faso-and-Sierra-Leone |title=Orange and Bharti Airtel International (Netherlands) BV ("Airtel") have signed an agreement leading to Orange’s acquisition of Airtel’s operations in Burkina Faso and Sierra Leone. |publisher=orange.com |date= |accessdate=3 February 2016}} |- |align=right| 2 || Telmob ([[Onatel]]) ||[[CDMA2000]], [[EVDO]]
[[GSM]] 900 MHz ([[GPRS]], [[Enhanced Data Rates for GSM Evolution|EDGE]])
2100 MHz [[UMTS]], [[DC-HSPA+]] || 3.9 {{cite web|url=http://www.ihs.com/products/global-insight/industry-economic-report.aspx?id=1065932366 |title=Maroc Telecom Reports 9.6 Mil. Sub-Saharan African Mobile Subscribers in December 2011 |publisher=Ihs.com |date= |accessdate=13 August 2012}} (2012) || [[Maroc Telecom]] (51%) |- |align=right| 3 || [[Telecel Faso]] ||| [[GSM]]-900 MHz ([[GPRS]], [[EDGE]]) || 2 (2012) || [[Planor Afrique]] |} ==Burundi== In 2011 the penetration rate was estimated at 20% over a population estimate of 8 million.{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/05/23/burundi-telecoms-idUSL5E8GN5MK20120523 |title=Burundi mobile users up 19 pct in 2011 |accessdate=1 July 2012 | work=Reuters |date=23 May 2012}} The telecom regulator in Burundi is Agence de Régulation et de Contrôle des Télécommunications (ARCT). {|class="wikitable" |- ! style="width:3%;"| Rank !! style="width:15%;"| Operator !! style="width:30%;"| Technology !! style="width:20%;" | Subscribers
(in millions) !! style="width:32%;"| Ownership |- |align=right| 1 || [[Econet|Econet Leo]]
||[[CDMA]]
[[GSM]]-900/1800 MHz
2100 MHz [[UMTS]] [[LTE (telecommunication)|LTE]] | 2.6{{cite web|url=http://www.agenceecofin.com/finance/0907-30497-burundi-econet-wireless-becomes-econet-leo-following-buyout-of-u-com-subsidiary-of-vimpelcom |title=Burundi: Econet Wireless becomes Econet Leo, following buyout of U-Com, subsidiary of VimpelCom |publisher=agenceecofin.com |date=9 July 2015 |accessdate=16 August 2015}} (July 2015) || [[Econet Wireless]]

(formerly [[Lacell]]) || [[GSM]]-1800 MHz
[[UMTS]] || ''Not Yet Available'' || Smart Telecom |} ==Cabo Verde== In September 2010 the penetration rate was estimated at 87.5% over a population estimate of 0.5 million.{{cite web |url=http://mnodirectory.com/ame/Cape_Verde.htm |title=Cape Verde Mobile Market (Q1 2008 - Q3 2010) |accessdate=10 November 2011}} The telecom regulator in Cabo Verde is Agência Nacional de Comunicações (ANAC). {|class="wikitable" |- ! style="width:3%;"| Rank !! style="width:15%;"| Operator !! style="width:30%;"| Technology !! style="width:20%;" | Subscribers
(in millions) !! style="width:32%;"| Ownership |- |align=right| 1 || [[CV Móvel]] || [[GSM]]-900/1800 MHz [[UMTS]] || 0.355{{cite web |url=http://www.telecom.pt/NR/rdonlyres/7AEA0B40-DD55-4FCB-9689-77423D1F20B8/1446008/PT_3Q09_E.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-11-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091121212934/http://www.telecom.pt/NR/rdonlyres/7AEA0B40-DD55-4FCB-9689-77423D1F20B8/1446008/PT_3Q09_E.pdf |archivedate=21 November 2009 |df=dmy-all }} (September 2009) || [[Portugal Telecom]] (40%) |- |align=right| 2 || [[T-MAIS]] || [[GSM]]-900/1800 MHz || 0.047{{cite web|url=http://www.artci.ci/index.php/Telephonie-mobile/abonnes-service-mobile.html|title=ABONNÉS - TÉLÉPHONIE MOBILE|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|accessdate=12 Mar 2018}} (Q1 2010) || [[T-Mais]] |} ==Cameroon== In July 2011 the penetration rate was estimated at 43% over a population estimate of 19.7 million.{{cite web |url=http://www.art.cm:81/images/doc/aper%2B%BAu%20%2B%AEvolutif%20%20trimestriel%202011.pdf |title=Cameroun: Informations statistiques sur le marché de la téléphonie (Q1 & Q2 2011) |accessdate=1 July 2012}} The telecom regulator in Cameroon is Agence de Régulation des Télécommunications (ART). {|class="wikitable" |- ! style="width:3%;"| Rank !! style="width:15%;"| Operator !! style="width:30%;"| Technology !! style="width:20%;" | Subscribers
(in millions) !! style="width:32%;"| Ownership |- |align=right| 1 || [[MTN Group|MTN]] || [[GSM]]-MHz 900 [[LTE (telecommunication)|LTE]] | 10.1 {{cite web|url=http://www.agenceecofin.com/operateur/0506-29556-cameroun-l-operateur-vietnamien-nexttel-annonce-2-millions-d-abonnes-en-8-mois-d-activites |title=Cameroun: l’opérateur vietnamien Nexttel annonce 2 millions d’abonnés en 8 mois d’activités |publisher=Agence Ecofin |date=5 June 2015 |accessdate=5 September 2015}} (dec 2014) || [[MTN Group]] (70%) |- |align=right| 2 || [[Orange S.A.|Orange]] || [[GSM]]-900 MHz [[LTE (telecommunication)|LTE]] | 6.2 {{cite web|url=http://www.agenceecofin.com/operateur/0506-29556-cameroun-l-operateur-vietnamien-nexttel-annonce-2-millions-d-abonnes-en-8-mois-d-activites |title=Cameroun: l’opérateur vietnamien Nexttel annonce 2 millions d’abonnés en 8 mois d’activités |publisher=Agence Ecofin |date=5 June 2015 |accessdate=5 September 2015}} (dec 2014) || [[Orange S.A.]] |- |align=right| 3 || [[Viettel Mobile|Nexttel]] || [[GSM]]-900/1800 MHz
[[UMTS]] || 2.0 {{cite web|url=http://www.agenceecofin.com/operateur/0506-29556-cameroun-l-operateur-vietnamien-nexttel-annonce-2-millions-d-abonnes-en-8-mois-d-activites |title=Cameroun: l’opérateur vietnamien Nexttel annonce 2 millions d’abonnés en 8 mois d’activités |publisher=Agence Ecofin |date=5 June 2015 |accessdate=5 September 2015}} (May 2015) || [[Viettel|Viettel Global]], Bestinver Cameroon S.A.R.L |- |align=right| 4 || [[Camtel]] || [[GSM]] || ''new licence in September 2014'' || [[Camtel]] (government) |- |align=right| 5 || [[YooMee]] || [[WiMAX]] || ''Not yet available'' || [[YooMee]] |} ==Central African Republic== In September 2010 the penetration rate was estimated at 17.2% over a population estimate of 4.9 million.{{cite web |url=http://mnodirectory.com/ame/Central_African_Republic.htm |title=Central African Republic Mobile Market (Q1 2008 - Q3 2010) |accessdate=10 November 2011}} The telecom regulator in Central African Republic is Agence de régulation des télécommunications (ART). {|class="wikitable" |- ! style="width:3%;"| Rank !! style="width:15%;"| Operator !! style="width:30%;"| Technology !! style="width:20%;" | Subscribers
(in millions) !! style="width:32%;"| Ownership |- |align=right| 1 || [[Telecel Centrafrique]] ||| [[GSM]]-900 || 0.143{{cite web |url=http://www.orascomtelecom.com/files/financial/2072690534_OTH_Investor_Presentation_2009.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-03-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090704073201/http://www.orascomtelecom.com/files/financial/2072690534_OTH_Investor_Presentation_2009.pdf |archivedate=4 July 2009 |df=dmy-all }} (December 2008) || [[Orascom Telecom]] |- |align=right| 2 || [[Orange S.A.|Orange]] || [[GSM]]-1800 ([[GPRS]])
2100 MHz [[UMTS]], [[HSPA+]] || 0.189{{cite web|url=http://www.artci.ci/index.php/Telephonie-mobile/abonnes-service-mobile.html|title=ABONNÉS - TÉLÉPHONIE MOBILE|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=ARTCI|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=12 March 2018}} (Dec 2009) || [[Orange S.A.]] |- |align=right| 3 || [[NationLink Telecom|Nationlink]] ||| [[GSM]]-900 || 0.158{{cite web|url=http://store.businessmonitor.com/article/290618/ |title=Bintel Close To Launch Of Third African Network |publisher=Store.businessmonitor.com |date= |accessdate=13 August 2012}} (end 2008) || [[Bintel]] |- |align=right| 4 || Moov || [[GSM]] || ''Not Yet Available'' || [[Etisalat]] |} ==Chad== In September 2010 the penetration rate was estimated at 24.3% over a population estimate of 10.7 million.{{cite web |url=http://mnodirectory.com/ame/Chad.htm |title=Chad Mobile Market (Q1 2008 - Q3 2010) |accessdate=10 November 2011}} The telecom regulator in Chad is Office Tchadien de Régulation des Télécommunications (OTRT). {|class="wikitable" |- ! style="width:3%;"| Rank !! style="width:15%;"| Operator !! style="width:30%;"| Technology !! style="width:20%;" | Subscribers
(in millions) !! style="width:32%;"| Ownership |- |align=right| 1 || [[Tigo]] ||| [[GSM]]-900/1800 MHz ([[GPRS]], [[Enhanced Data Rates for GSM Evolution|EDGE]]. 3G HSPA 2100 MHz,4G LTE 10 MHz ) || 1.257http://files.shareholder.com/downloads/MICC/1042867849x0x410578/4d61d055-83f3-4348-9a03-6d4909b1eb39/101019_FINAL.PDF (Oct 2010) || [[Millicom|MIC]] |- |align=right| 2 || [[Airtel Africa|Airtel]] ||| [[GSM]]-900 MHz ([[GPRS]], [[Enhanced Data Rates for GSM Evolution|EDGE]])
2100 MHz [[UMTS]], [[HSDPA]] [[LTE (telecommunication)|LTE]] | 1.199 (June 2009) || [[Bharti Airtel]] |} ==Comoros== In September 2010 the penetration rate was estimated at 20.8% over a population estimate of 0.8 million.{{cite web |url=http://mnodirectory.com/ame/Comores.htm |title=Comores Mobile Market (Q1 2008 - Q3 2010) |accessdate=10 November 2011}} The telecom regulator in Comoros is Autorité Nationale de Régulation des TIC (ANRTIC). {|class="wikitable" |- ! style="width:3%;"| Rank !! style="width:15%;"| Operator !! style="width:30%;"| Technology !! style="width:20%;" | Subscribers
(in millions) !! style="width:32%;"| Ownership |- |align=right| 1 || [[Comores Telecom]] (Comtel) ||| [[GSM]]-900 [[UMTS]], [[High Speed Packet Access|HSPA]], [[HSPA+]] [[LTE (telecommunication)|LTE]] | 0.056 (2007){{cite web|url=http://www.cellular-news.com/story/30687.php |title=Second Mobile Network Licensed in Comoros |publisher=Cellular-news.com |date=22 April 2008 |accessdate=13 August 2012}} || government ([[Societe Nationale des Telecommunications]]) |- |align=right| 2 || Comoro Gulf Holding || [[GSM]] || - || 90% [[Comoro Gulf Holding]], 10% government |} ==Congo== In Q4 2015 the penetration rate was estimated at 95.7%{{cite web |url=http://www.arpce.cg/index.php/fr/abonnes-telephonie-mobile |title=Congo: observatoire de la telephonie mobile |publisher=ARPCE |date= 31 December 2015|accessdate=2 April 2016}} over a population estimate of 4.6 million. The telecom regulator in Congo is Agence de Régulation des postes et des Communications Electroniques (ARPCE). {|class="wikitable" |- ! style="width:3%;"| Rank !! style="width:15%;"| Operator !! style="width:30%;"| Technology !! style="width:20%;" | Subscribers
(in millions) !! style="width:32%;"| Ownership |- |align=right| 1 || [[Mobile Telephone Networks|MTN]] || [[GSM]]-900 MHz
[[UMTS]], [[High Speed Packet Access|HSPA]], [[HSPA+]] [[LTE (telecommunication)|LTE]] | 2.250{{cite web |url=http://www.arpce.cg/index.php/fr/abonnes-telephonie-mobile |title=Congo: observatoire de la telephonie mobile (abonnés) |publisher=ARPCE |date= 31 December 2015|accessdate=2 April 2016}} (Q4 2015) || [[Mobile Telephone Networks|MTN]] |- |align=right| 2 || [[Airtel Africa|Airtel]] ||| [[GSM]]-900 MHz
2100 MHz [[UMTS]], [[HSPA+]] [[LTE (telecommunication)|LTE]] | 1.851{{cite web |url=http://www.arpce.cg/index.php/fr/abonnes-telephonie-mobile |title=Congo: observatoire de la telephonie mobile (abonnés) |publisher=ARPCE |date= 31 December 2015|accessdate=2 April 2016}} (Q4 2015) || [[Bharti Airtel]] (90%) |- |align=right| 3 || [[Azur Congo|Azur]] ||| [[GSM]]-900/1800 MHz || 0.313{{cite web |url=http://www.arpce.cg/index.php/fr/abonnes-telephonie-mobile |title=Congo: observatoire de la telephonie mobile (abonnés) |publisher=ARPCE |date= 31 December 2015|accessdate=2 April 2016}} (Q4 2015) || [[Bintel]] |} ==Côte d'Ivoire== In September 2010 the penetration rate was estimated at 68.5% over a population estimate of 21.5 million.{{cite web |url=http://mnodirectory.com/ame/Cote_d_Ivoire.htm |title=Côte d'Ivoire Mobile Market (Q1 2008 - Q3 2010) |accessdate=10 November 2011}} The telecom regulator in Côte d'Ivoire is Autorité de Régulation des Télécommunications/TIC de Côte d'Ivoire (ARTCI). {|class="wikitable" |- ! style="width:3%;"| Rank !! style="width:15%;"| Operator !! style="width:30%;"| Technology !! style="width:20%;" | Subscribers

[[Image:Grand Palace in Bangkok - Chakri Mahaprasad Hall.jpg|right|thumb|300px|Chakri Mahaprasad Hall at the [[Grand Palace]]]] {{Main article|List of Thai royal residences}} This is a list of [[royal residence]]s in [[Bangkok]].
==Current royal residences in Bangkok== * [[Grand Palace]], – The primary and official residence of the king. * [[Dusit Palace]] (1897–1901) – Commissioned by King Chulalongkorn as an alternative primary residence to the Grand Palace. Apart from Chitralada Villa, now serves mainly as a museum and in certain state functions. ** [[Amphorn Sathan Residential Hall]] (1906) – Currently the residence of King [[Vajiralongkorn]]. ** [[Chitralada Royal Villa]] (1913) – Part of the Dusit Palace (see below), it is the formerly ''de facto'' primary residence of the late King [[Bhumibol Adulyadej]]. Currently the residence of Queen [[Sirikit]]. ** [[Vimanmek Mansion]] – Main residential building of the Dusit Palace complex; now serves as a museum. * [[Sa Pathum Palace]], Bangkok – Currently the residence of Princess Maha Chakri [[Sirindhorn]]. * [[Sukhothai Palace]] (1918) – Currently the residence of Princess [[Bajrakitiyabha]] and Princess [[Sirivannavari Nariratana]]. * Le Dix Palace (1980) – Former residence of the late Princess [[Galyani Vadhana]]. * Ruen Rudee Palace – Former residence of the late Princess [[Bejaratana]].
==Former royal residences in Bangkok== * [[Phra Racha Wang Derm]] (Thonburi Palace) (1768) – Royal palace of King [[Taksin]]; now site of the Royal Thai Navy headquarters. * [[Front Palace]] (Phra Ratchawang Bowon Sathan Mongkhon), Bangkok (1782–85) – Residence of the [[Front Palace|holder of the same title]], who was also known as the ''uparaja'' or "vice king". Its grounds are now the site of the [[Bangkok National Museum]], [[Thammasat University]], [[Bunditpatanasilpa Institute]], the [[National Theatre (Thailand)|National Theatre]] and the [[Office of the Council of State]]. * [[Rear Palace]] (Phra Ratchawang Bowon Sathan Phimuk) (built in the reign of King Rama I) – Residence of the "Rear Palace" or second vice king. It is now the site of [[Siriraj Hospital]]. * Tha Phra Palace (1782) – Served as the residence of Prince Chetsadabodin ([[Rama III]]) and Prince [[Narisara Nuvadtivongs]], among others; now the main campus of [[Silpakorn University]]. * Nantha Utthayan Palace – Built in the reign of King [[Mongkut]], its location is now occupied by the [[Royal Thai Navy]]. * Pathum Wan Palace (later known as Phetchabun Palace) – Built in the reign of King Mongkut as a country residence; later given to Prince [[Chudadhuj Dharadilok]]. Its location is now the site of [[Central World]]. * [[Saranrom Palace]] (construction began 1866) – Served as temporary residence for some princes and as lodging for royal guests. It is now the site of the [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Thailand)|Meseum of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs]] and Saranrom Park. * Buraphaphirom Palace, Bangkok – Rebuilt in 1875 to serve as the residence of Prince [[Bhanurangsi Savangwongse]], the palace has since been demolished, and its former grounds are now a commercial area known as [[Wang Burapha]]. * [[Windsor Palace (Thailand)|Windsor Palace]], Bangkok – Built in the reign of King Chulalongkorn to serve as the residence of Crown Prince [[Vajirunhis]]. The palace became part of Chulalongkorn University after the prince's death; its former location is now the site of the [[National Stadium]]. * [[Bang Khun Phrom Palace]] (1899) – Former residence of Prince [[Paribatra Sukhumbandh]]; now a museum of the [[Bank of Thailand]]. * [[Paruskavan Palace]] (1904–05) – Former residence of [[Chakrabongse Bhuvanath]]; now the headquarters of the [[Metropolitan Police Bureau]] and the [[National Intelligence Agency (Thailand)|National Intelligence Agency]]. * Ladawan Palace (1906) – Former residence of Prince [[Yugala Dighambara]]; now the site of the [[Crown Property Bureau]]. * Thewet Palace – Residence of Prince [[Kitiyakara Voralaksana]] and his descendants. * [[Phaya Thai Palace]] (1909) – Served as country residence of King Chulalongkorn and Queen [[Saovabha Phongsri]], and later King Vajiravudh. Converted to a hotel, then a hospital; now within the grounds of Phramongkutklao [[Phramongkutklao Hospital|Hospital]] and [[Phramongkutklao College of Medicine|College of Medicine]]. * [[Chakrabongse Palace]] (1909–1910) – former residence of Prince Chakrabongse Bhuvanath; now the site of Chakrabongse Villas, a private resort, and the headquarters of Green World Foundation and River Books. * Chan Kasem Palace (1909–11) – Built as the residence of then-Crown Prince [[Vajiravudh]], the prince succeeded his father before the palace's completion. It is now the site of the [[Ministry of Education (Thailand)|Ministry of Education]]. * [[Varadis Palace]] (1911) – Former residence of Prince [[Damrong Rajanubhab]]; now a museum. * Thewawet Palace (1914) – Former residence of Prince [[Devawongse Varopakarn]]; now a museum of the Bank of Thailand. * [[Suan Pakkad Palace]] (1952) – Former residence of Prince [[Chumbhotbongs Paribatra]]; now a museum.
==See also== * [[List of Thai royal residences]]
{{Royal palaces in Thailand}}
[[Category:Royal residences in Bangkok]] [[Category:Lists of buildings and structures in Thailand|Palaces in Bangkok]] [[Category:Lists of palaces]] [[Category:Bangkok-related lists|Palaces]]

page.title: List of postcode districts in the United Kingdom

revision.comment: /* List */Improving links and other minor cleanup tasks
revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=September 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2017}} [[File:British postcode areas and former postal counties.svg|thumb|400px|Postcode areas shown with former postal counties]] This is a list of [[Postcodes in the United Kingdom|postcode districts]] in the United Kingdom and [[Crown dependencies]]. A group of postcode districts with the same alphabetical prefix is called a [[List of postcode areas in the United Kingdom|postcode area]]. All, or part, of one or more postcode districts are grouped into [[post town]]s.{{Cite book |title=Address Management Guide |edition=5th |publisher=Royal Mail Group plc |date=March 2007 |url=http://www.royalmail.com/marketing-services/address-management-unit/address-data-products/address-management-guide |accessdate=25 October 2012}} Until 1996, Royal Mail required counties to be included in addresses, except for 110 of the larger post towns. For these "special post towns", the [[Postal counties of the United Kingdom|former postal county]] is shown in brackets below. Since 1996, counties are not required for any address. The code for a postcode district is also called an "outward code". ==List== {|class="toc" !Postcode areas |- |[[#AB|AB]] [[#AL|AL]] [[#B|B]] [[#BA|BA]] [[#BB|BB]] [[#BD|BD]] ''[[#BF|BF]]'' [[#BH|BH]] [[#BL|BL]] [[#BN|BN]] [[#BR|BR]] [[#BS|BS]] [[#BT|BT]] ''[[#BX|BX]]'' [[#CA|CA]] [[#CB|CB]] [[#CF|CF]] [[#CH|CH]] [[#CM|CM]] [[#CO|CO]] [[#CR|CR]] [[#CT|CT]] [[#CV|CV]] [[#CW|CW]] [[#DA|DA]] [[#DD|DD]] [[#DE|DE]] [[#DG|DG]] [[#DH|DH]] [[#DL|DL]] [[#DN|DN]] [[#DT|DT]] [[#DY|DY]] [[#E|E]] [[#EC|EC]] [[#EH|EH]] [[#EN|EN]] [[#EX|EX]] [[#FK|FK]] [[#FY|FY]] [[#G|G]] [[#GL|GL]] [[#GU|GU]] [[#GY|GY]] [[#HA|HA]] [[#HD|HD]] [[#HG|HG]] [[#HP|HP]] [[#HR|HR]] [[#HS|HS]] [[#HU|HU]] [[#HX|HX]] [[#IG|IG]] [[#IM|IM]] [[#IP|IP]] [[#IV|IV]] [[#JE|JE]] [[#KA|KA]] [[#KT|KT]] [[#KW|KW]] [[#KY|KY]] [[#L|L]] (''[[#GIR|GIR]]'') [[#LA|LA]] [[#LD|LD]] [[#LE|LE]] [[#LL|LL]] [[#LN|LN]] [[#LS|LS]] [[#LU|LU]] [[#M|M]] [[#ME|ME]] [[#MK|MK]] [[#ML|ML]] [[#N|N]] [[#NE|NE]] [[#NG|NG]] [[#NN|NN]] [[#NP|NP]] [[#NR|NR]] [[#NW|NW]] [[#OL|OL]] [[#OX|OX]] [[#PA|PA]] [[#PE|PE]] [[#PH|PH]] [[#PL|PL]] [[#PO|PO]] [[#PR|PR]] [[#RG|RG]] [[#RH|RH]] [[#RM|RM]] [[#S|S]] [[#SA|SA]] [[#SE|SE]] [[#SG|SG]] [[#SK|SK]] [[#SL|SL]] [[#SM|SM]] [[#SN|SN]] [[#SO|SO]] [[#SP|SP]] [[#SR|SR]] [[#SS|SS]] [[#ST|ST]] [[#SW|SW]] [[#SY|SY]] [[#TA|TA]] [[#TD|TD]] [[#TF|TF]] [[#TN|TN]] [[#TQ|TQ]] [[#TR|TR]] [[#TS|TS]] [[#TW|TW]] [[#UB|UB]] [[#W|W]] [[#WA|WA]] [[#WC|WC]] [[#WD|WD]] [[#WF|WF]] [[#WN|WN]] [[#WR|WR]] [[#WS|WS]] [[#WV|WV]] [[#YO|YO]] [[#ZE|ZE]] |} {{-}} {|class="wikitable sortable" !{{nowrap|Postcode area}} !{{nowrap|Postcode districts}} !{{nowrap|[[Post town]]}} !{{nowrap|[[Postal counties of the United Kingdom|Former postal county]]}} |- |{{Anchor|AB}}[[AB postcode area|AB]] |AB10, AB11, AB12, AB15, AB16,
