{{Chinese name|[[Liu]]}} {{infobox Chinese |t=劉安 |s=刘安 |p=Liú Ān |j=Lau4 On1 |y=Làuh Ōn |poj=Lâu An |mc=Ljuw 'An |oc-bs=*mə-ru ʔˤan (or ʔˤar) }} {{Infobox royalty |birth_date=179 BC |death_date=122 BC (aged 57) |father=Liu Chang, Prince Li of Huainan |mother=Lady Yong |reign=164 BC-122 BC |title=[[King of Huainan]] |predecessor=Liu He |issue=Prince Liu Buhai
Prince Liu Qian
Princess [[Liu Ling (Han dynasty)|Liu Ling]] }} '''Liú Ān''' ({{zh|t=劉安}}, c. 179–122 BC) was a [[Han dynasty]] Chinese prince and an advisor to his nephew, [[Emperor Wu of Han]] (武帝). He is best known for editing the (139 BC) ''[[Huainanzi]]'' compendium of [[Daoist]], [[Confucianist]], [[Buddhist]] and [[Legalism (Chinese philosophy)|Legalist]] teachings. Early texts represent Liu An in three ways: the "author-editor of a respected philosophical symposium", the "bumbling rebel who took his life to avoid arrest", and the successful Daoist adept who transformed into a ''[[Xian (Taoism)|xian]]'' and "rose into the air to escape prosecution for trumped-up charges of treason and flew to eternal life."Wallacker, p. 36. == Life == He was the grandson of [[Liu Bang]], the founding emperor of the Han Dynasty. After his father died, he became the [[Prince of Huainan]], the lands south of the [[Huai River]], at the age of 16. Liu An had two sons. The younger was Liu Qian (刘迁), who was born by his princess consort and thus became heir to Huainan, while the elder, [[Liu Buhai]] (刘不害), was born to a concubine. Liu An favoured Liu Qian over Liu Buhai and never viewed the latter as his son. Liu Qian never regarded Liu Buhai as his elder brother. According to Tui'en Ling (推恩令, ''Order to Expand Favours''), Liu Buhai could become a marquess if Liu An carved a part of Huainan for him as his fief, but Liu An never did. Liu Jian (刘建), son of Liu Buhai, having realized that both he and his father had little chance to be a marquess, became so resentful that he accused Liu An and Liu Qian of a [[coup]] attempt. Finally, in a fate similar to his father, Liu An committed [[suicide]] in 122 BC after his plot was revealed. ==Literature== Noted for his literary ability, Liu An was reputed to be able to compose an elaborate work of prose between waking and finishing breakfast. In addition to composing literary pieces himself, Liu An also frequently invited other scholars as guests to his estate. Eight of these scholars in particular became known as the [[Eight Immortals of Huainan]] (淮南八仙). ===''Huainanzi''=== Together with the Eight Immortals of Huainan and/or other members his literary circle, Liu An published a treatise in 139 BC. known as the ''[[Huainanzi]]'', translated as "Book of the Master of Huainan", or the "Huainan Philosophers". This book is considered one of the cornerstones of Taoist philosophy, along with the works of [[Laozi]] and [[Zhuangzi (book)|Zhuangzi]]. Along with the earlier ''ShuJing'' (''[[Classic of History]]'') of the 5th century BC ([[Warring States]] era), this book provided further concrete information on [[History of geography#China|geography]], including descriptions of the [[topography]] of China. His book was also concerned with mathematics and music, making use of the "[[Pythagorean comma]]" and listing the first known [[Shí-èr-lǜ|Chinese 12 tone musical tuning]]. ===''Chu ci''=== One of the two major ancient Chinese poetry collections was the ''[[Chu ci]]'', also known as ''The Songs of the South'' or ''The Songs of Chu'' (the other being the ''[[Shijing]]''). The seminal poem of the collection is the "[[Li Sao]]", generally agreed to be by [[Qu Yuan]]. Liu An wrote an introduction to the "[[Li Sao]]" as well as the first known commentary. There is also reasonable evidence that Liu An was the first editor and anthologist of the original ''Chu ci'' collection. The poem "''Zhao yin shi''" (Summons for a Recluse") is attributed to him and "[[Yuan You]]" ("Far-off Journey") shows many similarities to the work of the literary circle around Liu An.Hawkes, 243 and 191-193 == Legend of inventing soy milk == According to the legend, Liu An developed [[soy milk]] for his old, ill mother. She wanted to taste [[soybeans]] but couldn't chew, so Liu An ground the soybeans into milk, apparently upon her suggestion.{{cite web |url=http://kaleidoscope.cultural-china.com/en/8Kaleidoscope12274.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-07-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160825205454/http://kaleidoscope.cultural-china.com/en/8Kaleidoscope12274.html |archivedate=2016-08-25 |df= }} No historical evidence supports the legend. In the [[Ming Dynasty]] reference work ''[[Bencao Gangmu]]'', author [[Li Shizhen]] describes the development of [[tofu|bean curd]] but does not mention a particular inventor. The attribution of the invention of tofu to Liu An was also made by another [[Ming dynasty]] writer, Li Yi (李翊).戒庵老人漫筆「豆腐起於淮南王劉安之術。」 During the [[Song dynasty]] in the 10th century, [[Zhu Xi]] had already written of the method of Huainan in "Song of Bean Curd" ("豆腐詩").「種豆豆苗稀，力竭心已腐，早知淮南術，安坐獲泉布。」 "Planting soybeans but the harvest was little, the body is tired and the mind is rotted, if the method of Huainan was known earlier (by me), (I) would be able to get a lot with just relaxing and sitting there." It is also mentioned in a book which called bean curd "Lai Ki" in the Han dynasty, and the word appeared in an early Song dynasty writing.《行神研究》引 《綺翁憶梅庵雜記》記豆腐業淮南王劉安云：「 相傳農曆九月十五日，為淮南王劉安誕辰，內地豆腐業者均於本日舉行之公祭，祭畢聚餐。」劉安為西漢人，具辯才，善屬文，好讀書鼓琴，天下方術之士多歸之，在其在發明豆腐時，蜀人名曰「黎祈」，故陸游詩有「洗釜煮黎祈」句，惟何時名為豆腐，則不可考。 Other Chinese sources discredit the Liu An invention theory, however, and state that Liu An lived with a lot of vegetarian monks and the method was taught by them. The Chinese Daoists that he recruited used "alchemical" methods to make both soy milk and bean curd, perhaps as a medicine for eternal life. As the only powerful noble at that time, Liu An could order the (relative) mass-production of such items and spread them around, thus making him famous for soy milk and bean curd.《中國行業神》, 李喬 Still, many place Liu An as the inventor of both bean curd and soy milk.《中國民間神像》, 宋兆麟 A different tradition could be found in 《金華地方風俗志》 and 《中國風俗故事集》, which mention that soy milk and bean curd were made before the Han dynasty. These traditions date soy milk to the [[Warring States period|warring states period]] by the [[Yan (state)|Yan]] general [[Yue Yi]],樂毅因父母年老嚼不動黃豆，樂毅就把黃豆磨成豆漿，把鹽鹵灑進豆漿，結果成了豆腐。又說醫生開了石膏，樂毅把石膏放進豆漿，結果做出的豆腐比放鹽鹵更好。 These two books are rather recent and the quote in it was only a legend told to bean curd makers orally, without written record. == See also == * [[List of geographers]] * [[List of Chinese people]] * [[List of Chinese writers]] *[[Summons for a Recluse]] == References == {{Reflist}} * *[[David Hawkes (Sinologist)|Hawkes, David]], translator and introduction (2011 [1985]). Qu Yuan ''et al.'', ''The Songs of the South: An Ancient Chinese Anthology of Poems by Qu Yuan and Other Poets''. London: Penguin Books. {{ISBN|978-0-14-044375-2}} * Needham, Joseph (1986). ''Science and Civilization in China: Volume 3''. Taipei: Caves Books, Ltd. *Wallacker, Benjamin E. (1972), "Liu an, Second King of Huai-nan (180?-122 B. C.)," ''Journal of the American Oriental Society'' 92.1, pp. 36–51. == External links == * [http://www.goldenelixir.com/taoism/texts_huainan_zi.html The Huainan Zi text of Liu An] * ''[http://www.themontrealreview.com/2009/The-Dao-of-the-Military-Liu-An-Art-of-War.php The Dao of the Military: Liu An's Art of War]'', (Columbia University Press, 2012) * {{Gutenberg author | id=Liu,+An | name=An Liu}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Liu, An}} [[Category:170s BC births]] [[Category:122 BC deaths]] [[Category:Chinese cartographers]] [[Category:Chinese geographers]] [[Category:Chinese scholars]] [[Category:Ancient geographers]] [[Category:Han dynasty imperial princes]] [[Category:Patrons of literature]]

{{unreferenced|date=October 2015}} {{Use mdy dates|date=August 2015}} {{Infobox park | name = Memorial Park (Port of Spain) | photo = Memorial Park Cenotaph Port of Spain.JPG | photo_width = | photo_caption = | type = City park | location = Frederick Street, [[Downtown Port of Spain|Downtown]], [[Port of Spain]], [[Trinidad and Tobago]] | coords = {{coord|10.6635|-61.5096|format=dms|type:landmark_region:TT|display=inline,title}} | area = | created = 1945 | operator = Port of Spain City Corporation | visitation_num = | status = Open year round | publictransit = }}
'''Memorial Park''' is an [[urban park]] in upper [[Downtown Port of Spain|Downtown]], [[Port of Spain]], [[Trinidad and Tobago]]. Memorial Park is a public city park in commemoration of the Trinidadian veterans that served in [[World War I]] and [[World War II]]. It is one of the most visited urban parks in the city.
== Location == Memorial Park is located south of the [[Queens Park Savannah]], west of Charlotte Street, north of Keate Street, and adjacent to the National Academy for the Performing Arts and the [[National Museum and Art Gallery, Trinidad|National Museum and Art Gallery]].
[[Category:Geography of Port of Spain]] [[Category:Parks in Trinidad and Tobago]] [[Category:1945 establishments in Trinidad and Tobago]] [[Category:World War II memorials]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Port of Spain]]

revision.text:
{{Distinguish|Vastitas Borealis}} {{redirect-distinguish|Borealis Basin|Arctic Basin}} {{Infobox feature on Mars |name = Borealis Basin |image = [[File:Mars topography (MOLA dataset) with poles HiRes.jpg|350px]] |caption = The Borealis Basin is the large blue and green region lying north of the equator. Volcanic eruptions on the [[Tharsis]] bulge, the higher elevation region on the left of the image, covered over parts of the basin after its formation. |type = |location = Northern Hemisphere, Mars |coordinates = {{coord|67|N|208|E|globe:mars_type:landmark|display=inline,title}} |coordinates_footnotes= |mean solar time= |length = |width = |diameter = |depth = |area = |dimensions = |peak = |discoverer = |naming = |eponym = }} The '''North Polar Basin''', more commonly known as the '''Borealis Basin,''' is a large [[Depression (geology)|basin]] in the northern hemisphere of [[Mars]] that covers 40% of the planet.<ref name=":5" /><ref name=":3" /> Some scientists have postulated that the basin formed during the [[Impact event|impact]] of a single, large body roughly 2% the mass of Mars, having a diameter of about 1,900 km (1,200 miles).<ref name=":5">{{Cite web|url=https://www.nasa.gov/home/hqnews/2008/jun/HQ_08159_Mars_crater.html|title=NASA - NASA Spacecraft Reveal Largest Crater in Solar System|website=www.nasa.gov|language=en|access-date=2017-04-06}}</ref><ref name=":6" /> However, the basin is not currently recognized as an [[Impact crater|impact basin]] by the [[International Astronomical Union|IAU]]. The basin is one of the flattest areas in the Solar System, and has an [[Ellipse|elliptical]] shape.<ref name=":3" /><ref name=":5" /> [[Chryse Planitia]], the landing site of the [[Viking 1]] lander, is a bay that opens into this basin.
== Large regions within the Borealis Basin <ref name=":3" /><ref>{{Cite journal|date=2016-11-30|title=Vastitas Borealis|url=https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Vastitas_Borealis&oldid=752254313|journal=Wikipedia|language=en}}</ref> == Because the Borealis basin covers 40% of the surface of Mars, and much of the Northern Hemisphere, many currently recognized regions of Mars lie within it: * [[Acidalia Planitia]] * [[Arcadia Planitia]] * [[Planum Boreum]] * [[Utopia Planitia]] * [[Vastitas Borealis]]
== Borealis Impact ==
=== Formation of the Borealis Basin === One possible explanation for the basin's low, flat and relatively crater-free topography is that the basin was formed by a single large impact. Two simulations of a possible impact sketched a profile for the collision: low velocity—{{convert|6|to|10|km|mi|abbr=on}} per second—oblique angle and a diameter of {{convert|1600|-|2700|km|mi|abbr=on}}.<ref name=":6">{{cite journal |title=Mega-impact formation of the Mars hemispheric dichotomy |author=Marinova |journal=[[Nature (journal)|Nature]] |volume=453 |pages=1216–1219 |doi=10.1038/nature07070 |year=2008 |pmid=18580945 |last2=Aharonson |first2=O |last3=Asphaug |first3=E |issue=7199 |bibcode=2008Natur.453.1216M |display-authors=1 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |title=Implications of an impact origin for the Martian hemispheric dichotomy |author=Nimmo |journal=[[Nature (journal)|Nature]] |volume=453 |pages=1220–1223 |doi=10.1038/nature07025 |year=2008 |pmid=18580946 |last2=Hart |first2=SD |last3=Korycansky |first3=DG |last4=Agnor |first4=CB |issue=7199 |bibcode=2008Natur.453.1220N |display-authors=1 }}</ref> Topographical data from ''[[Mars Global Surveyor]]'' are consistent with the models and also suggest that the elliptical crater has axes of length {{convert|10600|km|mi|abbr=on}} and {{convert|8500|km|mi|abbr=on}}, centered on {{Coord|67|N|208|E|globe:Mars}}, though this has been partially obscured by later volcanic eruptions that created the [[Tharsis bulge]] along its rim.<ref name=":3" /> There is evidence for a secondary rim as well.<ref name=":3">{{cite journal|title=The Borealis basin and the origin of the Martian crustal dichotomy|author=Andrews-Hanna|journal=[[Nature (journal)|Nature]]|volume=453|pages=1212–1215|doi=10.1038/nature07011|year=2008|pmid=18580944|last2=Zuber|first2=MT|last3=Banerdt|first3=WB|issue=7199|bibcode = 2008Natur.453.1212A|display-authors=1 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.space.com/scienceastronomy/080625-mars-impact.html|title=Huge Impact Created Mars' Split Personality|accessdate=2008-07-01|publisher=[[Space.com]]}}</ref> This would make the North Polar Basin by far the [[largest impact crater in the Solar System]], approximately four times the diameter of the next largest craters: [[Utopia Planitia]], which is imbedded inside the North Polar Basin, the [[South Pole–Aitken basin]] on the [[Moon]], and [[Hellas Planitia]] on Mars's southern hemisphere.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://newsoffice.mit.edu/2008/solar-systems-biggest-impact-scar-discovered|title=Solar system's biggest impact scar discovered: MIT scientists solve riddle of Mars' two-faced nature|author=Chandler, David|date=2008-06-25|accessdate=2015-01-01|publisher=[[Massachusetts Institute of Technology|MIT]] News|deadurl=no}}</ref>
This impact would have resulted in significant crustal melting and a general increase in the rate of crustal formation for a period of 40 million years following the impact.<ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|last=Ghods|first=Abdolreza|last2=Arkani-Hamed|first2=Jafar|date=2011-09-01|title=Effects of the Borealis impact on the mantle dynamics of Mars|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0031920111001324|journal=Physics of the Earth and Planetary Interiors|volume=188|issue=1–2|pages=37–46|doi=10.1016/j.pepi.2011.06.010|bibcode=2011PEPI..188...37G}}</ref> Such a large impact would have disturbed the [[Mantle (geology)|mantle]], altering the normal [[Convection|convection currents]] and causing upwellings which further increase the amount of melting at the impact site.<ref name=":4" /> Overall, such an event would actually increase the rate of cooling of the Martian interior.<ref name=":4" /> The lack of magnetic anomalies observed in the northern hemisphere could be explained by such an impact, as the shock waves produced might have demagnetized the crust.<ref name=":4" />
=== Potential formation of Phobos and Deimos via Borealis impact === [[File:Phobos deimos diff horizontal.jpg|thumb|The moons of Mars: Phobos and Deimos. Phobos is the larger of the two moons, and is the closest of the two to Mars. Phobos has an average radius of 11 km, while Deimos has an average radius of 6 km.|338x338px]] The [[Phobos (moon)#Origin|origin of Mars' moons]], [[Phobos (moon)|Phobos]] and [[Deimos (moon)|Deimos]] (pictured right), is unknown and remains controversial. One theory is that the moons are captured asteroids.<ref>{{Cite journal|date=2017-03-29|title=Phobos (moon)|url=https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Phobos_(moon)&oldid=772786540|journal=Wikipedia|language=en}}</ref> However, the moons' near circular orbits and low inclination relative to the Martian equator are not in agreement with the capture hypothesis.<ref name=":2" /> The detection of minerals on Phobos similar to those in the Martian [[lithosphere]], and the unusually low density and high porosity of Phobos, such that the moon would not be expected to remain aggregate if dynamically captured, suggest that the moons could have formed via [[Accretion (astrophysics)|accretion]] in Martian orbit, similar to how Earth's [[Moon]] formed.<ref name=":2" />
While estimates of the mass ejected by a large, Borealis-size impact vary, simulations suggest that a body approximately 0.02 Mars masses in size is capable of producing a sizable debris disk in Martian orbit, on the order of 5x10<sup>20</sup> kg, with a significant fraction of the material remaining close to Mars.<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Citron|first=Robert I.|last2=Genda|first2=Hidenori|last3=Ida|first3=Shigeru|date=2015-05-15|title=Formation of Phobos and Deimos via a giant impact|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0019103515000639|journal=Icarus|volume=252|pages=334–338|doi=10.1016/j.icarus.2015.02.011|arxiv=1503.05623|bibcode=2015Icar..252..334C}}</ref><ref name=":6" /> This figure lies within the estimated mass range necessary to form the two moons, as other data suggests that only 1% of the mass of an accretion disk successfully forms moons.<ref name=":2" /> There are several other large impact basins on Mars that could have ejected enough debris to form the moons.<ref name=":2" />
== Ancient tsunamis == [[File:MarsLomonosovCraterWinter.jpg|thumb|Lomonosov crater, the most likely candidate for the impact that produced the tsunami. It is 150 km in diameter, and is a prominent feature of the Borealis basin.]] Analysis of Mars Global Surveyor data found mineral deposits similar to [[terminal moraine]]s on Earth along the southern rim of the northern lowlands. Scientists have developed several theories to explain their presence, including: volcanic activity, glacial activity, and a series of Martian [[tsunami]]s.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Costard|first=Francois|last2=Séjourné|first2=Antoine|last3=Kelfoun|first3=Karim|last4=Clifford|first4=Stephen|last5=Lavigne|first5=Franck|last6=Di Pietro|first6=Ilaria|last7=Bouley|first7=Sylvain|date=2017-01-01|title=Modeling tsunami propagation and the emplacement of thumbprint terrain in an early Mars ocean|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/2016JE005230/abstract|journal=Journal of Geophysical Research: Planets|language=en|pages=2016JE005230|doi=10.1002/2016JE005230|issn=2169-9100|bibcode=2017JGRE..122..633C}}</ref> The arrangement of the deposits resembles deposits observed in recent tsunami events here on [[Earth]], and other features of the deposits are inconsistent with the volcanic and glacial hypotheses.<ref name=":0" /> One recent investigation identified three impact craters in [[Acidalia Planitia]] as being the likely source of the hypothetical tsunamis, with the [[Lomonosov (Martian crater)|Lomonosov crater]] (pictured right) being the most likely candidate.<ref name=":0" /> Here, the tsunami generated by the impactor would have reached heights of 75 m (250 ft), and traveled 150 km (90 mi) past the southern rim.<ref name=":0" /> Dating techniques put the origin of the deposits sometime between the Late [[Hesperian]] and Early [[Amazonian (Mars)|Amazonian]] periods, some 3 billion years ago, providing evidence to the presence of an [[Mars ocean hypothesis|ocean]] during this period.<ref name=":0" />
==See also== * [[Mars Ocean Hypothesis]] (Oceanus Borealis) * [[Arctic Basin]] (Earth's "North Polar Basin") * [[Planum Boreum]] * [[Utopia Planitia]] * [[Vastitas Borealis]]
==References== * Martel, L.M.V. (June, 2001), [http://www.psrd.hawaii.edu/June01/MarsChryse.html "Outflow Channels May Make a Case for a Bygone Ocean on Mars"], ''Planetary Science Research Discoveries''. (retrieved 17 August 2005) {{Reflist}}
{{Geography of Mars}} {{portal bar|Mars}}
[[Category:Surface features of Mars]]

revision.text:
'''Russian Classification of Territories of Municipal Formations'''<ref name="self">The English name of the document is given per the English title included on the document's first page.</ref> ({{lang-ru|Общероссийский классификатор территорий муниципальных образований}}), or '''OKTMO''' ({{lang-ru|ОКТМО}}), is one of several [[Russia]]n national registers. OKTMO's purpose is organization of information about structure of the [[municipal divisions of Russia]].
The document assigns numeric codes to each municipal division of the country.
OKTMO is used for statistical and tax purposes. It was adopted on December 14, 2005. It went into effect on January 1, 2014, replacing OKATO (''Russian Classification on Objects of Administrative Division'').
==See also== *[[OKATO]], Russian Classification on Objects of Administrative Division
==Notes== {{Reflist}}
==External links== {{Wikidata property|P764}} *[http://www.gks.ru/metod/classifiers.html OKTMO] on [[Russian Federal State Statistics Service]] site
[[Category:Subdivisions of Russia]] [[Category:Geocodes]] [[Category:Municipal divisions of Russia]]

revision.text:
An '''opisometer''', also called a '''curvimeter''', '''meilograph''', or '''map measurer''', is an instrument for [[measurement|measuring]] the [[length]]s of arbitrary curved lines.
[[File:Kurvimeter 1 fcm.jpg|thumbnail|An opisometer]]
A simple opisometer consists of a toothed wheel of known [[circumference]] on a handle. The wheel is placed in contact with the curved line to be measured and run along its length. By counting the number of teeth passing a mark on the handle while this is done, the length of the line can be ascertained:
:line length = wheel circumference × teeth counted/teeth on wheel. <!--If TeX must be used, one should write \mathrm{line}\ \mathrm{length}, etc. :<math>line length = wheel diameter \times teeth counted / teeth on wheel</math> -->
In more sophisticated models, sometimes called a '''chartometer''', the wheel is connected via gearing to a rotary dial from which the line length can be directly read.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=ThXH7xmUskIC&pg=PA83&dq=opisometer&hl=en&sa=X&ei=HmnGT-WrI6f80QXE_KzTBQ&ved=0CFUQ6AEwBjgK#v=onepage&q=opisometer&f=false Gerard L'Estrange Turner, ''Scientific Instruments, 1500-1900: An Introduction'', Philip Wilson Publishers 1998, ISBN 0-85667-491-5 (p.83)] </ref>
The instrument is most commonly used to measure the lengths of roads, rivers and other line features on [[map]]s. Opisometers designed for this purpose provide scales reading the measured distance in kilometers and miles.
Early versions of this instrument were [[patent]]ed in 1873 by the English engineer Edward Russell Morris.<ref>[http://www.london-gazette.co.uk/issues/24044/pages/5837/page.pdf THE LONDON GAZETTE, DECEMBER 12, 1873]</ref> The instruments he produced were initially described as a ''Patent Chartometer'' although later versions were sold under the curious name of ''Wealemefna''.<ref>[http://www.mathsinstruments.me.uk/page71.html Mathematical Instruments: Map Measurers]</ref> Writing in 1881, Morris described how he had created a wholly original name in an attempt to outwit his imitators; he also refused to disclose the origin of the word.<ref>English Mechanic and World of Science: Vol. 33, London, 1881</ref>
==References== <references />
{{commonscat-inline|Opisometers}} {{wiktionary-inline}}
[[Category:Length, distance, or range measuring devices]] [[Category:Cartography]] [[Category:Navigational equipment]] [[Category:Measuring instruments]]

revision.text:
[[File:Cosmeticsrazorback.jpg|thumb|This [[cosmetics]] store has over twice the recommended lighting levels.<ref>Peter Tregenza and David Loe, ''The Design of Lighting'', Routledge, New York (1996)</ref>]]
'''Over illumination''' is the presence of [[illuminance|lighting intensity]] higher than that which is appropriate for a specific activity. Over illumination was commonly ignored between 1950 and 1995, especially in office and [[retail]] environments.<ref name="Simpson">M.D. Simpson, ''A flexible approach to lighting design'', Proc. CIBSE National Lighting Conference, Cambridge, 8–11 April 1990, 182-189, Chartered Institution of Building Services Engineers</ref> Since then, however, the [[interior design]] community has begun to reconsider this practice. Over illumination encompasses two separate concerns: * Unnecessary electric lighting is expensive and energy-intensive. Lighting accounts for approximately 9% of residential electricity use {{as of|2001|lc=y}}<ref name="DOE">Department of Energy, http://www.eia.doe.gov/emeu/recs/recs2001/enduse2001/enduse2001.html</ref> and about 40% of commercial electricity use.<ref name=EIA>Lighting in Commercial Buildings, http://www.eia.doe.gov/emeu/cbecs/cbecs2003/lighting/lighting1.html</ref> * Excessive levels of artificial light may adversely affect health. These detrimental effects may depend on the spectrum as well as the overall brightness level of light.
Over illumination can be reduced by installing [[occupancy sensor]]s, using [[daylight|natural sunlight]] whenever possible, turning off lights when leaving a room, or changing the type of lightbulb. Over illumination does not refer to [[Photokeratitis|snowblindness]], where high exposure to [[ultraviolet light]] causes physical damage to the eye. Too little light, the opposite of over illumination, is associated with [[seasonal affective disorder]].
==Causes== [[File:Bigboxrazorback.jpg|thumb|Some big-box retail stores are over illuminated.]] [[File:Montecitorazorback.jpg|thumb|A [[Physical fitness|fitness]] club that is illuminated mostly by natural light]]
Over illumination can be caused by several factors: * Illuminating an unoccupied area * Using electrical lights instead of natural light * Providing lighting for an occupied area, but with too much intensity * Installing too few electrical controls. This results in an area that must either be over illuminated or not illuminated at all
In addition, there are ancillary reasons why over illumination might be decided to be necessary. For example, retail stores with large windows will sometimes stay illuminated overnight as a method of crime prevention.
While some aspects of illumination are readily controllable, such as turning off lights when exiting a room, others are determined by the architecture and construction of the building. For example, [[skylight (window)|skylight]]s decrease the amount of artificial lighting that is required during the daytime, but most buildings do not have them installed. In addition, too few light switches can also cause issues. If an office building with large windows only has one switch per floor, then electric lights will illuminate the perimeter areas (with abundant natural light) to same level as the interior zones (which receive less sunlight).
==Health effects== [[File:FluorescentT8razorback.jpg|thumb|Common T8 [[fluorescent lighting]] fixture frequently used in office environments]]
Over illumination has been linked to various negative health effects. While some effects might happen because the [[Compact fluorescent lamp#Comparison with incandescent lamps|color spectrum of fluorescent lighting]] is significantly different from [[Color temperature#Categorizing different lighting|sunlight]],<ref name="Cambridge" /><ref name="Lumina">Lumina Technologies, Santa Rosa, Ca., ''Survey of 156 California commercial buildings energy use'', August, 1996</ref><ref name="Boyce">Peter Boyce and Boyce R Boyce, ''Human Factors in Lighting'', 2nd ed., Taylor & Francis, London (2003) {{ISBN|0-7484-0950-5}}</ref>{{Full citation needed|date=August 2016}}{{Request quotation|date=August 2016}} other symptoms might be caused by light that is simply too intense. In particular, over illumination has been linked to [[headache]]s, [[Fatigue (medical)|fatigue]], [[stress (medicine)|medically defined stress]], anxiety, and decreases in [[Human sexuality|sexual]] function.<ref name="Cambridge">''Cambridge Handbook of Psychology, Health and Medicine'', edited by Andrew Baum, Robert West, John Weinman, Stanton Newman, Chris McManus, Cambridge University Press (1997) {{ISBN|0-521-43686-9}}</ref><ref name="Burks">Susan L. Burks, ''Managing your Migraine'', Humana Press, New Jersey (1994) {{ISBN|0-89603-277-9}}</ref><ref name="Pijnenburg">L. Pijnenburg, M. Camps and G. Jongmans-Liedekerken, ''Looking closer at assimilation lighting'', Venlo, GGD, Noord-Limburg (1991)</ref><ref name="Knez">Igor Knez, ''Effects of colour of light on nonvisual psychological processes'', Journal of Environmental Psychology, Volume 21, Issue 2, June 2001, Pages 201-208</ref>
Some studies attribute migraine headaches to overly intense light,<ref name="Burks" /> while others linked it with certain spectral distributions.<ref name="Boyce" /> In one survey bright light was the number two trigger (affecting 47% of respondents) for causing a migraine episode.<ref name="Burks" />
Fatigue is another common complaint from individuals exposed to over illumination, especially with fluorescent media.<ref name="Cambridge" />
Likewise, over illumination can also cause stress and anxiety. In fact, natural light was preferred over purely artificial light by office workers from both eastern and western cultures.<ref name="Nagy">E. Nagy, Sachiko Yasunaga and Satoshi Kose, ''Japanese office employees' psychological reactions to their underground and above-ground offices'', Building Research Institute, Ministry of Construction, 1 Tatehara, Tsukuba-shi, Ibaraki-ken 305, Japan, Revised 13 April 1995. Available online 20 May 2004.</ref> In addition, over illumination can cause [[stress (medicine)|medical stress]]<ref name="Pijnenburg" /><ref name="Basso">M.R Basso Jr., ''Neurobiological relationships between ambient lighting and the startle response to acoustic stress in humans'', Int J Neurosci. 2001;110(3-4):147-57,</ref> and even aggravate other psychological disorders like [[agoraphobia]].<ref>J. Hazell and A.J. Wilkins, ''A contribution of fluorescent lighting to agoraphobia'', . Psychol Med. 1990 Aug;20(3):591-6</ref> The replacement of natural light with artificial light also decreases task performance under certain conditions.<ref name="Knez" />
===Circulatory and circadian rhythm effects=== [[Hypertension]] effects of over illumination can lead to aggravation of [[cardiovascular disease]] and [[erectile dysfunction]], which impacts are outcomes of long term cumulative exposure and associated systematic increases in blood pressure. The mechanism of this effect seems to be stress by related [[upregulation]] of [[Epinephrine|adrenaline]] production akin to the [[fight-or-flight response]].<ref>Narisada Kohei and Duco Schreude, ''Light Pollution Handbook'', Springer, Netherlands (2004) {{ISBN|1-4020-2665-X}}</ref><ref>''Biological Effects of Power Frequency Electric and Magnetic Fields'', Office of Technology Assessment, U.S. Congress, University Press of the Pacific (2002) {{ISBN|0-89875-974-9}}</ref>
[[Circadian rhythm]] disruption is primarily caused by the wrong timing of light in reference to the circadian phase. It can also be affected by too much light, too little light, or incorrect spectral composition of light. This effect is driven by stimulus (or lack of stimulus) to photosensitive ganglion cells in the retina. The "time of day", the circadian phase, is signalled to the [[pineal gland]], the body’s [[photometer]], by the [[suprachiasmatic nucleus]]. Bright light in the evening or in the early morning shifts the phase of the production of [[melatonin]] (see [[phase response curve]]). An out-of-sync melatonin rhythm can worsen [[cardiac arrhythmia]]s and increase [[Redox|oxidized]] [[lipid]]s in the [[Ischemia|ischemic]] [[heart]]. Melatonin also reduces [[superoxide]] production and myeloperoxide (an [[enzyme]] in neutrophils which produces [[hypochlorous acid]]) during ischemia-reperfusion.<ref name="Boyce" /><ref name="Reiter">R.J. Reiter, Cardiovascular Research; 58:10-19 (2003)</ref>
==Energy and economic considerations== Using too much lighting will lead to higher electricity consumption, and therefore higher electricity costs, for the owner of the building. The solution to this issue is multi-faceted because there are several causes of too much light.
===High-intensity light=== First, over illumination occurs when the intensity of lighting is too high for a given activity. For example, an office building might have many sets of fluorescent lights to keep the area illuminated after sundown. During the daytime, however, large windows might allow for abundant amounts of natural sunlight to enter the office. Therefore, keeping all of the fluorescent lights illuminated during the daytime might cause unnecessary costs and energy consumption.
===Leaving lights turned on=== Likewise, not switching off the lights when exiting a room will also cause higher energy consumption. Some people avoid frequently turning off CFL bulbs because they think that doing so will cause them to burn out prematurely. While this is true to a certain extent,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www1.eere.energy.gov/femp/pdfs/29267-5.4.3.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-07-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110511132153/http://www1.eere.energy.gov/femp/pdfs/29267-5.4.3.pdf |archivedate=2011-05-11 |df= }}</ref> the US Department of Energy recommends that 15 minutes is an appropriate time frame. If someone plans to leave the room for less than 15 minutes, then the light should be left on. If the room will be unoccupied for more than 15 minutes, then the light should be switched off.<ref name="energy.gov">http://energy.gov/energysaver/articles/when-turn-your-lights</ref> Another concern is that turning on a fluorescent bulb consumes large amounts of energy. While fluorescent bulbs do need more energy turn on, the amount of electricity consumed is equal to only a few seconds of normal operation.<ref name="energy.gov" /><ref>''A Consumers Guide to Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy'', [[U.S. Department of Energy]], Washington DC (2006)</ref><ref name=NYT>{{cite news|work=New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/09/04/science/04qna.html?ex=1346558400&en=fb20488ad5a46f3c&ei=5124&partner=permalink&exprod=permalink|date=2007-09-04|accessdate=2008-05-06|first=C. Claiborne|last=Ray|title=Lights Off!}}</ref>
Sometimes people do not turn off lights for other reasons, such as an office worker whose company actually pays for the electricity. In these cases [[building automation]] provides more control. These solutions provide centralized control of all lighting within a home or commercial building, allowing easy implementation of scheduling, [[occupancy sensor|occupancy control]], daylight harvesting and more. Many systems also support [[demand response]] and will automatically dim or turn off lights to take advantage of DR incentives and cost savings. Many newer control systems are using wireless mesh open standards (such as [[ZigBee]]), which provides benefits including easier installation (no need to run control wires) and interoperability with other standards-based building control systems (e.g. security).<ref>{{cite web|title=Lighting control saves money and makes sense|url=http://www.daintree.net/downloads/whitepapers/smart-lighting.pdf|publisher=[[Daintree Networks]]|format=PDF}}</ref>
===Architectural design and the type of light bulbs=== Architectural design can also provide ways of reducing energy usage. There are technological aspects of [[window]] design where window angles can be calculated to minimize interior glare and reduce interior over illumination, while at the same time reducing solar heat loading and subsequent demand for air conditioning as energy conservation techniques. For the [[Dakin Building]] in [[Brisbane, California]] the angled window projections effectively provide permanent sunscreens, obviating interior blinds or shades.
Ideally, the design of a building would create multiple switches for the overhead lighting. Adjusting these settings would allow the optimal light intensity to be delivered,<ref name="Simpson" /> the most common version of this control being the "three-level switch", also called A/B switching. Much of the benefit of the excess illumination reduction comes from a better ratio of natural light to fluorescent light that can result from any of the above changes. Research has been conducted showing worker productivity gains in settings where each worker selects his or her own lighting level.<ref>H. Juslen, M. Wouters M and A. Tenner, ''The influence of controllable task-lighting on productivity: a field study in a factory'', Appl Ergon., Mar 7; 2006</ref>
Lastly, the type of light bulbs that are installed has a significant effect on energy consumption. The efficiency of light sources vary greatly. Fluorescent lights produce several times as much light, for given power input, as incandescent lights do, and LEDs are continuing to improve beyond that. Shades vary in their absorption. Light colored ceilings, walls and other surfaces increase ambient light by reflecting.
==See also== * [[Christmas lights]] * [[Daylight harvesting]] * [[Energy conservation]] * [[Flicker fusion threshold]] * [[Hypertension]] * [[Light pollution]] * [[Light sensitivity]] * [[Seasonal affective disorder]] * [[World energy resources and consumption]] * [[Visual comfort probability]]
==References== {{Reflist|35em}}
==External links== * [http://www.labour.gov.hk/eng/public/oh/OHB50.pdf Government of Hong Kong Health Effects of Lighting in the Workplace]
[[Category:Environmental science]] [[Category:Light pollution]] [[Category:Lighting]] [[Category:Low-energy building]]

{{refimprove|date=June 2017}}
[[Image:Pikyry 2.png|thumb|350px|right|Camino interno del refugio]] '''Pikyry''' is a [[biological reserve]] in the [[Alto Paraná Department]] of [[Paraguay]], on the right bank of the [[Paraná river]], and is one of the sites earmarked as 8 ecological reserve by the [[Itaipu dam]], the largest dam in production in the world, located between Paraguay and Brazil. Located in a natural bay, Pikyry is formed by the stream and its confluence with the river Paraná, and has an area of 1,110 hectares
==Geography and climate== The topography of the area is flat, inclining slightly downward towards the reservoir, artificially created for the Itaipu power plant in 1982. The soils are predominantly [[latosole]]s clay. The levels of organic matter are generally high as a result of the prevailing vegetation, and is slightly acidic. There are also - though very few - hydromorphic soils belonging to the group of [[gley soil|gley]] - and humic [[planosole]]s.
It is part of an area inside the Gaza Protection Reservoir in which preliminary studies have demonstrated the need for the area to be integrated into the program since it possesses unique characteristics. Conservation is very important to preserve the area from [[Refugio Mbaracayú|Mbaracayu Biological Reserve]] until [[Tatí Yupí Refuge]].
The climate is subtropical, with abundant and well distributed rainfall, ranging from 1,500 to 1,700 millimeters per year. The average annual temperature is 21 to 22 °C, having a marked difference in daytime and nighttime temperature in winter. The relative humidity is 70 to 80% and the prevailing winds are the northeast and southeast, encouraging and pleasant conditions of the place.
==Animals and plants== [[Image:Pikyry 4.png|thumb|200px|right|Costa lindante con el lago]] The vegetation, dominated by species such as ''[[Tabebuia]]'', ''[[Cedrela fissilis]]'', ''[[Patagonula American]]'' among others. Besides abundant species [[Lauraceae]] and [[undergrowth]] populated with species like [[Piperaceae]], [[Bromeliaceae]], [[Rubiaceae]] [[pteridophytes]], [[Poaceae]] among others. There exists, 300 metres within the preserve's border, a variety of [[Arecaceae]], ''[[Trithrinax brasiliensis]]'', the only recorded example in this part of Paraguay.
There are several species of mammals, birds and reptiles for example: capybara (''[[Hydrochaeris hydrochaeris]]''), monkey (''[[Cebus apella]]''), kuatí ('' [[Nasua nasua]]''), among others.
==Area subdivision == The biological reserve of Pikyry is divided into distinct zones in order to handle them properly. [[Image:Pikyry 3.png|thumb|350px|right|Picada dentro del refugio]] *''Areas of special use'': areas essential for the administration, office accommodation, restaurant, aviation runway, and so on *''Zones extensive use'': areas which visitors access for education and recreation *''Zones intensive'': areas with outstanding scenery which can support large numbers of visitors and recreational activities (camping areas, visitors' centers and scenic lookouts) *''Buffer Zones and Recovery'': areas that have been severely damaged, largely on the border of the preserve near heavily populated areas *''Zone Core'': natural areas that have received the minimum of disruption caused by man (with three distinct nuclei and characteristic of the place)
The reserve has a panoramic viewpoint, which can be seen most of the wooded area, as well as the vast body of water formed by the dam. The combined resources of vegetation, water and topography give it inestimable value.
== References == * Che Retá Paraguay
==External links== * [http://www.itaipu.gov.py Itaipu Binacional - Spanish] * [http://www.itaipu.gov.br Itaipu Binacional - Portuguese]
{{coord missing|Paraguay}}

[[File:Rano-Kau-Crater-Gap-2013.jpg|250px|thumb|[[Rano Kau]], [[Rapa Nui National Park|Parque National Rapa Nui]], [[Easter Island]]]] [[File:Paine.jpg|thumb|250px|Torres del Paine National Park]]
The '''protected areas of Chile''' are areas that have natural beauty or significant historical value protected by the government of [[Chile]]. These protected areas cover over {{convert|140000|sqkm|0|abbr=on}}, which is 19% of the territory of Chile. The National System of Protected Wild Areas (SNASPE by its Spanish acronym) is regulated by law #18,362 passed in 1984, and administered by the [[Corporación Nacional Forestal|National Forest Corporation]] (CONAF).
There are three types of territories: * [[List of national parks of Chile|National Parks]] * [[National Reserves]] * [[Natural Monument]]s
==Protected areas by type==
===National parks=== {{Main|List of national parks of Chile}}
===National reserves=== {| class="wikitable collapsible autocollapse sortable" ! National reserves of Chile |- !Name !class="unsortable"|Photo ![[Natural regions of Chile|Natural region]] !Area !Established |- | [[Altos de Lircay National Reserve|Altos de Lircay]] | [[Image:Vilchesw.jpg|175px]] | [[Zona Central, Chile|Zona Central]] | | 1996 |- | [[Isla Mocha National Reserve|Isla Mocha]] | [[Image:Isla Mocha 1.jpg|175px]] | [[Zona Sur]] | {{sort|{{commas|12200}}|{{convert|23.69|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}}}} | 1988 |- | [[Lago Peñuelas National Reserve|Lago Peñuelas]] | [[Image:Cielo (300968795).jpg|175px]] | [[Zona Central, Chile|Zona Central]] | {{sort|{{commas|12200}}|{{convert|92.6|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}}}} | 1952 |- | [[Llanquihue National Reserve|Llanquihue]] | [[Image:Reserva Nacional Llanquihue - Chile - Alerce Gigante.jpg|175px]] | [[Zona Sur]] | {{sort|{{commas|12200}}|{{convert|161.1|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}}}} | 1912 |- | [[Los Flamencos National Reserve|Los Flamencos]] | [[Image:LagunaCerroMiscanti.jpg|175px]] | [[Norte Grande]] | {{sort|{{commas|12200}}|{{convert|740.0|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}}}} | 1990 |- | [[Malalcahuello-Nalcas]] | [[Image:Lonquimay Volcano.jpg|175px]] | [[Zona Sur]] | {{sort|{{commas|12200}}|{{convert|12789|ha|sqmi|0|abbr=on}}}} | 1931 |- | [[Mocho-Choshuenco National Reserve|Mocho-Choshuenco]] | [[Image:CerroChoshuenco.jpg|175px]] | [[Zona Sur]] | {{sort|{{commas|12200}}|{{convert|7537.6|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}}}} | 1994 |- | [[Pampa del Tamarugal National Reserve|Pampa del Tamarugal]] | [[image:Pintados2.jpg|175px]] | [[Norte Grande]] | {{sort|{{commas|12200}}|{{convert|102264|ha|sqmi|0|abbr=on}}}} | 1987 |- | [[Pingüino de Humboldt National Reserve|Pingüino de Humboldt]] | [[image:Pinguinos-Humboldt Isla Choros Chile.JPG|175px]] | [[Norte Chico, Chile|Norte Chico]] | {{sort|{{commas|12200}}|{{convert|859.3|ha|sqmi|0|abbr=on}}}} | 1990 |- | [[Ralco National Reserve|Ralco]] | [[image:Volcan Callaqui y Laguna El Barco.jpg|175px]] | [[Zona Central, Chile|Zona Central]] | {{sort|{{commas|12200}}|{{convert|12421|ha|sqmi|0|abbr=on}}}} | 1987 |- | [[Río de Los Cipreses National Reserve|Río de Los Cipreses]] | [[image:Reserva Rio Cipreses Hualo.jpg|175px]] | [[Zona Central, Chile|Zona Central]] | {{sort|{{commas|12200}}|{{convert|36882|ha|sqmi|0|abbr=on}}}} | 1985 |- | [[Valdivian Coastal Reserve|Costera Valdiviana]] | [[image:Laguna Colun.JPG|175px]] | [[Zona Sur]] | {{sort|{{commas|12200}}|{{convert|597|ha|sqmi|0|abbr=on}}}} | 2005 |}
===Natural monuments=== {| class="wikitable collapsible autocollapse sortable" ! Natural monuments of Chile |- !Name !class="unsortable"|Photo ![[Natural regions of Chile|Natural region]] !Area !Established |- | [[Cerro Ñielol Natural Monument|Cerro Ñielol]] | [[Image:Temuco, Chile, viewed from the Cerro Ñielol Natural Monument - 200609.jpg|175px]] | [[Zona Sur]] | {{sort|{{commas|12200}}|{{convert|0.89|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}}}} | 1988 |- | [[Cueva del Milodón Natural Monument|Cueva del Milodón]] | [[Image:Milodon cave.JPG|175px]] | [[Zona Austral]] | | 1993 |- | [[El Morado Natural Monument|El Morado]] | [[Image:San Francisco Glacier - Summer.JPG|175px]] | [[Zona Central, Chile|Zona Central]] | {{sort|{{commas|12200}}|{{convert|30.09|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}}}} | |- | [[La Portada Natural Monument|La Portada]] | [[image:MonumentoNaturalLaPortada.jpg|175px]] | [[Norte Grande]] | {{sort|{{commas|12200}}|{{convert|0.3127|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}}}} | 1990 |- | [[Los Pingüinos Natural Monument|Los Pingüinos]] | [[image:Islamagdalena.jpg|175px]] | [[Zona Austral]] | {{sort|{{commas|12200}}|{{convert|0.97|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}}}} | 1966 |}
==Protected areas by region==

{{Infobox river | name = Rakovički Creek | name_native = Раковички поток / ''Rakovički potok'' | image = | image_caption = | source1_location = [[Torlak (Belgrade)|Torlak]] Hill, [[Kumodraž]]-[[Belgrade]] | mouth_location = [[Topčiderka]], at [[Kneževac]]-[[Belgrade]] | mouth_coordinates = {{coord|44|44|17|N|20|26|06|E|source:kolossus-frwiki|display=it}} | progression = [[Topčiderka]]→ {{PSava}} | subdivision_type1 = Country | subdivision_name1 = {{flag|Serbia}} | length = approx. {{convert|8.5|km|abbr=on}} | source1_elevation = | discharge1_avg = | basin_size = }}
The '''Rakovički Creek''' ({{lang-sr|Раковички поток}} / ''Rakovički potok'', "Rakovica Creek") is a short stream in north-central [[Serbia]], an 8,5 kilometer-long right tributuary to the [[Topčiderka]] river. During its entire flow it runs through the southern outskirts of the urban section of [[Belgrade]]. It is one of the 40 rivers, streams and creeks that flow or used to flow through Belgrade, but as the majority of them is completely or partially conducted underground into the city sewage system, Rakovički potok avoided such faith. Even though it is short, the creek flows through a number of Belgrade's neighborhoods and gave its name to two urban neighborhoods of Belgrade, one municipality and a monastery.
== Course ==
The creek originates from the northern slopes of the Torlak hill, in the south-eastern part of the Belgrade's urban neighborhood of [[Kumodraž]] in the [[Voždovac]] municipality. It flows to the south, along the eastern side of the Torlak, passing between the neighborhoods of [[Jajinci]] and [[Selo Rakovica]]. In the ''Pašinac'' field it receives the ''Milošev potok'' from the left, turns north-west and enters the municipality of Rakovica. It flows next to the northern section of the neighborhood of [[Resnik, Belgrade|Resnik]], several smaller, new neighborhoods ([[Jelezovac]], [[Sunčani Breg]], [[Straževica]]) and the monastery of Rakovica, curving along the eastern and northern slopes of the 209 meter-high hill of Straževica. At the neighborhood of [[Kneževac]], Rakovički potok receives the creek of ''Zmajevac'' and for the last 300 meters has been conducted underground, below the industrial complex of the "21 Maj" factory, emptying into the Topčiderka.
== Characteristics ==
The creek got its name from the [[crayfish]] ("Crayfish creek"; Serbian: ''rak'', ''rakovica'') which used to live in the creek in the Middle Ages. In turn, the creek gave its name to the Belgrade's modern municipality of Rakovica, the neighborhoods of Rakovica (in the same municipality) and Selo Rakovica (in the municipality of Voždovac) and the monastery of Rakovica.
The central valley of the creek is a natural route for the eastern part of the ''Kružni put'', the main road connecting the southern outskirts of Belgrade and the projected route of the future [[Belgrade beltway]]. Belgrade-[[Požarevac]] railway also passes through the valley, parallel to the road. The area near the creek's mouth (Kneževac-Rakovica) is one of major industrial zones in Belgrade.
In May 1999, during the [[NATO bombing of Serbia]], the [[electrical substation]] in Rakovica was hit and 80 tons of [[heating oil]] partially burned polluting the air, but a significant amount leaked into the Rakovički potok polluting Topčiderka and [[Sava]] rivers downstream.<ref>[http://www.yurope.com/kosovo/arhiva/kosovo-7/0021.html Damages in the 1999 NATO bombing of Serbia].</ref>
== References ==
{{reflist}}
== Bibliography ==
* ''Beograd — plan grada''; M@gic M@p, 2006. {{ISBN|86-83501-53-1}}.
{{DEFAULTSORT:Rakovicki}} [[Category:Sava basin|2Rakovički potok]] [[Category:Rivers of Serbia]] [[Category:Geography of Belgrade]] [[Category:Šumadija]]

{{Madagascar-stub}} '''Sakoa''' is a region of southwestern [[Madagascar]] characterised by [[Madagascar spiny thickets|dry spiny forest]] and known particularly for its [[coal field]]s, the highest quality of which is the Sakoa field. There are a number of license holders on the field. The vast majority of licenses of commercial value are held by Madagascar Consolidated Mining, a subsidiary of [[Red Island Minerals]], founded by Sam Malin, which is appraising and developing the resources of the field. Pan African Mining holds a considerable number of licenses on the periphery of the field. Other coal fields adjacent to the Sakoa region include the Ianapera, Imaloto, [[Sakamena]] and Vohibory fields.
== Sources ==
[http://www.panda.org/about_wwf/what_we_do/freshwater/our_solutions/wetland_services/projects/index.cfm?uProjectID=MG0088 WWF Dry Forest Programme]
==References== * David Hilling, ''Alternative Energy Sources for Africa: Potential and Prospects'', African Affairs, Vol. 75, No. 300 (Jul., 1976), pp. 359-371 [https://www.jstor.org/stable/721803 Alternative Energy Sources for Africa: Potential and Prospects]
[[Category:Geography of Madagascar]]

{{Refimprove|date=June 2011}}
'''Sardeka''' ({{IPA-eu|s̺aɾdeka}}; also ''Xardeka'', ''Chardeka'', ''Chardeca'') is a [[Basque language|Basque]] [[Basque toponymy|place name]] that points out [[mountain pass]]es by analogy of form with a [[fork]].<ref>Basque ''sarde, saharde'' 'fork'</ref> This approach explains the pass name [[Hourquette]] in the [[Gascony|Gascon]] [[Pyrenees]].
The name ''sardeka'' is generally attributed to mounts (borrowed from a neighboring pass): *''Sardeka'': mounts (494 m) in [[Gotein-Libarrenx]], (1 555 m) near ''Pellüsa gaina'' or (1 440  m) near ''Arthanolatze gaina'', *''Sardeka gaina'': a mount (1 893 m) and a crest (1 437 m) near ''Eskantolha'', *''Hargaina Sardeka'' (852 m) in [[Aussurucq]],
== Notes == <references/>

revision.comment: -[[Category:Professional associations based in Saudi Arabia]]; ±[[Category:Learned societies]]→[[Category:Learned societies of Saudi Arabia]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
The '''Saudi Geographical Society''' ({{lang-ar| '''الجمعية الجغرافية السعودية'''}}, ''Aj-jam'aiya Aj-joġrafïya as-Saʻūdiyya''), a [[learned society]] headquartered in [[King Saud University]], [[Riyadh]] in the [[Kingdom of Saudi Arabia]], is a non-for-profit organization for workers and experts in [[geography]]. Its recently elected chairman is Prof. Mohammad Sh. Makki.
By 2005, 251 members were involved in the Society within 5 Research Groups.
==History== The first meeting for the General Congress took place on 22 December 1984. It was ratified by the Higher Education Council in Saudi Arabia under the category of research societies operating in national universities. Previously, many geographic associations were working within the Saudi universities. These associations merged to become the recent ''Society'' that joined the [[International Geographical Union]].
==Mission== SGS is mainly working to encourage research and scientific consultations within geographical aspects related to the area of [[Arabian Peninsula]] and Saudi Arabia, in particular and to publish research and results. It is also dedicated to writing and translating references and publications to [[Arabic]].
==Publications== The Society publishes a bilingual (Arabic and English) biennial refereed and [[Academic journal|scientific Journal]] called "''The Arabian Journal of Geographical Information Systems''" ({{ISSN|1425-2502}}). An annual [[wikt:bulletin|bulletin]] is also published by the Society as ''The Newsletter of Saudi Geographical Society'' focusing more on internal issues and news about new publications, meetings and activities managed by the Society and its partners.
SGS is also printing professional high-quality [[map]]s and managing a [[database]] of geographical information on its server.
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070612161329/http://www.saudigs.org/english/index.php Official website]
{{Saudi Arabia topics}}
[[Category:Learned societies of Saudi Arabia]] [[Category:Geographic societies]] [[Category:Geography of Saudi Arabia]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1984]] [[Category:1984 establishments in Saudi Arabia]]

[[File:Senedd TV.jpg|thumb|250px|Screenshot of the front page of '''senedd.tv''' in 2009]] The [[Senedd]] houses the debating chamber and committee rooms for the [[National Assembly for Wales]] in [[Cardiff]], [[Wales]]. Since the Senedd opened on 1 March 2006, there have been many occasions of the '''Senedd on television''', the most notable being the regular screening of live proceedings from the [[National Assembly for Wales]] on [[S4C2]] and also on [[internet television]].{{cite web | url= http://www.assemblywales.org/abthome/abt-nafw/equalities/equality-scheme-home-page/equality-scheme-access-buildings-information-and-proceedings_.htm| title= Access to our Information, Proceedings and Buildings | publisher= [[National Assembly for Wales]]|accessdate=2009-06-07}} Coverage of the S4C2 screenings are on Tuesdays, Wednesdays and Thursdays between 9:00 am 6:00 pm when the Assembly is sitting.{{cite web | url= http://www.publictechnology.net/modules.php?op=modload&name=News&file=article&sid=15961| title= Web TV will stream proceedings National Assembly for Wales to help e-democracy| publisher= Public Technology Ltd |accessdate=2009-06-07}} In addition, limited screens are shown on the [[BBC Two|BBC Two Wales]] programme ''"am.pm"'', including [[First Minister for Wales|First Minister]]'s Questions.{{cite web | url= http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b006p2y2| title= am.pm| publisher= BBC |accessdate=2009-06-07}} Internet television screenings are shown on the National Assembly's own website www.senedd.tv, which screens approximately 35 hours of content each week in the [[English language|English]] and [[Welsh language]]s. The service began 15 April 2008.{{cite web |url=http://www.assemblywales.org/newhome/new-news-third-assembly.htm?act=dis&id=81543&ds=5/2008| title= Assembly to launch enhanced E-democracy services| publisher= [[National Assembly for Wales]]|accessdate=2009-06-07}} Coverage of events in the Assembly can also be watched on the BBC Democracy Live website.{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/democracylive/hi/wales/default.stm | work=BBC News | date=2011-05-31 | title=Index}} == In popular culture == The Senedd building was involved in what is called the "Sex and the Senedd" controversy.{{cite news | url= https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/pandora/pandora-sex-and-the-senedd-814058.html | title= Pandora: Sex and the Senedd| publisher= [[The Independent]]|accessdate=2009-06-07 | location=London | date=2008-04-23}}{{cite web | url= http://www.bbc.co.uk/wales/radiowales/sites/phonein/updates/20080422.shtml| title= Tuesday 22 April| publisher= BBC|accessdate=2009-06-07}} An episode of ''[[Caerdydd (TV series)|Caerdydd]]'', the [[S4C]] [[Welsh language]] television programme set in [[Cardiff]], which started when the broadcast of the episode shot a sex scene was filmed in a toilet room of the Senedd, and not in a television studio.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/wales/7359846.stm|title=Row over TV sex scene at assembly |date=2008-04-22 |publisher= BBC|accessdate=2009-05-28 }}{{cite web |url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/tv/a94441/welsh-drama-blasted-for-toilet-sex-scene.html|title= Welsh drama blasted for toilet sex scene |publisher= [[Digital Spy]]|accessdate=2009-05-28 }}{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/arts/main.jhtml?xml=/arts/2008/04/22/btvwales122.xml|title=Welsh outrage over Assembly sex scene |publisher=The Daily Telegraph |accessdate=2009-05-28 | location=London | first=Polly | last=Corrigan | date=2008-04-22}} The [[Assembly Commission|National Assembly for Wales Commission]], who approved filming in the Neuadd area, the corridors of the Senedd and for one scene in the baby-changing room, were not made aware of the nature of the scene.{{cite news|title=Welsh fury at 'Sex and the Senedd' shoot |publisher= Times Online |accessdate=2008-04-22 |url=http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/tv_and_radio/article3795750.ece | location=London | first=Philippe | last=Naughton | date=2008-04-22}} The ''[[Doctor Who]]'' episode "''[[The Lazarus Experiment]]''" was filmed in the Senedd,{{cite web | url= http://www.doctorwholocations.net/locations/senedd| title= Senedd Building| publisher= www.doctorwholocations.net |accessdate=2009-04-26}} as was the [[Doctor Who spin-offs|Doctor Who spin-off]] programme ''[[Torchwood]]'', which used the Senedd in the episode "''[[Meat (Torchwood)|Meat]]''", where [[Gwen Cooper]] and [[Rhys Williams (Torchwood)|Rhys Williams]] sit on the steps of the Senedd building. In March 2015 it emerged that the makers of ''[[Spectre (2015 film)|Spectre]]'', the 24th [[James Bond in film|James Bond film]], had requested use of the Senedd's debating chamber for the filming of some scenes, but that this had been declined by Senedd officials, who said the debating chamber was "not a drama studio". Several Welsh politicians, including [[First Minister for Wales|First Minister]] [[Carwyn Jones]] and [[Welsh Conservative Party]] leader [[Andrew R. T. Davies]], cited the decision as a missed opportunity that would have boosted tourism for Wales.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-wales-31868336 |work=BBC News |title=Senedd Bond row: Politicians shaken and stirred |publisher=BBC |date=13 March 2015 |accessdate=14 March 2015}} == Notes == {{reflist|2}} == External links == {{commons category|Senedd}} *[http://www.senedd.tv Live internet television from www.senedd.tv] *[http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b006p2y2 Recorded internet television from the BBC am.pm] [[Category:Politics of Wales]] [[Category:Places in popular culture]] [[Category:Television in Wales]] [[Category:Television programs by topic]] [[Category:Welsh culture]] {{Wales-stub}} {{UK-tv-stub}}

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.6.5)
revision.text:
{{About|mulching in permaculture|the similar but more general technique|Mulch}}
In [[permaculture]], '''sheet mulching''' is an agricultural [[no-dig gardening]] technique that attempts to mimic natural [[forests]]' processes. When deployed properly and in combination with other permacultural principles, it can generate healthy, productive, and low maintenance [[ecosystem]]s.<ref name="agroforestry">{{cite web |last=Elevitch |first=Craig |first2=Kim |last2=Wilkinson |url=http://www.agroforestry.net/pubs/Sheet_Mulching.html |title=Sheet Mulching: Greater Plant and Soil Health for Less Work |publisher=Agroforestry.net |year=1998 |accessdate=November 9, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20021210053204/http://www.agroforestry.net/pubs/Sheet_Mulching.html |archivedate=December 10, 2002 |df= }}</ref><ref name="mason">{{cite book|last=Mason|first=John|title=Sustainable Agriculture|year=2003|publisher=CSIRO|location=Collingwood, Vic.|isbn=978-0-643-06876-6|edition=Second}}</ref>
==Technique==
[[File:Soil profile.png|thumb|180px|right|Typical layers of natural soil.]] A model for sheet mulching consists of the following steps:<ref name="agroforestry" /><ref name="Gaia">{{cite book|last=Hemenway|first=Toby|title=Gaia's Garden: A Guide to Home-Scale Permaculture|year=2009|publisher=Chelsea Green Pub.|location=White River Junction, Vt.|isbn=978-1-60358-029-8|edition=2nd}}</ref>
# The area of interest is flattened by trimming down existing plant species such as [[grass]]es. # The soil is analyzed and its [[Soil pH|pH]] is adjusted (if needed). # The soil is moisturized (if needed) to facilitate the activity of decomposers. # The soil is then covered with a thin layer of slowly decomposing material (known as the '''weed barrier'''), typically cardboard. This suppresses the weeds by blocking sunlight, adds nutrients to the soil as weed matter quickly decays beneath the barrier, and increases the mechanical stability of the growing medium. # A layer (around 10 cm thick) of weed-free soil, rich in nutrients is added, in an attempt to mimic the [[Soil horizon|A horizon]]. # A layer (at most 15 cm thick) of weed-free, woody and leafy matter is added in an attempt to mimic the [[forest floor]] or O Horizon. Theoretically, the soil is now ready to receive the desirable plant seeds.<ref>{{cite news|last=Stout|first=Ruth|title=Ruth Stout's System|url=http://www.motherearthnews.com/Organic-Gardening/2004-02-01/Ruth-Stouts-System.aspx|accessdate=November 9, 2011|newspaper=Mother Earth News|date=February–March 2004}}</ref>
==Variations and considerations==
*Often the barrier is applied a few months before planting to ensure the penetration of roots of newly planted seeds.<ref name="Gaia" /> *Very thick barriers can cause anaerobic conditions. *Some permaculturists incorporate [[compost]]ing in steps 5 and/or 6.<ref name="Gaia" /> *Sheets of newspaper and clothing can be used instead of cardboard.<ref name="Gaia" /> *Before step 4, an initial layer (2–3 kg/m<sup>2</sup>) of matter rich in nutrients (such as compost or manure) may be added to bolster decomposition.<ref name="agroforestry" /> *Some varieties of grasses and weeds may be beneficial in a number of ways. Such plants can be controlled and used rather than eradicated.<ref name="agroforestry" /> See also: [[mulch]], [[list of beneficial weeds]]. *One variation of mulching, called [[hugelkultur]], involves using buried logs and branches as the first layer of the bed.<ref name="Faires">{{citation|author=Nicole Faires|title=The Ultimate Guide to Permaculture|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zNtshW9a-rUC&pg=PT228|accessdate=3 July 2012|publisher=Skyhorse Publishing Inc.|isbn=978-1-62087-316-8|page=228}}</ref>
==Advantages== Sheet mulch has important advantages relative to conventional methods:
*Improvement of desirable plants' health and productivity.<ref name="agroforestry" /> *Retention of water and nutrients and stabilization of [[biochemical cycle]]s.<ref name="agroforestry" /> *Improvement of [[soil structure]], [[soil life]], and prevention of soil [[erosion]].<ref name="agroforestry" /><ref name="stopwaste">{{cite web |url=https://stopwaste.org/home/index.asp?page=398 |title=Sheet Mulching |publisher=StopWaste.Org |date= |accessdate=November 9, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111001123401/http://www.stopwaste.org/home/index.asp?page=398 |archivedate=October 1, 2011 |df= }}</ref> *Avoidance of potentially dangerous [[pesticide]]s, especially [[herbicide]]s. *Reduction of overall maintenance labor and costs.<ref name="stopwaste" />
==Disadvantages==
*Some weed seeds (such as those of [[Cynodon dactylon|Bermuda grass]] and species of [[bindweed]]) may persist under the barrier and within the [[soil seed bank]].<ref name="Gaia" /> * [[Termites]] are attracted to the area. While they are a natural part of the ecosystem that transforms the weed barrier into rich soil, they can pose a hazard to nearby wood-framed structures. *[[Slug]] populations may increase during the early stages of decomposition. However they can be kept away or harvested.<ref name="Gaia" /> *The system may need a constant supply of organic material, at least during the early stages.<ref name="agroforestry" /> *Roaming animals may interrupt the sheet mulching process.<ref name="agroforestry" />
==See also== {{Portal|Gardening}} *[[Agroecology]] *[[Ecoagriculture]] *[[Ecological design]] *[[Ecosystem approach]] *[[Forest gardening]]
== References == {{Reflist|30em}}
{{Permaculture}}
[[Category:Soil improvers]] [[Category:Horticulture and gardening]] [[Category:Organic gardening]] [[Category:Permaculture]] [[Category:Sustainable agriculture]] [[Category:Habitat management equipment and methods]]

{{Infobox UNESCO World Heritage Site | WHS = | image = {{Photomontage | photo1a = Schloss Schönbrunn Wien 2014 (Zuschnitt 2).jpg{{!}}Schönbrunn Palace | photo2a = Wien Rathaus hochauflösend.jpg{{!}}Vienna City Hall, | photo3a = Wien - Stephansdom (1).JPG{{!}}St. Stephen's Cathedral | photo4a = 0101-0102 - Wien - Naitonalbibliothek.jpg{{!}}Hofburg Palace | spacing = 2 | position = center | color_border = white | color = white | size = 266 | foot_montage = }} | image_upright = 1.2 | caption = Descending, from top: [[Schönbrunn Palace]], [[Rathaus, Vienna|City Hall]], [[St. Stephen's Cathedral, Vienna|St. Stephen's Cathedral]], and [[Hofburg Palace]] | location = [[Vienna]], [[Austria]] | website = {{URL|https://www.wien.gv.at/}} | embedded = {{Infobox UNESCO World Heritage Site | child = yes | official_name = [[Palace and Gardens of Schönbrunn]] | criteria = {{UNESCO WHS type|(i)(iv)}}(i)(iv) | ID = 786 | year = 1996 | area = {{convert|186.28|ha|acre|abbr=on}} | buffer_zone = {{convert|260.64|ha|acre|abbr=on}} }}{{Infobox UNESCO World Heritage Site | child = yes | official_name = [[Historic Centre of Vienna]] | criteria = {{UNESCO WHS type|(ii)(iv)(vi)}}(ii)(iv)(vi) | ID = 1033 | year = 2001 | danger = 2017–... | area = {{convert|371|ha|sqmi|abbr=on}} | buffer_zone = {{convert|462|ha|sqmi|abbr=on}} }} | locmapin = | map_caption = }} The '''tourist attractions of Vienna''' concentrate in three distinct areas. The largest cluster, centred on [[Schönbrunn Palace]], attracted around five million visitors in 2009, down from six million in 2008. Museums and exhibitions of [[Hofburg Palace]] accounted for nearly two million visitors in 2008, with a significant decline in 2009. The third, and the newest, cluster of modern art museums in [[Museumsquartier]] attracted less than one million visitors.According to the Vienna Tourist Board, the Schönbrunn cluster includes the Palace itself, [[Tiergarten Schönbrunn]], the Palmenhaus, the Wüstenhaus, the Imperial Coach Collection (Wagenburg), the Maze Gardens (Irrgarten) and the Privy Gardens (KronPrinzgarten). See ''[http://www.wientourismus.at/media/files-b2b/besucherfrequenzen-2007 Sehenwurdigkeiten 2007 (in German)]{{Dead link|date=July 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }}'' and ''[http://www.wientourismus.at/media/files-b2b/besucherfrequenzen-2008 Sehenwurdigkeiten 2008 (in German)]{{Dead link|date=July 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }}'' for exact composition of each of three clusters. Nearby duo of [[Kunsthistorisches Museum|Kunsthistorisches]] and [[Naturhistorisches Museum|Naturhistorisches]] museums, located halfway between Museumsquartier and Hofburg, also reported around one million visitors. The [[Landstraße]] district, which lies south-east of the [[Innere Stadt|old city]], is home to art exhibitions at the [[Belvedere (palace)|Belvedere Palace]] and the [[KunstHausWien]]. Vienna stands out among other European tourist destinations for being a "new old city", a city in transition from an older "picture city" like [[Florence]] and [[Venice]] to being a [[global city]] like [[Paris]] and [[London]].Mazanec, Wober pp. 185-187. For six consecutive years, 2003–2008, tourism industry was on the rise, but in 2009 the [[financial crisis of 2007–2010|global financial crisis]] caused a sharp decline, especially in long-distance tourism from Asia and North America. The new museums of modern art retained or even increased their attendance, but museums of classical art lost more than a third of their former ticket sales. According to preliminary data for the first half of 2010, Vienna is already past the bottom of the crisis and visitor numbers are rising again. In 2013, Vienna was ranked the world’s most livable city for the fifth consecutive year, playing host to 5.8 million tourists, a growth of over four percent as compared to 2012.{{cite web|title=Vienna seeks to double its Indian Tourist Inflow by 2020|url=http://news.biharprabha.com/2014/02/vienna-seeks-to-double-its-indian-tourist-inflow-by-2020/|work=IANS|publisher=news.biharprabha.com|accessdate=25 February 2014}} ==Effects of the global crisis== In 2003–2008 the Austrian tourism industry enjoyed a six-year streak of growth, with each year beating the previous record by an average 2.1%.''[http://diepresse.com/home/panorama/oesterreich/534498/index.do?from=suche.intern.portal Umsatzeinbrüche im Tourismus (in German)]''. Die Presse, January 22 (Web edition: January 21), 2010. Retrieved 2010-08-22.OECD 2010, pp. 16, 123-124. Tourism generated 8.4% of Austrian [[gross domestic product]] (23.6 billion Euros) and provided 181 thousand jobs.OECD 2010, p. 119. The "top ten" of Vienna's tourist attractions in this period included the [[Schönbrunn Palace]], [[Tiergarten Schönbrunn]], the [[Albertina, Vienna|Albertina]], the [[Wiener Riesenrad]], the [[Hofburg Palace]] museums, the [[Belvedere (palace)|Belvedere]], the [[Kunsthistorisches Museum|Kunsthistorisches]] and [[Naturhistorisches Museum|Naturhistorisches]] museums, the [[KunstHausWien]] and the [[Donauturm]] observation deck. In 2008, the effects of the unfolding [[financial crisis of 2007–2010|global financial crisis]] on the economy were more than offset by a boost from the [[UEFA Euro 2008]]. The number of tourists reached an all-time high, although during the tournament itself museum attendance dropped by 60%, and theatres cancelled their shows altogether.Kimmelman, Michael (2008). ''[https://www.nytimes.com/2015/06/26/arts/design/26abroad.html?_r=1&scp=4&sq=Vienna+museum+crisis&st=nyt In Battle for Vienna: Soccer 1, Culture 0]''. ''The New York Times'', June 26, 2008. Retrieved 2010-08-25. The crisis hit the Austrian tourist industry in the first quarter of 2009, when international tourist arrivals dropped by 8.6%.Relative to the record high recorded in the first quarter of 2008. - OECD 2010, p. 19. Museum attendance suffered disproportionately higher losses. Ticket sales at Hofburg palace exhibitions dropped by 20%. Tickets sales at the [[Albertina, Vienna|Albertina]], the most visited art collection in Vienna, dropped by more than a third, from 997 thousand in 2008 to 630 thousand in 2009. Its former third place in the list of Viennese attractions was taken over by the [[Wiener Riesenrad]]. The Schönbrunn Palace also recorded a drop in visitors, but its profits actually ''increased'' by a third.''[http://diepresse.com/home/panorama/wien/585475/index.do?from=suche.intern.portal Schönbrunn ist Wiens beliebteste Sehenswürdigkeit (in German)]''. Die Presse. August 9 (Web edition: August 8), 2010. Retrieved 2010-08-22. Tiergarten Schönbrunn reported a "record drop" of 70% in February 2009Compared to February 2008, which was an all-time high record month. In February 2008, the Tiergarten began displaying the [[giant panda]] and [[polar bear]] cubs, which attracted unusually high numbers of local visitors. - ''[http://diepresse.com/home/panorama/oesterreich/468044/index.do?from=suche.intern.portal Eintrittspreise: Was alles teurer wird (in German)]''. Die Presse. April 6, 2009 (printed edition: April 7). Retrieved 2010-08-28. (50% for the first quarter of 2009). Practically all museums and zoos increased ticket prices, by an average of 16.7%, the first price hike since the [[History of the euro#Creation|introduction of the Euro]] in 2002.''[http://diepresse.com/home/panorama/oesterreich/468044/index.do?from=suche.intern.portal Eintrittspreise: Was alles teurer wird (in German)]''. Die Presse. April 6, 2009 (printed edition: April 7). Retrieved 2010-08-28. According to the Vienna Tourist Board, in 2009 the city's hotels recorded 4.385 million visitors (2008: 4.593 million). 20% of the visitors were Austrians, 24% were Germans, 5% Italians and 5% Americans. The worst losses were recorded among tourists from Asia, North America and Eastern Europe.''[http://b2b.wien.info/article.asp?IDArticle=3942 Arrivals & Overnights 2009 (data for January-December 2009)]''. Vienna Tourist Board. Retrieved 2010-08-22. The state responded with promoting Austria in the neighbouring countries to compensate the losses in long-distance international tourism.OECD 2010, p. 123. In the end of 2009, the trend reversed with an increase in tourists from [[Japan]], [[Italy]], [[Spain]], [[Greece]] and [[Russia]]. Recovery continued in the first half of 2010. Schönbrunn Palace recorded a 5% increase in ticket sales compared to the first half of 2009, Hofburg had a twelve per cent increase.''[http://diepresse.com/home/panorama/oesterreich/580194 Tourismus: Schönbrunn trotzt Krise (in German)]''. Die Presse, July 10 (Web edition: July 9), 2010. Retrieved 2010-08-22. ==Ranking of tourist attractions== Annual rankings of tourist attractions are compiled and published by the Vienna Tourist Board (German: [[:de:WienTourismus|Wiener Tourismusverband]]). The underlying tickets sales statistics counts all visitors, tourists and Viennese natives, together. Freely accessible landmarks are omitted from the statistics altogether. The symbol of Vienna, [[St. Stephen's Cathedral, Vienna|St. Stephen's Cathedral]], ranks only seventeenth: the number (218,000 visitors in 2009) represents sales of tickets to its underground crypts, but access to the cathedral itself is free. The [[Schönbrunn Palace]] counts each entry by a holder of a multi-entry ticket as a separate visit. Thus, for example, in 2008 it sold 1.98 million tickets, but reported 2.581 million ''entries''.''[http://diepresse.com/home/panorama/wien/494693/index.do?from=suche.intern.portal Schloss Schönbrunn: Rekordumsatz trotz Fußball-EM (in German)]''. Die Presse. July 13, 2009. Retrieved 2010-08-22. The Palmenhaus and the Wüstenhaus, tropical landscape exhibits in the historic greenhouses of [[Tiergarten Schönbrunn]], are counted as separate tourist attractions. The three Hofburg exhibitions (the Imperial Apartments, [[Elisabeth of Bavaria|Sisi Museum]] and the Imperial Silver collection) are usually visited as a package, and each combo ticket is counted as one visit.''[http://diepresse.com/home/wirtschaft/economist/317794/index.do?from=suche.intern.portal Schloss Schönbrunn Top-Sehenswürdigkeit Wiens (in German)]''. Die Presse. July 18, 2007. Retrieved 2010-08-22. {| class="wikitable" |- ! rowspan=2 | Rank

Retrieved 2010-08-28. ! 2007''[http://www.wientourismus.at/media/files-b2b/besucherfrequenzen2007.pdf (in German)]''. Vienna Tourist Board.
